Latitudinarianism: A latitudinarian system or condition; freedom of opinion in matters pertaining to religious belief.
Lineman: One who carries the line in surveying, etc.; the surveyor who marks positions with a range pole.
Lead: The act of leading or conducting; guidance; direction; as, to take the lead; to be under the lead of another.
Leak: To let water or other fluid in or out through a hole, crevice, etc.; as, the cask leaks; the roof leaks; the boat leaks.
Lambent: Playing on the surface; touching lightly; gliding over.
Logania: The type genus of the Loganiaceae; Australian and New Zealand shrubs sometimes cultivated for their flowers.
Leam: A cord or strap for leading a dog.
Lear: An annealing oven. See Leer, n.
Leap: The act of leaping, or the space passed by leaping; a jump; a spring; a bound.
Landlock: To inclose, or nearly inclose, as a harbor or a vessel, with land.
Leat: An artificial water trench, esp. one to or from a mill.
Leucaniline: A colorless, crystalline, organic base, obtained from rosaniline by reduction, and also from other sources. It forms colorless salts.
Leaf: To shoot out leaves; to produce leaves; to leave; as, the trees leaf in May.
Lamellirostral: Having a lamellate bill, as ducks and geese.
&Verbar;Lusus natur\u00e6: Sport or freak of nature; a deformed or unnatural production.
localized: confined or restricted to a particular location; as, the localized infection formed a definite abscess.   Contrasted with disseminated or systemic.
Lycaeon: A genus of canids including the African hunting dog.
Lingism: A mode of treating certain diseases, as obesity, by gymnastics; -- proposed by Pehr Henrik Ling, a Swede. See Kinesiatrics.
lepidopteron: An insect that in the adult state has four wings more or less covered with tiny scales.
Long primer: A kind of type, in size between small pica and bourgeois.
Lanai: an island in the Hawaiian chain.
Lanner: A long-tailed falcon (Falco lanarius), of Southern Europe, Asia, and Northern Africa, resembling the American prairie falcon.
Laicality: The state or quality of being laic; the state or condition of a layman.
Lixivium: A solution of alkaline salts extracted from wood ashes; hence, any solution obtained by lixiviation.
Locusta: The spikelet or flower cluster of grasses.
League: To join in a league; to cause to combine for a joint purpose; to combine; to unite; as, common interests will league heterogeneous elements.
&Verbar;Loutou: A crested black monkey (Semnopithecus maurus) of Java.
Lean: That part of flesh which consists principally of muscle without the fat.
Leatherwood: A small branching shrub (Dirca palustris), with a white, soft wood, and a tough, leathery bark, common in damp woods in the Northern United States; -- called also moosewood, and wicopy.
lincomycin: An antibacterial antibiotic obtained from the bacterium Streptomyces lincolnensis and used in the treatment of certain penicillin-resistant infections.
Lacinia: One of the narrow, jagged, irregular pieces or divisions which form a sort of fringe on the borders of the petals of some flowers.
Lithofellic: Pertaining to, or designating, a crystalline, organic acid, resembling cholic acid, found in the biliary intestinal concretions (bezoar stones) common in certain species of antelope.
laurel-tree: A small tree (Persea borbonia) of the Southern U. S. having dark red heartwood.
Lockout: The closing of a factory or workshop by an employer, usually in order to bring the workmen to satisfactory terms by a suspension of wages.
low-tension: subjected to or capable of operating under relative low voltage.  Contrasted with high-tension.
&Verbar;Lambda: The name of the Greek letter Λ, λ, corresponding with the English letter L, l.
&Verbar;Lectica: A kind of litter or portable couch.
Lanarkite: A mineral consisting of sulphate of lead, occurring either massive or in long slender prisms, of a greenish white or gray color.
&Verbar;Lorette: In France, a name for a woman who is supported by her lovers, and devotes herself to idleness, show, and pleasure; -- so called from the church of Notre Dame de Lorette, in Paris, near which many of them resided.
Lest: For fear that; that . . . not; in order that . . . not.
Lonchocarpus: A genus of chiefly tropical American shrubs and trees having pinnate leaves and red or white flowers.
Legalism: Strictness, or the doctrine of strictness, in conforming to law.
long-wearing: withstanding long use without deterioration; resistant to damage.
laurels: An honor or honors conferred for some notable achievement.
Libellee: The party against whom a libel has been filed; -- corresponding to defendant in a common law action.
Lustrate: To make clear or pure by means of a propitiatory offering; to purify.
Low-studded: Furnished or built with short studs; as, a low-studded house or room.
Lanolin: A peculiar fatlike body, made up of cholesterin and certain fatty acids, found in feathers, hair, wool, and keratin tissues generally.
Leafy: Full of leaves; abounding in leaves; as, the leafy forest.
Legalist: One who practices or advocates strict conformity to law; in theology, one who holds to the law of works. See Legal, 2 (a).
leaders: the body of people who lead a group; the leadership{3}; as, they hung the leaders of the insurrection.
&Verbar;Limicol\u00e6: A group of shore birds, embracing the plovers, sandpipers, snipe, curlew, etc.; the Grallæ.
Locular: Of or relating to the cell or compartment of an ovary, etc.; in composition, having cells; as trilocular.
Lodge: To give shelter or rest to; especially, to furnish a sleeping place for; to harbor; to shelter; hence, to receive; to hold.
Liquescent: Tending to become liquid; inclined to melt; melting.
Lection: A lesson or selection, especially of Scripture, read in divine service.
Lyginopteridales: An order of fossil gymnospermous trees or climbing plants from the Devonian: the seed ferns.
Lure: To recall a hawk or other animal.
Lycopus: A small genus of nonaromatic herbs of the mint family.
LSD: lysergic acid diethylamide, a powerful hallucinogenic drug.
Lingot: A linget or ingot; also, a mold for casting metals. See Linget.
Lucknow: A city in India, the site of the Indian Mutiny (1857) when the British were beseiged.
Lustily: In a lusty or vigorous manner.
lampshade: a protective ornamental covering used to screen the light bulb in a lamp from direct view.
Ladys finger: The kidney vetch, Anthyllis vulneraria; called also lady's fingers.
Laborious: Requiring labor, perseverance, or sacrifices; toilsome; tiresome.
Light-hearted: Free from grief or anxiety; gay; cheerful; merry.
Logarithmic: Of or pertaining to logarithms; consisting of logarithms.
Lussheburgh: A spurious coin of light weight imported into England from Luxemburg, or Lussheburgh, as it was formerly called.
Logging: The business of felling trees, cutting them into logs, and transporting the logs to sawmills or to market.
&Verbar;Lepidoptera: An order of insects, which includes the butterflies and moths. They have broad wings, covered with minute overlapping scales, usually brightly colored.
latchkey child: A child who frequently spends part of the day at home without adult supervision, especially a school child who returns home before the parent(s) return from work.  Called also door-key child.
Latrine: A privy, or water-closet, esp. in a camp, hospital, etc.
lamedh: The 12th letter of the Hebrew alphabet, corresponding to l.
&Verbar;Limuloidea: An order of Merostomata, including among living animals the genus Limulus, with various allied fossil genera, mostly of the Carboniferous period. Called also Xiphosura.
LF: low frequency, a term used to refer to radio waves of a frequency from 30 to 300 kilohertz.  Contrasted to HF, high frequency.
Liable: Bound or obliged in law or equity; responsible; answerable; as, the surety is liable for the debt of his principal.
loanword: a word borrowed from another language; e.g. blitz is a German word borrowed into modern English.
Labrador: A region of British America on the Atlantic coast, north of Newfoundland.
Lupercal: A grotto on the Palatine Hill sacred to Lupercus, the Lycean Pan.
Lettuce: A composite plant of the genus Lactuca (Lactuca sativa), the leaves of which are used as salad.  Plants of this genus yield a milky juice, from which lactucarium is obtained.  The commonest wild lettuce of the United States is Lactuca Canadensis.
Latinistic: Of, pertaining to, or derived from, Latin; in the Latin style or idiom.
loincloth: A cloth covering for the loins, worn around the hips; -- sometimes worn in tropical areas as the only article of clothing.
lacertid: Any lizard of the family Lacertidae, a family of Old World terrestrial lizard.
Lentiscus: A tree; the mastic. See Mastic.
Lachrymation: The act of shedding tears; weeping.
laser disk: A digital data storage medium consisting of a thin disk onto which the data is impressed by a laser, in the form of a linear sequence of dots; same as optical disk.  The data is subsequently read back by the use of a laser beam.  See also compact disk.
Legislation: The act of legislating; preparation and enactment of laws; the laws enacted.
Lichened: Belonging to, or covered with, lichens.
Landflood: An overflowing of land by river; an inundation; a freshet.
Lampoon: To subject to abusive ridicule expressed in a work of art; to make (a person, behavior, or institution) the subject of a lampoon.
Lithobilic: Pertaining to or designating an organic acid of the tartaric acid series, distinct from lithofellic acid, but, like it, obtained from certain bile products, as bezoar stones.
Lagostomus: A mammal genus comprising the viscachas.
&Verbar;Lithargyrum: Crystallized litharge, obtained by fusion in the form of fine yellow scales.
Lotion: A washing, especially of the skin for the purpose of rendering it fair.
Leontopodium: A genus of plants including the edelweiss (Leontopodium alpinum).
Leech: To treat as a surgeon; to doctor; as, to leech wounds.
Lindiform: Resembling the genus Lindia; -- said of certain apodous insect larvæ.
Lighten: To make lighter, or less heavy; to reduce in weight; to relieve of part of a load or burden; as, to lighten a ship by unloading; to lighten a load or burden.
Livelong: Whole; entire; long in passing; -- used of time, as day or night, in adverbial phrases, and usually with a sense of tediousness.
lessening: a change downward; a decrease; a reduction.
Lighter: To convey by a lighter, as to or from the shore; as, to lighter the cargo of a ship.
lobsterback: A British soldier in the 1700's; -- so-called because of his red coat, esp. during the American Revolutionary War.
Lieberk\u00fchn: A concave metallic mirror attached to the object-glass end of a microscope, to throw down light on opaque objects; a reflector.
Lignin: A substance characterizing wood cells and differing from cellulose in its conduct with certain chemical reagents.
Laceman: A man who deals in lace.
Lopping: A cutting off, as of branches; that which is cut off; leavings.
loony: someone mentally deranged and possibly dangerous.
Laborsome: Made with, or requiring, great labor, pains, or diligence.
Liquescency: The quality or state of being liquescent.
Lamentable: Mourning; sorrowful; expressing grief; as, a lamentable countenance.
laser printer: A printer controlled by a computer, using a laser beam to produce images in a fine dot-matrix pattern of charge on an electrostatic drum, to which fine particles of ink are subsequently caused to adhere, and the image of which is subsequently transferred to paper or another type of material in sheet form.  It is capable of high-speed production of images with a higher resolution than those from dot-matrix impact printers.
&Verbar;Lumen: A unit of illumination, being the amount of illumination of a unit area of spherical surface, due to a light of unit intensity placed at the center of the sphere.
Lunt: The match cord formerly used in firing cannon.
lipid-lowering: Serving to reduce the concentration of lipid, such as cholesterol, in the blood; -- of medications, such as Mevinolin, that are used especially to reduce blood cholesterol, as a preventive measure against heart disease.
lasiocampid: A member of the Lasiocampidae, a family of medium-sized stout-bodied neutral-colored moth with comblike antennae.
laparoscope: A slender endoscope, containing fiber-optic viewing capability and miniature surgical devices, which can be inserted through a small incision in the abdominal wall, allowing a surgeon to perform minor surgery with minimal damage to the abdominal muscles.
littered: having articles scattered about in a disorderly fashion.
Lung: An organ for aërial respiration; -- commonly in the plural.
Lune: Anything in the shape of a half moon.
Loord: A dull, stupid fellow; a drone.
Leucorrh\u0153a: A discharge of a white, yellowish, or greenish, viscid mucus, resulting from inflammation or irritation of the membrane lining the genital organs of the female; the whites.
&Verbar;Lymphoma: A tumor having a structure resembling that of a lymphatic gland; -- called also lymphadenoma.
Levelly: In an even or level manner.
Lie: The position or way in which anything lies; the lay, as of land or country.
Lif: The fiber by which the petioles of the date palm are bound together, from which various kinds of cordage are made.
La: Look; see; behold; -- sometimes followed by you.
Lin: A pool or collection of water, particularly one above or below a fall of water.
Li: A Chinese measure of distance, being a little more than one third of a mile.
Lexicography: The art, process, or occupation of making a lexicon or dictionary; the principles which are applied in making dictionaries; as, with so many words lexicography can be interesting in parts but at length is rather tedious labor.
Lodicule: One of the two or three delicate membranous scales which are next to the stamens in grasses.
Lore: That which is or may be learned or known; the knowledge gained from tradition, books, or experience; often, the whole body of knowledge possessed by a people or class of people, or pertaining to a particular subject; as, the lore of the Egyptians; priestly lore; legal lore; folklore.
Lord: To play the lord; to domineer; to rule with arbitrary or despotic sway; -- sometimes with over; and sometimes with it in the manner of a transitive verb; as, rich students lording it over their classmates.
Lockjaw: A contraction of the muscles of the jaw by which its motion is suspended; a variety of tetanus; trismus.
Legitim: The portion of movable estate to which the children are entitled upon the death of the father.
Livre: A French money of account, afterward a silver coin equal to 20 sous. It is not now in use, having been superseded by the franc.
Lloyds: An association of underwriters and others in London, for the collection and diffusion of marine intelligence, the insurance, classification, registration, and certifying of vessels, and the transaction of business of various kinds connected with shipping.
&Verbar;Lima\u00e7on: A curve of the fourth degree, invented by Pascal. Its polar equation is r = a cos θ + b.
lordless: having no lord or master; as, the “ronin” of Japan were lordless samurai.
Lapstreak: Made with boards whose edges lap one over another; clinker-built; -- said of boats.  Contrasted with carvel-built.
lab: Of or pertaining to a laboratory; as, a lab bench.
Ligamental: Composing a ligament; of the nature of a ligament; binding; as, a strong ligamentous membrane.
lav: Same as lavatory{5}; -- a shortened form of the word.
Lenten: Of or pertaining to the fast called Lent; used in, or suitable to, Lent; as, the Lenten season.
Log-chip: A thin, flat piece of board in the form of a quadrant of a circle attached to the log line; -- called also log-ship. See 2d Log, n., 2.
&Verbar;Latitat: A writ based upon the presumption that the person summoned was hiding.
Lymphogenic: Connected with, or formed in, the lymphatic glands.
Lateness: The state, condition, or quality, of being late; as, the lateness of his arrival; the lateness of the hour; the lateness of the season.
Labialize: To modify by contraction of the lip opening.
Laryngologist: One who applies himself to laryngology.
&Verbar;Lytta: A fibrous and muscular band lying within the longitudinal axis of the tongue in many mammals, as the dog.
lightship: A vessel equipped like a lighthouse, carrying at the masthead a brilliant light, and moored off a shoal or place of dangerous navigation where a permanent lighthouse would be impracticable, to serve as a guide for mariners; as, the Ambrose lightship off New York was rammed and damaged in 1950 by the Santa Monica.
Landscape: A portion of land or territory which the eye can comprehend in a single view, including all the objects it contains.
Litigiousness: The state of being litigious; disposition to engage in or carry on lawsuits.
Lawmonger: A trader in law; one who practices law as if it were a trade.
Loxodromics: The art or method of sailing on the loxodromic or rhumb line.
Literate: One educated, but not having taken a university degree; especially, such a person who is prepared to take holy orders.
lindy: an energetic American dance that was popular in the 1930s (probably named for the aviator Charles Lindbergh).
Limation: The act of filing or polishing.
Lobular: Like a lobule; pertaining to a lobule or lobules.
Letheon: Sulphuric ether used as an anæsthetic agent.
Landgrave: A German nobleman of a rank corresponding to that of an earl in England and of a count in France.
low-key: restrained in style or quality; not flashy or intense; understated; as, a little masterpiece of low-keyed eloquence.
Leonid: One of the shooting stars which constitute the star shower that recurs near the fourteenth of November at intervals of about thirty-three years; -- so called because these shooting stars appear on the heavens to move in lines directed from the constellation Leo.
lifeline: The anem given to one of the creases on the palm; its length is said by palmists to indicate how long one will live.
Limaceous: Pertaining to, or like, Limax, or the slugs.
Lecithin: A complex, nitrogenous phosphorized substance widely distributed through the animal body, and especially conspicuous in the brain and nerve tissue, in yolk of eggs, and in the white blood corpuscles.
Legality: The state or quality of being legal; conformity to law.
Legendary: A book of legends; a tale or narrative.
Ligulate: Like a bandage, or strap; strap-shaped.
Linseed: The seeds of flax, from which linseed oil is obtained.
Lacustral: Found in, or pertaining to, lakes or ponds, or growing in them; as, lacustrine flowers.
Ladys thumb: An annual weed (Polygonum Persicaria), having a lanceolate leaf with a dark spot in the middle.
Longitude: Length; measure or distance along the longest line; -- distinguished from breadth or thickness; as, the longitude of a room; rare now, except in a humorous sense.
Leprosy: A cutaneous disease which first appears as blebs or as reddish, shining, slightly prominent spots, with spreading edges. These are often followed by an eruption of dark or yellowish prominent nodules, frequently producing great deformity. In one variety of the disease, anæsthesia of the skin is a prominent symptom. In addition there may be wasting of the muscles, falling out of the hair and nails, and distortion of the hands and feet with destruction of the bones and joints. It is incurable, and is probably contagious.
Ladys comb: An umbelliferous plant (Scandix Pecten-Veneris), its clusters of long slender fruits remotely resembling a comb.
&Verbar;Levana: A goddess who protected newborn infants.
Leucic: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid obtained from leucin, and called also oxycaproic acid.
Lassitude: A condition of the body, or mind, when its voluntary functions are performed with difficulty, and only by a strong exertion of the will; languor; debility; weariness.
Liberal: One who favors greater freedom in political or religious matters; an opponent of the established systems; a reformer; in English politics, a member of the Liberal party, so called.  Cf. Whig.
Laoco\u00f6n: A priest of Apollo, during the Trojan war. (See 2.)
Leprosity: The state or quality of being leprous or scaly; also, a scale.
Lign-aloes: Aloes wood, or agallochum. See     Agallochum.
Largeness: The quality or state of being large.
Lepismoid: Like or pertaining to the Lepisma.
leaf cutter: Any one of various species of wild bees of the genus Megachile, which cut rounded pieces from the edges of leaves, or the petals of flowers, to be used in the construction of their nests, which are made in holes and crevices, or in a leaf rolled up for the purpose. Among the common American species are Megachile brevis and Megachile centuncularis. Called also rose-cutting bee.
lower limit: the limit on the lower (or southernmost) side of something.
&Verbar;loma: A lobe; a membranous fringe or flap.
Lenitive: A medicine or application that has the quality of easing pain or protecting from the action of irritants.
lifted: turned upward; as, she left the room with her face lifted.
Lycoperdales: A small order of basidiomycetous fungi having fleshy often globose fruiting bodies: puffpalls; earthstars.
Licorice: A plant of the genus Glycyrrhiza (Glycyrrhiza glabra), the root of which abounds with a sweet juice, and is much used in demulcent compositions.
Lentoid: Having the form of a lens; lens-shaped.
Luciform: Having, in some respects, the nature of light; resembling light.
Latitude: Extent from side to side, or distance sidewise from a given point or line; breadth; width.
litterer: a person who litters public places with refuse.
looseleaf: having rings that open and close permitting insertion and removal of pages; -- of notebooks and binders and the paper used in them; as, a looseleaf notebook; looseleaf paper.
Lungfish: Any fish belonging to the Dipnoi; -- so called because they have both lungs and gills.
Levyne: A whitish, reddish, or yellowish, transparent or translucent mineral, allied to chabazite.
laser beam: A beam of light from a laser.
Lienal: Of or pertaining to the spleen; splenic.
Latching: A loop or eye formed on the head rope of a bonnet, by which it is attached to the foot of a sail; -- called also latch and lasket.
Levy: To seize property, real or personal, or subject it to the operation of an execution; to make a levy; as, to levy on property; the usual mode of levying, in England, is by seizing the goods.
Literality: The state or quality of being literal.
&Verbar;Levari facias: A writ of execution at common law.
Lowbred: Bred, or like one bred, in a low condition of life; characteristic or indicative of such breeding; rude; impolite; vulgar; as, a lowbred fellow; a lowbred remark.
Lactonic: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid obtained by the oxidation of milk sugar (lactose).
Lability: Liability to lapse, err, or apostatize.
Lamelliferous: Bearing, or composed of, lamellæ, or thin layers, plates, or scales; foliated.
Linen: Thread or cloth made of flax or (rarely) of hemp; -- used in a general sense to include cambric, shirting, sheeting, towels, tablecloths, etc.; as, bed linens
&Verbar;Lagena: The terminal part of the cochlea in birds and most reptiles; an appendage of the sacculus, corresponding to the cochlea, in fishes and amphibians.
Lycaenidae: A natural family of small usually brilliantly colored butterflies; males have short forelegs.
Lodgeable: That may be or can be lodged; as, so many persons are not lodgeable in this village.
Litter: To be supplied with litter as bedding; to sleep or make one's bed in litter.
Laughsome: Exciting laughter; also, addicted to laughter; merry.
Labiate: A plant of the order Labiatæ.
leporide: red breed of domestic rabbits, also called Belgian hare.
Landgraviate: The territory held by a landgrave.
Lexiphanic: Using, or interlarded with, pretentious words; bombastic; as, a lexiphanic writer or speaker; lexiphanic writing.
Lopsided: Leaning to one side because of some defect of structure; as, a lopsided ship.
Literalist: One who adheres to the letter or exact word; an interpreter according to the letter.
Lengthily: In a lengthy manner; at great length or extent.
Ladys cushion: An herb growing in dense tufts; the thrift (Armeria vulgaris).
Lophobranchiate: Of or pertaining to the Lophobranchii.
&Verbar;Longipennes: A group of longwinged sea birds, including the gulls, petrels, etc.
loaded: containing as much or as many as is possible; -- of containers, vehicles, trays, etc.; as, a tray loaded with dishes
lockmaster: a worker in charge of a lock (on a canal).
&Verbar;Leucoma: A white opacity in the cornea of the eye; -- called also albugo.
Liturgiology: The science treating of liturgical matters; a treatise on, or description of, liturgies.
Linstock: A pointed forked staff, shod with iron at the foot, to hold a lighted match for firing cannon.
Langaha: A curious colubriform snake of the genus Xyphorhynchus, from Madagascar. It is brownish red, and its nose is prolonged in the form of a sharp blade.
Lump together: To combine (various items) and treat them as a unit.  See lump, v. i.
Living picture: A tableau in which persons take part; also, specif., such a tableau as imitating a work of art.
Luckiness: The state or quality of being lucky; as, the luckiness of a man or of an event.
Lobster thermidor: a dish of lobster meat cooked with a rich creamy wine sauce, stuffed back into the lobster shell, sprinkled with grated cheese, and browned.
Laburnum: A small leguminous tree (Cytisus Laburnum), native of the Alps. The plant is reputed to be poisonous, esp. the bark and seeds. It has handsome racemes of yellow blossoms.
Luminescence: Any emission of light not ascribable directly to incandescence, and therefore occurring at low temperatures, as in phosphorescence and fluorescence or other luminous radiation resulting from vital processes, chemical action, friction, solution, or the influence of light or of ultraviolet or cathode rays, etc.
Layia: A genus of Western U. S. annuals with showy yellow or white flowers.
Lituiform: Having the form of a lituus; like a lituite.
Lithotypic: Of, pertaining to, or produced by, lithotypy.
lathee: a heavy stick (often bamboo) bound with iron; used by police in India.
Lysimeter: An instrument for measuring the water that percolates through a certain depth of soil.
&Verbar;Littorina: A genus of small pectinibranch mollusks, having thick spiral shells, abundant between tides on nearly all rocky seacoasts. They feed on seaweeds. The common periwinkle is a well-known example. See Periwinkle.
Lactamic: Pertaining to, or designating, an amido acid related to lactic acid, and called also amido-propionic acid.
Loudness: The quality or state of being loud.
Latch: To catch so as to hold.
&Verbar;Linum: A genus of herbaceous plants including the flax (Linum usitatissimum).
Loquacious: Given to continual talking; talkative; garrulous.
Leptology: A minute and tedious discourse on trifling things.
Liparidae: A natural family including the snailfishes.
Leptiform: Having a form somewhat like leptus; -- said of active insect larvæ having three pairs of legs. See Larva.
Leve: To grant; -- used esp. in exclamations or prayers followed by a dependent clause.
Legionry: A body of legions; legions, collectively.
Laryngograph: An instrument for recording the larynx movements in speech.
Loiseleuria: A genus of plants having only one species, the alpine azalea.
Lay shaft: A secondary shaft, as in a sliding change gear for an automobile; a cam shaft operated by a two-to-one gear in an internal-combustion engine. It is generally a shaft moving more or less independently of the other parts of a machine, as, in some marine engines, a shaft, driven by a small auxiliary engine, for independently operating the valves of the main engine to insure uniform motion.
&Verbar;Landdrost: A chief magistrate in rural districts. He was replaced in 1827 by “resident magistrates.”
Ladys slipper: Any orchidaceous plant of the genus Cypripedium, the labellum of which resembles a slipper. Less commonly, in the United States, the garden balsam (Impatiens Balsamina).
lunchtime: the time for eating lunch; as, he observed a regular lunchtime.
Low-mindedness: The quality of being low-minded; meanness; baseness.
Lithotint: A kind of lithography by which the effect of a tinted drawing is produced, as if made with India ink.
Livery stable: A stable where horses are kept for hire, and where stabling is provided. See Livery, n., 3 (e) (f) & (g).
&Verbar;Lycoperdon: A genus of fungi, remarkable for the great quantity of spores, forming a fine dust, which is thrown out like smoke when the plant is compressed or burst; puffball.
lycee: A French lyceum, or secondary school for students intermediate between elementary school and college, supported by the French government, for preparing students for the university.
L-plate: a square plate bearing the letter L that is attached to both ends of a car to indicate that the driver is a learner.
Lungis: A lingerer; a dull, drowsy fellow.
Linnaea: A genus with only one species, the twinflower.
Lachrymatory: A “tear-bottle;” a narrow-necked vessel found in sepulchers of the ancient Romans; -- so called from a former notion that the tears of the deceased person's friends were collected in it. Called also lachrymal or lacrymal.
Lifting: Used in, or for, or by, lifting.
Lachrymals: Tears; also, lachrymal feelings or organs.
Leucitoid: The trapezohedron or tetragonal trisoctahedron; -- so called as being the form of the mineral leucite.
&Verbar;Labipalpus: One of the labial palpi of an insect. See Illust. under Labium.
&Verbar;Lignum rhodium: The fragrant wood of several shrubs and trees, especially of species of Rhodorhiza from the Canary Islands, and of the West Indian Amyris balsamifera.
Linchpin: A pin used to prevent the wheel of a vehicle from sliding off the axletree.
Lagopous: Having a dense covering of long hair, like the foot of a hare.
Labiatifloral: Having labiate flowers, as the snapdragon.
Logic: The science or art of exact reasoning, or of pure and formal thought, or of the laws according to which the processes of pure thinking should be conducted; the science of the formation and application of general notions; the science of generalization, judgment, classification, reasoning, and systematic arrangement; the science of correct reasoning.
Luck: That which happens to a person; an event, good or ill, affecting one's interests or happiness, and which is deemed casual; a course or series of such events regarded as occurring by chance; chance; hap; fate; fortune; often, one's habitual or characteristic fortune; as, good, bad, ill, or hard luck.  Luck is often used by itself to mean good luck; as, luck is better than skill; a stroke of luck.
lithoglyphic: Of or pertaining to the art of cutting and engraving precious stones.
Lap-welded: Having edges or ends united by a lap weld; as, a lap-welded pipe.
Lewis: An iron dovetailed tenon, made in sections, which can be fitted into a dovetail mortise; -- used in hoisting large stones, etc.
Lending: The act of one who lends.
Luminiferous: Producing light; yielding light; transmitting light; as, the luminiferous ether.
Labially: In a labial manner; with, or by means of, the lips.
Lothario: A gay seducer of women; a libertine.
Lisbon: A sweet, light-colored species of wine, produced in the province of Estremadura, and so called as being shipped from Lisbon, in Portugal.
Loathing: Extreme disgust; a feeling of aversion, nausea, abhorrence, or detestation.
littleneck: a quahog when young and small; frequently eaten raw.
Lactucone: A white, crystalline, tasteless substance, found in the milky sap of species of Lactuca, and constituting an essential ingredient of lactucarium.
landing gear: The wheels and attached structures under an airplane that support it and allow it to move when on the ground; also, the floats or pontoons of an amphibious airplane together with their supporting structures.  Landing gear may be fixed rigidly in place, or retractable when in flight.
Loving cup: A large ornamental drinking vessel having two or more handles, intended to pass from hand to hand, as at a banquet.
Living: The state of one who, or that which, lives; lives; life; existence.
Leucophlegmacy: A dropsical habit of body, or the commencement of anasarca; paleness, with viscid juices and cold sweats.
Leafed: Having (such) a leaf or (so many) leaves; -- used in composition; as, broad-leafed; four-leafed.
Laxity: The state or quality of being lax; lack of tenseness, strictness, or exactness.
Liege: A free and independent person; specif., a lord paramount; a sovereign.
Listing: The act or process of one who lists (in any sense of the verb); as, the listing of a door; the listing of a stock at the Stock Exchange.
Lain: p. p. of Lie, v. i.
Latisternal: Having a broad breastbone, or sternum; -- said of anthropoid apes.
liberated: released from chemical combination, or as a consequence of chemical reaction; -- of a gas.
Lemaireocereus: A genus of tropical American cacti, usually tall and branching with stout spines and funnel-shaped flowers and globular or ovoid often edible fruit.
Lenger: Longer; longest; -- obsolete compar. and superl. of long.
Lineage: Descent in a line from a common progenitor; progeny; race; descending line of offspring or ascending line of parentage.
Lock-weir: A waste weir for a canal, discharging into a lock chamber.
Level: To be level; to be on a level with, or on an equality with, something; hence, to accord; to agree; to suit.
Larget: A short piece of bar iron for rolling into a sheet; a small billet.
Levee: To keep within a channel by means of levees; as, to levee a river.
Latterday: Belonging to present times or those recent by comparison.
Lever: A rigid piece which is capable of turning about one point, or axis (the fulcrum), and in which are two or more other points where forces are applied; -- used for transmitting and modifying force and motion. Specif., a bar of metal, wood, or other rigid substance, used to exert a pressure, or sustain a weight, at one point of its length, by receiving a force or power at a second, and turning at a third on a fixed point called a fulcrum. It is usually named as the first of the six mechanical powers, and is of three kinds, according as either the fulcrum F, the weight W, or the power P, respectively, is situated between the other two, as in the figures.
living will: A document signed by an individual expressing his/her desire that, in the event of an illness from which there is no reasonable expectation of recovery, aggressive or extraordinary measures to prolong life, such as resuscitation and life-support equipment, should not be used.
Lincolnian: of or pertaining to Abraham Lincoln.
Levet: A trumpet call for rousing soldiers; a reveille.
Likable: Such as can be liked; such as to attract liking; easy to like; evoking sympathy; as, a likable person.
Lactescent: Having a milky look; becoming milky.
leatherlike: resembling or made to resemble leather; tough but pliable; leathery.
&Verbar;Lumbricus: A genus of annelids, belonging to the Oligochæta, and including the common earthworms. See Earthworm.
lawfully-begotten: born in wedlock; legitimate; enjoying full filial rights; not illegitimate; -- of people.
Litocranius: A genus of East African antelopes including the gerenuks.
Libration point: any one of five points in the plane of a system of two large astronomical bodies orbiting each other, as the Earth-moon system, where the gravitational pull of the two bodies on an object are approximately equal, and in opposite directions.  A solid object moving in the same velocity and direction as such a libration point will remain in gravitational equilibrium with the two bodies of the system and not fall toward either body.
Linnaeus:
Carolus Linnaeus, also called Karl von Linné.  Born at Råshult, Småland, Sweden, May 13, 1707: died at Upsala, Sweden, Jan. 10, 1778.  A celebrated Swedish botanist and naturalist, founder of the Linnean system in botany.  He made a journey to Lapland in 1732; resided in the Netherlands 1735-38; and became professor of medicine (later of botany) at Upsala in 1741.  Among his works are “Systema naturæ” (1735), “Fundamenta botanica” (1736), “Genera plantarum” (1737), “Flora lapponica” (1737),
“Philosophia botanica” (1751), and “Species plantarum” (1753).
Liveryman: One who wears a livery, as a servant.
Leverage: The action of a lever; mechanical advantage gained by the lever.
Lory: Any one of many species of small parrots of the family Trichoglossidæ, generally having the tongue papillose at the tip, and the mandibles straighter and less toothed than in common parrots.  They are found in the East Indies, Australia, New Guinea, and the adjacent islands.  They feed mostly on soft fruits and on the honey of flowers.
Levant: To run away from one's debts; to decamp.
Lithotriptist: One skilled in breaking and extracting stone in the bladder.
Lithophane: Porcelain impressed with figures which are made distinct by transmitted light, as in a lamp shade or when hung in a window.
&Verbar;L\u00e6laps: A genus of huge, carnivorous, dinosaurian reptiles from the Cretaceous formation of the United States.  They had very large hind legs and tail, and are supposed to have been bipedal.  Some of the species were about eighteen feet high.
Lascar: A native sailor, employed in European vessels; also, a menial employed about arsenals, camps, camps, etc.; a camp follower.
Longhorn: A long-horned animal, as a cow, goat, or beetle. See Long-horned.
Leucophyll: A colorless substance isomeric with chlorophyll, contained in parts of plants capable of becoming green.
Luciferous: Giving light; affording light or means of discovery.
Leptodactylus: The type genus of the Leptodactylidae; in some classifications it is placed in the family Bufonidae.
Lophophore: A disk which surrounds the mouth and bears the tentacles of the Bryozoa. See Phylactolemata.
The abbreviation for limited, term appended to the name of a company that is organized to give its owners limited liability; also abbreviated Ltd.  It corresponds to Inc. in the United States.
Lenard rays: Rays emanating from the outer surface of a plate composed of any material permeable by cathode rays, as aluminium, which forms a portion of a wall of a vacuum tube, or which is mounted within the tube and exposed to radiation from the cathode. Lenard rays are similar in all their known properties to cathode rays. So called from the German physicist Philipp Lenard (b. 1862), who first described them.
&Verbar;Lemniscus: One of two oval bodies hanging from the interior walls of the body in the Acanthocephala.
&Verbar;Linn\u00e6a borealis: The twin flower which grows in cold northern climates.
Lacertiloid: Like or belonging to the Lacertilia.
Lively: In a brisk, active, or animated manner; briskly; vigorously.
Laroid: Like or belonging to the Gull family (Laridæ).
Leviticus: The third canonical book of the Old Testament, containing the laws and regulations relating to the priests and Levites among the Hebrews, or the body of the ceremonial law.
lithoglyptics: The art of cutting and engraving gems.
liaise: To form or maintain a liaison{3}.
Liquefaction: The act or operation of making or becoming liquid; especially, the conversion of a solid into a liquid by the sole agency of heat.
Libratory: Balancing; moving like a balance, as it tends to an equipoise or level.
larynx: The expanded upper end of the windpipe or trachea, connected with the hyoid bone or cartilage. It contains the vocal cords, which produce the voice by their vibrations, when they are stretched and a current of air passes between them.  The larynx is connected with the pharynx by an opening, the glottis, which, in mammals, is protected by a lidlike epiglottis.
Lumber: To move heavily, as if burdened.
Looby: An awkward, clumsy fellow; a lubber.
Lockage: Materials for locks in a canal, or the works forming a lock or locks.
Logothete: An accountant; under Constantine, an officer of the empire; a receiver of revenue; an administrator of a department.
Lamprey: An eel-like marsipobranch of the genus Petromyzon, and allied genera; called also lamprey eel and lamper eel.  The lampreys have a round, sucking mouth, without jaws, but set with numerous minute teeth, and one to three larger teeth on the palate (see Illust. of Cyclostomi). There are seven small branchial openings on each side.
Lima: The capital city of Peru, in South America.
Lymphatic: One of the lymphatic or absorbent vessels, which carry lymph and discharge it into the veins; lymph duct; lymphatic duct.
Lithocarp: Fossil fruit; a fruit petrified; a carpolite.
Leman: A sweetheart, of either sex; a gallant, or a mistress; -- usually in a bad sense.
&Verbar;Labarum: The standard adopted by the Emperor Constantine after his conversion to Christianity. It is described as a pike bearing a silk banner hanging from a crosspiece, and surmounted by a golden crown. It bore a monogram of the first two letters (ΧΡ) (which appear like the English letters X and P), of the name of Christ in its Greek form. Later, the name was given to various modifications of this standard.
Lozengy: Divided into lozenge-shaped compartments, as the field or a bearing, by lines drawn in the direction of the bend sinister.
Logy: Heavy or dull in respect to motion or thought; as, a logy horse; feeling logy.
Laura: A number of hermitages or cells in the same neighborhood occupied by anchorites who were under the same superior.
Libretto: A book containing the words of an opera or extended piece of music.
&Verbar;Lucuma: An American genus of sapotaceous trees bearing sweet and edible fruits.
leatherleaf: A stiff leathery-leaved fern (Polypodium scouleri) of Western North America having ovate fronds parted to the midrib.
Luciferian: One of the followers of Lucifer, bishop of Cagliari, in the fourth century, who separated from the orthodox churches because they would not go as far as he did in opposing the Arians.
less-traveled: not visited by many travelers; as, the tourist's desire to visit less-traveled countries.
&Verbar;Lepisma: A genus of wingless thysanurous insects having an elongated flattened body, covered with shining scales and terminated by seven unequal bristles. A common species (Lepisma saccharina) is found in houses, and often injures books and furniture; it feeds on starch and eats sized paper and starched clothes. Called also shiner, silverfish, silver witch, silver moth, and furniture bug.
leg-pulling: The act of attempting to make somebody believe something that is not true, done as a joke.
Liberalize: To make liberal; to free from narrow views or prejudices; to make less strict.
Lagenophera: A small genus of herbs of Australia and South America having small solidary white or purple flowers similar to true daisies of genus Bellis.
Locally: With respect to place; in place; as, to be locally separated or distant.
lawrencium: A transuranic element of atomic number 103.  It was discovered in 1961 by bombardment of californium in a cyclotron with boron nuclei.  Other isotopes were prepared in 1965 at Dubna.  The atomic weight of the most stable isotope is 256, having a half-life of 35 seconds.  Symbol Lr.
Leucophlegmatic: Having a dropsical habit of body, with a white bloated skin.
Lock stitch: A peculiar sort of stitch formed by the locking of two threads together, as in the work done by some sewing machines. See Stitch.
locoism: a disease of livestock caused by locoweed poisoning; characterized by weakness and lack of coordination and trembling and partial paralysis.
Laund: A plain sprinkled with trees or underbrush; a glade.
Lemnian: Of or pertaining to the isle of Lemnos.
Lyginopteris: A genus of fossil seed ferns of the Carboniferous.
Light-fingered: Dexterous in taking and conveying away; thievish; pilfering; addicted to petty thefts.
Luteous: Yellowish; more or less like buff.
Lawny: Made of lawn or fine linen.
Leucoethiopic: White and black; -- said of a white animal of a black species, or the albino of the negro race.
Lachrymiform: Having the form of a tear; tear-shaped.
Leatherback: A large sea turtle (Sphargis coriacea), having no bony shell on its back. It is common in the warm and temperate parts of the Atlantic, and sometimes weighs over a thousand pounds; -- called also leather turtle, leathery turtle, leather-backed tortoise, etc.
Langya: One of several species of East Indian and Asiatic fresh-water fishes of the genus Ophiocephalus, remarkable for their power of living out of water, and for their tenacity of life; -- called also walking fishes.
Leiopelmatidae: A natural family of primitive New Zealand frogs.
Lectionary: A book, or a list, of lections, for reading in divine service.
Lanthanum: A rare element of the rare earth group of the metals, of atomic number 57, allied to aluminum.  It occurs in certain rare minerals, as cerite, gadolinite, orthite, etc., and was so named from the difficulty of separating it from cerium, didymium, and other rare earth elements with which it is usually associated. Atomic weight 138.9. Symbol La.
Lixivial: Impregnated with, or consisting of, alkaline salts extracted from wood ashes; impregnated with a salt or salts like a lixivium.
light-skinned: having skin of a light colored hue.
low-ceilinged: having a lower than normal ceiling.
Lutra: A genus which in some classifications considered a genus of the subfamily Lutrinae.
Lacertian: Like a lizard; of or pertaining to the Lacertilia.
Lobcock: A dull, sluggish person; a lubber; a lob.
Lophobranch: Of or pertaining to the Lophobranchii.
Longbow: The ordinary bow, not mounted on a stock; -- so called in distinction from the crossbow when both were used as weapons of war.  Also, sometimes, such a bow of about the height of a man, as distinguished from a much shorter one.
Languorous: Producing, or tending to produce, languor; characterized by languor.
launcher: a device capable of launching a rocket.
legislating: the act of making or enacting laws; legislation{1}.
leopardbane: Any of several herbs of the genus Doronicum (as Doronicum acaule syn. Arnica acaulis) having alternate often clasping stem leaves cultivated for their long stalks of yellow flower heads.  See leopard's bane.
&Verbar;Lactucarium: The inspissated juice of the common lettuce, sometimes used as a substitute for opium.
Linotype: A kind of typesetting machine which produces castings, each of which corresponds to a line of separate types. By pressing the keys of a keyboard like one on a typewriter, the matrices for one line are properly arranged; the entire line, or stereotype, or slug, is then cast and planed, and the matrices are returned to their proper places, the whole process being automatic.
Luckily: In a lucky manner; by good fortune; fortunately; -- used in a good sense; as, they luckily escaped injury.
Leg-of-mutton: Having the general shape or outline of a leg of mutton; as, a leg-of-mutton, or shoulder-of-mutton, sail.
Lycanthropy: The supposed act of turning one's self or another person into a wolf.
Large-hearted: Having a large or generous heart or disposition; noble; liberal.
Lapwork: Work in which one part laps over another.
lyophilize: to freeze-dry; -- a technique used to dry serum, tissue, unstable chemicals and other sensitive materials.
&Verbar;Loggia: A roofed open gallery. It differs from a veranda in being more architectural, and in forming more decidedly a part of the main edifice to which it is attached; from a porch, in being intended not for entrance but for an out-of-door sitting-room.
Lodging: The act of one who, or that which, lodges.
Ligger: A baited line attached to a float, for night fishing. See Leger, a.
&Verbar;Lues: Disease, especially of a contagious kind.
Leaf-footed: Having leaflike expansions on the legs; -- said of certain insects; as, the leaf-footed bug (Leptoglossus phyllopus).
Lechanorales: A category used in some classification systems for all lichens that produce apothecia.
lemonwood: hard tough elastic wood of the lemonwood tree; used for making bows and fishing rods.
Lepidoganoid: Any one of a division (Lepidoganoidei) of ganoid fishes, including those that have scales forming a coat of mail. Also used adjectively.
Lurchline: The line by which a fowling net was pulled over so as to inclose the birds.
Lanthanotidae: A natural family of stout-bodied lizards.
leftist: a person who belongs to the political left.
Laminability: The quality or state of being laminable.
Laudation: The act of lauding; praise; high commendation.
Ladyfish: A large, handsome oceanic fish (Albula vulpes), found both in the Atlantic and Pacific oceans; -- called also bonefish, grubber, French mullet, and macabé.
Lappaceous: Resembling the capitulum of burdock; covered with forked points.
Lispingly: With a lisp; in a lisping manner.
Latinization: The act or process of Latinizing, as a word, language, or country.
Lynch law: The act or practice by private persons of inflicting punishment for crimes or offenses, without due process of law.
Lions foot: A composite plant of the genus Prenanthes, of which several species are found in the United States.
Logogriph: A sort of riddle in which it is required to discover a chosen word from various combinations of its letters, or of some of its letters, which form other words; -- thus, to discover the chosen word chatter form cat, hat, rat, hate, rate, etc.
Libidinosity: The state or quality of being libidinous; libidinousness.
Landlordism: The state of being a landlord; the characteristics of a landlord; specifically, in Great Britain, the relation of landlords to tenants, especially as regards leased agricultural lands.
loupe: Any of a variety of small magnifying glasses, having a magnifying power from 2X to 20X, commonly of 10X, which may be held in the hand, or in some cases held within the eyesocket without the use of a hand.  It is commonly used by jewelers and watchmakers.
Long-horned: Having a long horn or horns; as, a long-horned goat, or cow; having long antennæ, as certain beetles (Longicornia).
Lummox: A fat, ungainly, stupid person; an awkward bungler.
Lamella: a thin plate or scale of anything, as a thin scale growing from the petals of certain flowers; or one of the thin plates or scales of which certain shells are composed.
Lull: The power or quality of soothing; that which soothes; a lullaby.
Linn\u00e6an: Of or pertaining to Linnæus, the celebrated Swedish botanist.
&Verbar;Lithiasis: The formation of stony concretions or calculi in any part of the body, especially in the bladder and urinary passages.
Lopper: To turn sour and coagulate from too long standing, as milk.
Longspur: Any one of several species of fringilline birds of the genus Calcarius (or Plectrophanes), and allied genera.  The Lapland longspur (Calcarius Lapponicus), the chestnut-colored longspur (Calcarius ornatus), and other species, inhabit the United States.
Laureate: To honor with a wreath of laurel, as formerly was done in bestowing a degree at the English universities.
lookdown: A fish (Selene vomer) similar to the moonfish but with eyes high on the truncated forehead; it was also called moonfish at one time.
Landmark: A mark to designate the boundary of land; any mark or fixed object (as a marked tree, a stone, a ditch, or a heap of stones) by which the limits of a farm, a town, or other portion of territory may be known and preserved.
Lowboy: A chest of drawers not more than four feet high; -- applied commonly to the lower half of a tallboy from which the upper half has been removed.
Longspun: Spun out, or extended, to great length; hence, long-winded; tedious.
long-dated: of a gilt-edged security: having more than 15 years to run before redemption.
Leggy: having tall spindly stems; -- of plants.
Lycopod: A plant of the genus Lycopodium.
Lazy: Disinclined to action or exertion; averse to labor; idle; shirking work.
lcm: Abbreviation for the least common multiple, the smallest multiple that is exactly divisible by every member of a set of numbers; as, the least common multiple of 12 and 18 is 36.
Limber: To cause to become limber; to make flexible or pliant.
Liturgically: In the manner of a liturgy.
Laryngology: Systematized knowledge of the action and functions of the larynx; in pathology, the department which treats of the diseases of the larynx.
Lathing: The act or process of covering with laths.
Lactifuge: A medicine to check the secretion of milk, or to dispel a supposed accumulation of milk in any part of the body.
Laze: To waste in sloth; to spend, as time, in idleness; as, to laze away whole days.
liminal: of or pertaining to a limen, especially a sensory threshhold.
Lambkill: A small American ericaceous shrub (Kalmia angustifolia), resembling mountain laurel but having narrower leaves and small red flowers; -- called also calfkill, sheepkill, sheep laurel, etc. It is supposed to poison young sheep and other animals that eat it at times when the snow is deep and they cannot find other food.
Laxation: The act of loosening or slackening, or the state of being loosened or slackened.
Lavaret: A European whitefish (Coregonus laveretus), found in the mountain lakes of Sweden, Germany, and Switzerland.
&Verbar;Linga: The phallic symbol under which Siva is principally worshiped in his character of the creative and reproductive power.
Longulite: A kind of crystallite having a (slender) acicular form.
Lancer: One who lances; one who carries a lance; especially, a member of a mounted body of men armed with lances, attached to the cavalry service of some nations.
Linnet: Any one of several species of fringilline birds of the genera Linota, Acanthis, and allied genera, esp. the common European species (Linota cannabina), which, in full summer plumage, is chestnut brown above, with the breast more or less crimson. The feathers of its head are grayish brown, tipped with crimson. Called also gray linnet, red linnet, rose linnet, brown linnet, lintie, lintwhite, gorse thatcher, linnet finch, and greater redpoll. The American redpoll linnet (Acanthis linaria) often has the crown and throat rosy. See Redpoll, and Twite.
Lancet: A surgical knife-like instrument of various forms, commonly sharp-pointed and two-edged, used in venesection, and in opening abscesses, etc.
&Verbar;Literatus: A learned man; a man acquainted with literature; -- chiefly used in the plural.
Ladybird: Any one of numerous species of small beetles of the genus Coccinella and allied genera (family Coccinellidæ); -- called also ladybug, ladyclock, lady cow, lady fly, ladybeetle, and lady beetle.  Coccinella seplempunctata in one of the common European species. See Coccinella.
Lowry: An open box car used on railroads.  Compare Lorry.
Lithotripsy: The operation of crushing a stone in the bladder or urethra to reduce it to particles small enough to be voided; lithotrity.  It may be performed with an instrument called lithotriptor or lithotrite (also called a lithoclast); or, more recently, may be accomplished by devices using ultrasonic waves to fragment the stones.
Lignification: A change in the character of a cell wall, by which it becomes harder. It is supposed to be due to an incrustation of lignin.
Low-necked: Cut low in the neck; decollete; low-cut; -- said of a woman's dress.
Lampadist: One who gained the prize in the lampadrome.
Leghorn: A straw plaiting used for bonnets and hats, made from the straw of a particular kind of wheat, grown for the purpose in Tuscany, Italy; -- so called from Leghorn, the place of exportation.
Lym: A dog held in a leam; a bloodhound; a limehound.
Ligule: The thin and scarious projection from the upper end of the sheath of a leaf of grass.
Life-preserver: An apparatus, made in very various forms, and of various materials, for saving one from drowning by buoying up the body while in the water.
Loga\u0153dic: Composed of dactyls and trochees so arranged as to produce a movement like that of ordinary speech.
Leadsman: The man who heaves the lead.
Literally: According to the primary and natural import of words; not figuratively; as, a man and his wife can not be literally one flesh.
living wage: A wage or salary that permits a worker to live at least with minimal customary amenities, and above conditions of poverty.
lovesong: a song about love or expressing love for another person.
Logogram: A word letter; a phonogram, that, for the sake of brevity, represents a word; as, |, i. e., t, for it.  Cf. Grammalogue.
Lithologic: Of or pertaining to the character of a rock, as derived from the nature and mode of aggregation of its mineral contents.
lime light: An intense light produced by heating lime.  See Calcium light under Calcium.
libelluloid: Like or pertaining to the dragon flies.
Lunulite: Any bryozoan of the genus Lunulites, having a more or less circular form.
Lea: A meadow or sward land; a grassy field.
Life: The state of being which begins with generation, birth, or germination, and ends with death; also, the time during which this state continues; that state of an animal or plant in which all or any of its organs are capable of performing all or any of their functions; -- used of all animal and vegetable organisms.
Louis quatorze: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, the art or style of the times of Louis XIV. of France; as, Louis quatorze architecture.
lend-lease: the temporary transfer of goods and services to an ally to aid in a common cause; as, lend-lease during World War II was extremely generous.
Lee: Of or pertaining to the part or side opposite to that against which the wind blows; -- opposed to weather; as, the lee side or lee rail of a vessel.
Leg: To use as a leg, with it as object
Lenard tube: A tube for producing Lenard rays.
Looming: The indistinct and magnified appearance of objects seen in particular states of the atmosphere. See Mirage.
&Verbar;Latria: The highest kind of worship, or that paid to God; -- distinguished by the Roman Catholics from dulia, or the inferior worship paid to saints.
Leadhillite: A mineral of a yellowish or greenish white color, consisting of the sulphate and carbonate of lead; -- so called from having been first found at Leadhills, Scotland.
Land League: In Ireland, a combination of tenant farmers and other, organized, with Charles Stewart Parnell as president, in 1879 with a view to the reduction of farm rents and a reconstruction of the land laws.
Limpet: In a general sense, any hatshaped, or conical, gastropod shell.
Limpid: Characterized by clearness or transparency; clear; as, a limpid stream.
Labroid: Like the genus Labrus; belonging to the family Labridæ, an extensive family of marine fishes, often brilliantly colored, which are very abundant in the Indian and Pacific Oceans.  The tautog and cunner are American examples.
lefty: a person who uses the left hand with greater skill than the right; a left-handed person.
Lierne rib: In Gothic vaulting, any rib which does not spring from the impost and is not a ridge rib, but passes from one boss or intersection of the principal ribs to another.
&Verbar;Latibulum: A concealed hiding place; a burrow; a lair; a hole.
Leasehold: A tenure by lease; specifically, land held as personalty under a lease for years.
lights: The lungs of an animal or bird; -- sometimes coarsely applied to the lungs of a human being.
&Verbar;Leptothrix: Having the form of a little chain; -- applied to bacteria when, as in multiplication by fission, they form a chain of filiform individuals.
Lexicon: A vocabulary, or book containing an alphabetical arrangement of the words in a language or of a considerable number of them, with the definition of each; a dictionary; especially, a dictionary of the Greek, Hebrew, or Latin language.
&Verbar;Lacrimoso: Plaintive; -- a term applied to a mournful or pathetic movement or style.
Loco disease: A chronic nervous affection of cattle, horses, and sheep, caused by eating the loco weed and characterized by a slow, measured gait, high step, glassy eyes with defective vision, delirium, and gradual emaciation.
Lavender: An aromatic plant of the genus Lavandula (Lavandula vera), common in the south of Europe. It yields and oil used in medicine and perfumery. The Spike lavender (Lavandula Spica) yields a coarser oil (oil of spike), used in the arts.
Left-handed: Having the left hand or arm stronger and more dexterous than the right; using the left hand and arm with more dexterity than the right.
litterbin: a bin (usually in or outside a public building) into which the public can put rubbish.
liftoff: the initial ascent of a rocket from its launching pad.
Leontodon: A genus of liguliflorous composite plants, including the fall dandelion (Leontodon autumnale), and formerly the true dandelion; -- called also lion's tooth.
Laqueary: Using a noose, as a gladiator.
Langteraloo: An old game at cards. See Loo (a).
Ladrone: A robber; a pirate; hence, loosely, a rogue or rascal.
Locality: The state, or condition, of belonging to a definite place, or of being contained within definite limits.
Libration: The act or state of librating.
Lockram: A kind of linen cloth anciently used in England, originally imported from Brittany.
Limbate: Bordered, as when one color is surrounded by an edging of another.
Lupinine: An alkaloid found in several species of lupine (Lupinus luteus, Lupinus albus, etc.), and extracted as a bitter crystalline substance, having a formula C10H19NO.  Called also l-lupinine
Lippitude: Soreness of eyes; the state of being blear-eyed; blearedness.
Laminiferous: Having a structure consisting of laminæ, or thin layers.
Leonine: Pertaining to, or characteristic of, the lion; as, a leonine look; leonine rapacity.
Laminarian: Pertaining to seaweeds of the genus Laminaria, or to that zone of the sea (from two to ten fathoms in depth) where the seaweeds of this genus grow.
lead-in: a wire connecting an antenna to a receiver or a transmitter to a transmission line.
lanthanide: Any rare earth element of the lanthanide series (atomic numbers 57 through 71).
Labionasal: Formed by the lips and the nose.
launching: the act of moving a newly-built vessel into the water for the first time.
Laterifolious: Growing from the stem by the side of a leaf; as, a laterifolious flower.
Light-year: The distance over which light can travel in a year's time in a vacuum, 5.88 trillion miles (9.46 trillion kilometers); -- used as a unit in expressing stellar distances. It is more than 63,000 times as great as the distance from the earth to the sun.  The star nearest to the earth's sun is about 4 light years distant.
&Verbar;Limacina: A genus of small spiral pteropods, common in the Arctic and Antarctic seas. It contributes to the food of the right whales.
Literalize: To make literal; to interpret or put in practice according to the strict meaning of the words; -- opposed to spiritualize; as, to literalize Scripture.
Locution: Speech or discourse; a phrase; a form or mode of expression.
&Verbar;Lav\u0153sium: A supposed new metallic element, which was said to have been discovered in pyrites, and some other minerals, and to be of a silver-white color, and malleable.  It is not currently (1998) a recognized element.
Lecanomancy: Divination practiced with water in a basin, by throwing three stones into it, and invoking the demon whose aid was sought.
Londonize: To imitate the manner of the people of London.
Lordliness: The state or quality of being lordly.
Longipennine: Of or pertaining to the Longipennes; longipennate.
Left: That part of surrounding space toward which the left side of one's body is turned; as, the house is on the left when you face North.
Localization: Act of localizing, or state of being localized.
Lucernarian: Of or pertaining to the Lucernarida.
&Verbar;Levirostres: A group of birds, including the hornbills, kingfishers, and related forms.
Ludicrous: Adapted to excite laughter, without scorn or contempt; sportive.
lontar: A tall fan palm (Borassus flabellifer) of Africa and India and Malaysia yielding a hard wood and sweet sap that is a source of palm wine and sugar; the palmyra; -- its leaves are used for thatching and weaving.
Lobule: A small lobe; a subdivision of a lobe.
Latimeria: The type genus of the Latimeridae, including the coelacanth.
&Verbar;Laurus: A genus of trees including, according to modern authors, only the true laurel (Laurus nobilis), and the larger Laurus Canariensis of Madeira and the Canary Islands. Formerly the sassafras, the camphor tree, the cinnamon tree, and several other aromatic trees and shrubs, were also referred to the genus Laurus.
Lace-winged: Having thin, transparent, reticulated wings; as, the lace-winged flies.
Lock: To become fast, as by means of a lock or by interlacing; as, the door locks close.
&Verbar;Louchettes: Goggles intended to rectify strabismus by permitting vision only directly in front.
Livered: Having (such) a liver; used in composition; as, white-livered.
Lunda: A genus of birds including some of the puffins.
Linearly: In a linear manner; with lines.
long-distance: covering long distances; as, a long-distance runner; a long-distance telephone call.
Lobulate: Made up of, or divided into, lobules; as, a lobulated gland.
Lumpy: Full of lumps, or small compact masses; as, a lumpy bed; a lumpy batch of dough.
Lemonade: A beverage consisting of lemon juice mixed with water and sweetened.
lopsided victory: A victory in a contest in which one side defeats the other overwhelmingly; -- in sports, meaning one side scores much more than the other; in war, meaning one side has many more casualties than the other.
Lunular: Having a form like that of the new moon; shaped like a crescent; lunate.
Light-o-love: An old tune of a dance, the name of which made it a proverbial expression of levity, especially in love matters.
lomatia: any of various ornamental evergreens of the genus Lomatia having attractive fragrant flowers.
Lhasa: The capital city of Tibet; it is the sacred city of Lamaism.
limbic: of or pertaining to the limbic system; as, the limbic system.
Lymantriidae: The natural family comprising the tussock moths.
Long-sighted: Able to see objects at a great distance; hence, having great foresight; sagacious; farseeing.
Logomachy: Contention in words merely, or a contention about words; a war of words.
Ladies eardrops: The small-flowered Fuchsia (Fuchsia coccinea), and other closely related species.
Liberalizer: One who, or that which, liberalizes.
Leptodactylidae: A natural family of New World frogs; in some classifications it is essentially coextensive with the family Bufonidae.
&Verbar;Lepas: Any one of various species of Lepas, a genus of pedunculated barnacles found attached to floating timber, bottoms of ships, Gulf weed, etc.; -- called also goose barnacle. See Barnacle.
&Verbar;Laminaria: A genus of great seaweeds with long and broad fronds; kelp, or devil's apron. The fronds commonly grow in clusters, and are sometimes from thirty to fifty feet in length. See Illust. of Kelp.
Lamentation: The act of bewailing; audible expression of sorrow; wailing; moaning.
Lactam: One of a series of anhydrides of an amido type, analogous to the lactones, as oxindol; a cyclic amide.
low-grade: inferior; as, low-grade ore.  Opposite of high-grade.
Loanin: An open space between cultivated fields through which cattle are driven, and where the cows are sometimes milked; also, a lane.
Leucopyrite: A mineral of a color between white and steel-gray, with a metallic luster, and consisting chiefly of arsenic and iron.
&Verbar;Litterateur: One who occupies himself with literature; a literary man; a literatus.
Lyonia: A genus of evergreen or deciduous shrubs or small trees of the U. S. to the Antilles and eastern Asia to Himalaya.
Lunitidal: Pertaining to tidal movements dependent on the moon.
Loft: To raise aloft; to send into the air;
Lesquerella: A genus of low-growing hairy herbs, comprising some of the bladderpods.
load-shedding: The act or process of disconnecting the electric current on certain lines when the demand becomes greater than the supply.
lowdown: of the most contemptible kind; contemptible; mean; base; vile; -- of people or the actions of people; as, a lowdown sneak thief.
Lithely: In a lithe, pliant, or flexible manner.
log in: To establish communication with a host computer from a terminal or remote computer.
-logy: A combining form denoting a discourse, treatise, doctrine, theory, science; as, theology, geology, biology, mineralogy.
&Verbar;Lirella: A linear apothecium furrowed along the middle; the fruit of certain lichens.
lespedeza: Any shrubby or herbaceous plant of the genus Lespedeza, widely used for forage, soil improvement, and especially hay in the Southern U.S.
Leafless: Having no leaves or foliage; bearing no foliage.
lavaliere microphone: A small microphone worn around the neck on a supporting string or chain.
Lambertia: A small genus of Australian shrubs.
lactating: actively producing milk; -- of female mammals.
Lamarckian: Pertaining to, or involved in, the doctrines of Lamarckianism.
Liquidator: One who, or that which, liquidates.
Lycopode: Same as Lycopodium powder. See under Lycopodium.
Limpidity: The quality or state of being limpid.
Ler: the sea personified; father of Manannan; corresponds to the Welsh Llyr.
Lateran: The church and palace of St. John Lateran, the church being the cathedral church of Rome, and the highest in rank of all churches in the Catholic world.
landing strip: A runway at an airport, at which airplanes land{3}; the long smooth surface used for takeoff or landing{4}.
Leeangle: A heavy weapon of the Australian aborigines with a sharp-pointed end, about nine inches in length, projecting at right angles from the main part.
Lighting: A name sometimes applied to the process of annealing metals.
Leontocebus: A genus of marmosets including some of the tamarins.  Called also Leontopithecus and Leontideus.
Lyterian: Terminating a disease; indicating the end of a disease.
Langrage: A kind of shot formerly used at sea for tearing sails and rigging. It consisted of bolts, nails, and other pieces of iron fastened together or inclosed in a canister.
Lieutenant general: An army officer in rank next below a general and next above a major general.
Lauric: Pertaining to, or derived from, the European bay or laurel (Laurus nobilis).
Larvate: Masked; hence, concealed; obscure; -- applied in medicine to doubtful cases of some diseases; as, larvate pneumonis; larvate epilepsy.
Laurin: A white crystalline substance extracted from the fruit of the bay (Laurus nobilis), and consisting of a complex mixture of glycerin ethers of several organic acids.
lady-of-the-night: A West Indian shrub (Brunfelsia americana) with fragrant showy yellowish-white flowers.
Liquidation: The act or process of liquidating; the state of being liquidated.
Leningrad: A city in the European part of Soviet Russia; the former capital of Russia.  The name was formerly St. Petersburg and Petrograd, and was changed back to Saint Petersburg (Sankt Peterburg in Russian) in 1992.
Lacquering: The act or business of putting on lacquer; also, the coat of lacquer put on.
Liveliness: The quality or state of being lively or animated; sprightliness; vivacity; animation; spirit; as, the liveliness of youth, contrasted with the gravity of age.
Latinize: To use words or phrases borrowed from the Latin.
losings: something lost, especially money lost at gambling.  Inverse of winnings.
&Verbar;Lysis: The resolution or favorable termination of a disease, coming on gradually and not marked by abrupt change.
Logroll: To engage in logrolling; to accomplish by logrolling.
Liturgic: Pertaining to, of or the nature of, a liturgy; of or pertaining to public prayer and worship.
limen: a threshhold, especially the point where a psychological or physiological effect begins to occur.
Lock hospital: A hospital for the treatment of venereal diseases.
Ligan: Goods sunk in the sea, with a buoy attached in order that they may be found again. See Jetsam and Flotsam.
Leanness: The condition or quality of being lean.
&Verbar;Lepidodendron: A genus of fossil trees of the Devonian and Carboniferous ages, having the exterior marked with scars, mostly in quincunx order, produced by the separation of the leafstalks.
Label: To affix a label to; to mark with a name, etc.; as, to label a bottle or a package.
Longshore: Belonging to the seashore or a seaport; along and on the shore.
Latescence: A slight withdrawal from view or knowledge.
Ladin: A Romansch dialect spoken in some parts of Switzerland and the Tyrol.
Lumbosacral: Of or pertaining to the loins and sacrum; as, the lumbosacral nerve, a branch of one of the lumber nerves which passes over the sacrum.
Lucite: A brand name for a transparent plastic based on methyl methacrylate esters; the term is often used generically to refer to any similar transparent plastic.  It is sold in various forms, including rigid sheets which may be used as a substitute for glass in windows.
low-sudsing: causing little foam to form; -- used of e.g. detergents.  Contrasted with high-sudsing.
Lampic: Pertaining to, or produced by, a lamp; -- formerly said of a supposed acid.
Laryngoscopic: Of or pertaining to the inspection of the larynx; of or pertaining to the laryngoscope or laryngoscopy.
Lyrist: A musician who plays on the harp or lyre; a composer of lyrical poetry.
Landau: A four-wheeled covered vehicle, the top of which is divided into two sections which can be let down, or thrown back, in such a manner as to make an open carriage.
Landman: A man who lives or serves on land; -- opposed to seaman.
long-familiar: frequently seen or experienced; as, a long-familiar face.
Loper: One who, or that which, lopes; esp., a horse that lopes.
long-standing: existing since a time in the distant past; as, long-standing policies.
Lunule: Anything crescent-shaped; a crescent-shaped part or mark; a lunula; a lune.
lettercard: a postcard that folds so that the message is inside.
Luxation: The act of luxating, or the state of being luxated; a dislocation.
Libya: A country in Northern Africa, between Egypt and Tunisia, bordering the Mediterranean Sea.  It also borders on Algeria, Chad, Niger, and Sudan.  It is an Arabic-speaking country with over 97% of the population Sunni Moslem.  The population in 1995 was about 5,248,000.  The capital is Tripoli.
Latently: In a secret or concealed manner; invisibly.
Leitneriaceae: A natural family of trees coextensive with the genus Leitneria; commonly isolated in a distinct order.
Liechtenstein: a small principality in central Europe.
Liter: A measure of capacity in the metric system, being a cubic decimeter, equal to 61.022 cubic inches, or 2.113 American pints, or 1.76 English pints.
Laches: Neglect; negligence; remissness; neglect to do a thing at the proper time; especially, a delay in asserting a claim, sufficient to cause a person to lose the right to adjuducation of the claim by a court.
Lawgiver: One who makes or enacts a law or system of laws; a legislator.
Lithography: The art or process of putting designs or writing, with a greasy material, on stone, and of producing printed impressions therefrom. The process depends, in the main, upon the antipathy between grease and water, which prevents a printing ink containing oil from adhering to wetted parts of the stone not covered by the design. See Lithographic limestone, under Lithographic.
Lapillation: The state of being, or the act of making, stony.
Liberator: One who, or that which, liberates; a deliverer.
Lubrification: The act of lubricating, or making smooth.
Linarite: A hydrous sulphate of lead and copper occurring in bright blue monoclinic crystals.
Lotus: A name of several kinds of water lilies; as Nelumbium speciosum, used in religious ceremonies, anciently in Egypt, and to this day in Asia; Nelumbium luteum, the American lotus; and Nymphæa Lotus and Nymphæa cærulea, the respectively white-flowered and blue-flowered lotus of modern Egypt, which, with Nelumbium speciosum, are figured on its ancient monuments.
Locust tree: A large North American tree of the genus Robinia (Robinia Pseudacacia), producing large slender racemes of white, fragrant, papilionaceous flowers, and often cultivated as an ornamental tree. In England it is called acacia.
lunatic fringe: the members of a political or social group espousing extreme, fanatical, or seemingly irrational views.
&Verbar;Limax: A genus of airbreathing mollusks, including the common garden slugs. They have a small rudimentary shell. The breathing pore is on the right side of the neck. Several species are troublesome in gardens. See Slug.
Legacy: A gift of property by will, esp. of money or personal property; a bequest. Also Fig.; as, a legacy of dishonor or disease.
Loadstar: A star that leads; a guiding star; esp., the polestar, Polaris; also, the constellation containing the pole star, the cynosure (Ursa Minor).
Labefaction: The act of labefying or making weak; the state of being weakened; decay; ruin.
Limnodromus: A genus of shore birds including the dowitchers.
love-philter: a fabled drink credited with magical power; it can make the one who takes it love the one who gave it.
Lycopodite: An old name for a fossil club moss.
Lapstone: A stone for the lap, on which shoemakers beat leather.
Leymus: A genus that in some classifications overlaps the genus Elymus.
Leer: To entice with a leer, or leers; as, to leer a man to ruin.
Languaged: Having a language; skilled in language; -- chiefly used in composition.
Lunicurrent: Having relation to changes in currents that depend on the moon's phases.
loud-mouth: a person who causes trouble by speaking indiscretely.
&Verbar;Lepidosauria: A division of reptiles, including the serpents and lizards; the Plagiotremata.
Leek: A plant of the genus Allium (Allium Porrum), having broadly linear succulent leaves rising from a loose oblong cylindrical bulb. The flavor is stronger than that of the common onion.
Limbo: A West Indian dance contest, in which participants must dance under a pole which is lowered successively until only one participant can successfully pass under, without falling. It is  often performed at celebrations, such as weddings.
luthier: One who makes wooden stringed instruments, such as violins, guitars, etc.
Lardon: A bit of fat pork or bacon used in larding.
Lazzaroni: The homeless idlers of Naples who live by chance work or begging; -- so called from the Hospital of St. Lazarus, which serves as their refuge.
Lolium: A genus of plants including the darnel and ryegrass.
littermate: One of two or more animals born into the same litter.
Legibility: The quality of being legible; legibleness.
loafing: having no employment; being idle intentionally.
Lone-Star State: Texas; -- a nickname alluding to the single star on its coat of arms, being the device used on its flag and seal when it was a republic.
Leather: To beat, as with a thong of leather.
linesman: the official (in tennis or soccer) who watches the lines.
Litraneter: An instrument for ascertaining the specific gravity of liquids.
Lydine: A violet dye derived from aniline.
&Verbar;Lenvoi: One or more detached verses at the end of a literary composition, serving to convey the moral, or to address the poem to a particular person; -- orig. employed in old French poetry.
Lit: a form of the imp. & p. p. of Light.
lowercase: Pertaining to, or kept in, the lower case; -- used to denote the small letters, in distinction from capitals and small capitals; as, lowercase letters a and b and c etc.. Contrasted with uppercase.  See the Note under 1st Case, n., 3.
Lief: Gladly; willingly; freely; -- now used only in the phrases, had as lief, and would as lief; as, I had, or would, as lief go as not.
