&Verbar;Laissez faire: Noninterference; -- an axiom of some political economists, deprecating interference of government by attempts to foster or regulate commerce, manufactures, etc., by bounty or by restriction; as, the doctrine of laissez faire; the laissez faire system of government.
&Verbar;Lip\u00e6mia: A condition in which fat occurs in the blood.
Limousine liberal: a wealthy or well-to-do person of liberal political inclination.  It is sometimes used as a term of contempt for those espousing the cause of poor people, without having to endure the discomfort that their policies may inflict on others, such as the lower middle class.
Lien: A legal claim; a charge upon real or personal property for the satisfaction of some debt or duty; a right in one to control or hold and retain the property of another until some claim of the former is paid or satisfied.
Larboard: On or pertaining to the left-hand side of a vessel; port; as, the larboard quarter.
Lier: One who lies down; one who rests or remains, as in concealment.
Loin: That part of a human being or quadruped, which extends on either side of the spinal column between the hip bone and the false ribs. In human beings the loins are also called the reins. See Illust. of Beef.
Laotian: of or pertaining to Laos; as, the Laotian Prime Minister.
Lepadoid: A stalked barnacle of the genus Lepas, or family Lepadidæ; a goose barnacle. Also used adjectively.
Lieu: Place; room; stead; -- used only in the phrase in lieu of, that is, instead of.
Lewd: Not clerical; laic; laical; hence, unlearned; simple.
Lusern: A lynx. See 1st Lucern and Loup-cervier.
Lyrism: The act of playing on a lyre or harp.
Lipped: Having a lip or lips; having a raised or rounded edge resembling the lip; -- often used in composition; as, thick-lipped, thin-lipped, etc.
&Verbar;Lagomorpha: an order of rodent-like mammals, comprising the hares, rabbits, and pikas. They have four incisors in the upper jaw. Called also Duplicidentata.  They were formerly classified together with the rodents, but the Rodentia and Lagomorpha are now classed as separate orders.
Landwaiter: See Landing waiter, under Landing, a.
Lacrymal: See Lachrymatory, n., and Lachrymal, a.
loasa: any of various perennial South American plants of the genus Loasa having stinging hairs and showy white or yellow or reddish-orange flowers.
Leister: A spear armed with three or more prongs, for striking fish.
loony bin: An institution for the confinement or treatment of insane persons, such as an insane asylum or the psychiatric ward of a hospital.
Lean-to: A shed or slight building placed against the wall of a larger structure and having a single-pitched roof; -- called also penthouse, and to-fall.
Lexicographer: The author or compiler of a lexicon or dictionary.
Lernean: One of a family (Lernæidæ) of parasitic Crustacea found attached to fishes and other marine animals. Some species penetrate the skin and flesh with the elongated head, and feed on the viscera. See Illust. in Appendix.
lyophilized: dried by freezing and subsequent evaporation of the water in a high vacuum; -- used of tissue or blood or serum or other biological or sensitive substances.
Limpa: a type of rye bread, made using molasses or brown sugar.
Lightman: A man who carries or takes care of a light.
Lychnobite: One who labors at night and sleeps in the day.
Lacteally: Milkily; in the manner of milk.
Lycanthropist: One affected by the disease lycanthropy.
Larrikin: A rowdy street loafer; a rowdyish or noisy ill-bred fellow; a hoodlum; -- variously applied, as to a street blackguard, a street Arab, a youth given to horse-play, etc.
Lapidarian: Of or pertaining to stone; inscribed on stone; as, a lapidarian record.
lido: A recreational facility, especially one including a swimming pool for water sports.
License: To permit or authorize by license; to give license to; as, to license a man to preach.
Lotus-eater: One who ate the fruit or leaf of the lotus, and, as a consequence, gave himself up to indolence and daydreams; one of the Lotophagi.
latte: Same as cafe latte; a type of espresso coffee served with foamy steamed milk, and usually served in a tall glass or mug.
&Verbar;Lophobranchii: An order of teleostean fishes, having the gills arranged in tufts on the branchial arches, as the Hippocampus and pipefishes.
leprechaun: A small mischevous elf or spirit in Irish folklore; it is often depicted in literature as a dwarfish bearded old man; -- legend tells that if a leprechaun is captured, he will reveal the location of his hidden pot of gold.
Lode-ship: An old name for a pilot boat.
Languet: Anything resembling the tongue in form or office; specif., the slip of metal in an organ pipe which turns the current of air toward its mouth.
Lacteously: In a lacteous manner; after the manner of milk.
Lygodium: A genus of ferns with twining or climbing fronds, bearing stalked and variously-lobed divisions in pairs.
Latter-day saint: A Mormon; -- the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints being the name assumed by the whole body of Mormons.
Luff: To turn the head of a vessel toward the wind; to sail nearer the wind; to turn the tiller so as to make the vessel sail nearer the wind.
Lenni-Lenape: A general name for a group of Algonquin tribes which formerly occupied the coast region of North America from Connecticut to Virginia. They included the Mohicans, Delawares, Shawnees, and several other tribes.
legalese: A style of writing or speaking heavily emphasizing the abstruse technical vocabulary of the law, to the point where a speech or document may be incomprehensible to non-specialists.
Lithosphere: The solid earth as distinguished from its fluid envelopes, the hydrosphere and atmosphere.
lagoon: A shallow sound, channel, pond, or lake, especially one into which the sea flows; as, the lagoons of Venice.
&Verbar;Lacertilia: An order of Reptilia, which includes the lizards.
Lieutenancy: The office, rank, or commission, of a lieutenant.
Lithophyse: A spherulitic cavity often with concentric chambers, observed in some volcanic rocks, as in rhyolitic lavas. It is supposed to be produced by expanding gas, whence the name.
Lurk: To lie hidden; to lie in wait.
Leaven: To make light by the action of leaven; to cause to ferment.
Loud-voiced: Having a loud voice; speaking with a loud voice; noisy; clamorous.
Liparian: Any species of a family (Liparidæ) of destructive bombycid moths, as the tussock moths.
Levorotatory: Turning or rotating the plane of polarization of light towards the left; -- applied to crystals and compounds exhibiting optical activity, such as levulose, left-handed quartz crystals, etc.  Opposite of dextrorotatory.
LH: An abbreviation for luteinizing hormone, a gonadotropic hormone that is secreted by the pituitary and stimulates ovulation in female mammals, and stimulates androgen release in male mammals.
light-duty: not designed for heavy or demanding work; as, a light-duty detergent.  Opposite of heavy-duty.
Lithodome: Any one of several species of bivalves, which form holes in limestone, in which they live; esp., any species of the genus Lithodomus.
Lambative: A medicine taken by licking with the tongue; a lincture.
Lecturer: One who lectures; an assistant preacher.
Larva: Any young insect from the time that it hatches from the egg until it becomes a pupa, or chrysalis. During this time it usually molts several times, and may change its form or color each time.  The larvæ of many insects are much like the adults in form and habits, but have no trace of wings, the rudimentary wings appearing only in the pupa stage.  In other groups of insects the larvæ are totally unlike the parents in structure and habits, and are called caterpillars, grubs, maggots, etc.
Landing: A going or bringing on shore.
Lateritic: Consisting of, containing, or characterized by, laterite; as, lateritic formations.
Laxative: Having a tendency to loosen or relax.
Low-spirited: Deficient in animation and courage; dejected; depressed; dispirited; not sprightly.
Leucoxene: A nearly opaque white mineral, in part identical with titanite, observed in some igneous rocks as the result of the alteration of titanic iron.
Latigo halter: A kind of halter usually made of raw hide.
lancers: A set of quadrilles for 8 or 16 couples.
Lorel: A good for nothing fellow; a vagabond.
&Verbar;Leggiadro: Light or graceful; in a light, delicate, and brisk style.
Lazulite: A mineral of a light indigo-blue color, occurring in small masses, or in monoclinic crystals; blue spar. It is a hydrous phosphate of alumina and magnesia.
Limbous: With slightly overlapping borders; -- said of a suture.
Lampoonry: The act of lampooning; a lampoon, or lampoons.
Lycopodium: A genus of mosslike plants, the type of the order Lycopodiaceæ; club moss.
Labadist: A follower of Jean de Labadie, a religious teacher of the 17th century, who left the Roman Catholic Church and taught a kind of mysticism, and the obligation of community of property among Christians.
Lobulette: A little lobule, or subdivision of a lobule.
Leuconic: Pertaining to, or designating, a complex organic acid, obtained as a yellowish white gum by the oxidation of croconic acid.
Lobscouse: A combination of meat with vegetables, bread, etc., usually stewed, sometimes baked; an olio.
&Verbar;Leucocyth\u00e6mia: A disease in which the white corpuscles of the blood are largely increased in number, and there is enlargement of the spleen, or the lymphatic glands; leuchæmia.
Languishing: Becoming languid and weak; pining; losing health and strength.
Listless: Having no desire or inclination; indifferent; heedless; spiritless.
low-lying: having a small elevation above the ground or horizon or sea level; as, low-lying clouds.
Lapboard: A board used on the lap as a substitute for a table, as by tailors.
Lycosidae: The natural family of arachnids including the wolf spiders.
Louis dor: Formerly, a gold coin of France nominally worth twenty shillings sterling, but of varying value; -- first struck in 1640.
liberating: giving freedom from restriction or restraint.
Lavatera: A widespread genus of herbs or soft-wooded arborescent shrubs cultivated for their showy flowers.
Lansquenet: A German foot soldier in foreign service in the 15th and 16th centuries; a soldier of fortune; -- a term used in France and Western Europe.
Loasaceae: A natural family of bristly hairy sometimes climbing plants; America and Africa and Southern Arabia.
&Verbar;Labyrinthici: An order of teleostean fishes, including the Anabas, or climbing perch, and other allied fishes.
looseleaf binder: A type of notebook with hard covers attached to metal rings which open, allowing sheets of writing paper to be conveniently inserted into it and removed from it.
Lux: To put out of joint; to luxate.
Lipotyphla: A suborder of mammals including the moles; hedgehogs; and true shrews.
Luz: A bone of the human body which was supposed by certain Rabbinical writers to be indestructible. Its location was a matter of dispute.
Lotto: A game of chance, played with cards or tickets, on which are inscribed numbers, and any contrivance (as a wheel containing numbered balls) for determining a set of numbers by chance.  The player holding a card having on it the set of numbers drawn from the wheel takes the stakes after a certain percentage of them has been deducted for the dealer.  In some systems, lesser prizes are awarded for having some but not all of the numbers selected, such as four or five numbers in a six-number drawing.  A variety of lotto is called keno.  In another variety, the player chooses the numbers for the card or ticket s/he holds.  There may be from three to seven different numbers on a card or ticket.  In a modern computerized lotto system conducted by state authorities, the player chooses numbers, or allows the computer to choose numbers at random, which are then printed on a ticket that the player holds until the winning number is selected.
Logotype: A single type, containing two or more letters; as, æ, Æ, ﬁ, ﬂ, ﬄ, etc.; -- called also ligature.
Legal: Created by, permitted by, in conformity with, or relating to, law; as, a legal obligation; a legal standard or test; a legal procedure; a legal claim; a legal trade; anything is legal which the laws do not forbid.
Lithotomic: Pertaining to, or performed by, lithotomy.
Loreto nuns: Members of a congregation of nuns founded by Mrs. Mary Teresa Ball, near Dublin, Ireland, in 1822, and now spread over Ireland, India, Canada, and the United States.  The nuns are called also Ladies of Loreto.  They are engaged in teaching girls.
&Verbar;Lingerie: Linen goods collectively; linen underwear or nightclothes, esp. of women; the clothing of linen and cotton with its lace, etc., worn by a women.
Learned: Of or pertaining to learning; possessing, or characterized by, learning, esp. scholastic learning; erudite; well-informed; as, a learned scholar, writer, or lawyer; a learned book; a learned theory.
Lactobutyrometer: An instrument for determining the amount of butter fat contained in a given sample of milk.
Loophole: A small opening, as in the walls of fortification, or in the bulkhead of a ship, through which small arms or other weapons may be discharged at an enemy.
Lethargic: Pertaining to, affected with, or resembling, lethargy; morbidly drowsy; dull; heavy.
lymantriid: A dull-colored moth whose larvae have tufts of hair on the body and feed on the leaves of many deciduous trees.
Ligeance: The connection between sovereign and subject by which they were mutually bound, the former to protection and the securing of justice, the latter to faithful service; allegiance.
&Verbar;Lienculus: One of the small nodules sometimes found in the neighborhood of the spleen; an accessory or supplementary spleen.
Longipalp: One of a tribe of beetles, having long maxillary palpi.
Leopard: A large, savage, carnivorous mammal (Felis leopardus). It is of a yellow or fawn color, with rings or roselike clusters of black spots along the back and sides. It is found in Southern Asia and Africa. By some the panther (Felis pardus) is regarded as a variety of leopard.
&Verbar;Langue do\u00efl: The dialect formerly spoken north of the Loire (in which the word for “yes” was oïl, F. oui).
Limning: The act, process, or art of one who limns; the picture or decoration so produced.
lowball: to give a deceptively low estimate of the price of (merchandise or services); -- a sales tactic to induce a person to buy.
Lousily: In a lousy manner; in a mean, paltry manner; scurvily.
low-warp loom: a hand loom in which the warp is carried horizontally; for weaving tapestry.
Lepomis: A genus of freshwater sunfishes, inclding some of the breams.
Little: In a small quantity or degree; not much; slightly; somewhat; -- often with a preceding it.
Linkage: The act of linking; the state of being linked; also, a system of links.
Lyonnaise: Applied to boiled potatoes cut into small pieces and heated in oil or butter.  They are usually flavored with onion and parsley.
Light-armed: Armed with light weapons or accouterments.
loamless: having no loam; -- of soil; as, a stony loamless yard.  Contrasted with loamy.
Lady-killer: A gallant who captivates the hearts of women.
Linoleic: Pertaining to, or derived from, linoleum, or linseed oil; specifically (Chem.), designating an organic acid, a thin yellow oil, found combined as a salt of glycerin in oils of linseed, poppy, hemp, and certain nuts.
Levitical: Of or pertaining to a Levite or the Levites.
Lister: A double-moldboard plow which throws a deep furrow, and at the same time plants and covers grain in the bottom of the furrow.
Laud: To praise in words alone, or with words and singing; to celebrate; to extol.
Lactarene: A preparation of casein from milk, used in printing calico.
Leucoscope: An instrument, devised by Professor Helmholtz, for testing the color perception of the eye, or for comparing different lights, as to their constituent colors or their relative whiteness.
Loire: a French river which flows into the North Atlantic.
Lipogram: A writing composed of words not having a certain letter or letters; -- as in the Odyssey of Tryphiodorus there was no A in the first book, no B in the second, and so on.
Linguadental: An articulation pronounced by the aid or use of the tongue and teeth.
Levitically: After the manner of the Levites; in accordance with the levitical law.
Lixt: 2d pers. sing. pres. of Lige, to lie, to tell lies, -- contracted for ligest.
Leadwort: A genus of maritime herbs (Plumbago).  Plumbago Europæa has lead-colored spots on the leaves, and nearly lead-colored flowers.
Lopeared: Having ears which droop or hang down; as, a lop-eared hound.
Lactage: The produce of animals yielding milk; milk and that which is made from it.
&Verbar;Leucadendron: A genus of evergreen shrubs from the Cape of Good Hope, having handsome foliage. Leucadendron argenteum is the silverboom of the colonists.
Lucubrator: One who studies by night; also, one who produces lucubrations.
Liking: The state of being pleasing; a suiting. See On liking, below.
Lyencephalous: Pertaining to, or characteristic of, the Lyencephala.
Lobeliaceous: Of or pertaining to a natural order of plants of which the genus Lobelia is the type.
Lathereeve: Formerly, the head officer of a lathe. See 1st Lathe.
lowerclassman: an undergraduate who is not yet a senior.
liminality: that temporary state during a rite of passage when the participant lacks social status or rank, is required to follow specified forms of conduct, and is expected to show obedience and humility.
Lately: Not long ago; recently; as, he has lately arrived from Italy.
Legific: Of or pertaining to making laws.
Linkboy: A boy or man that carried a link or torch to light passengers.
&Verbar;Lapilli: Volcanic ashes, consisting of small, angular, stony fragments or particles.
Lay reader: A layman authorized to read parts of the public service of the church.
Lieno-intestinal: Of or pertaining to the spleen and intestine; as, the lieno-intestinal vein of the frog.
Leatheret: A material made in imitation of leather, made of paper and cloth.
Lancinate: To tear; to lacerate; to pierce or stab.
Ladino: The mixed Spanish and Hebrew language spoken by Sephardim.
&Verbar;Lychnis: A genus of Old World plants belonging to the Pink family (Caryophyllaceæ).  Most of the species have brilliantly colored flowers and cottony leaves, which may have anciently served as wicks for lamps.  The botanical name is in common use for the garden species.  The corn cockle (Lychnis Githago) is a common weed in wheat fields.
Lieutenant: An officer who supplies the place of a superior in his absence; a representative of, or substitute for, another in the performance of any duty.
Liripoop: A pendent part of the old clerical tippet; afterwards, a tippet; a scarf; -- worn also by doctors, learned men, etc.
Log-ship: A part of the log. See Log-chip, and 2d Log, n., 2.
Lichenic: Of, pertaining to, or obtained from, lichens.
Lung-grown: Having lungs that adhere to the pleura.
Lamblike: Like a lamb; gentle; meek; inoffensive.
Lepidine: An organic base, C9H6.N.CH3, metameric with quinaldine, and obtained by the distillation of cinchonine.
lights-out: a signal to turn the lights out.
Lichenology: The science which treats of lichens.
Lignitic: Containing lignite; resembling, or of the nature of, lignite; as, lignitic clay.
Liquation: The act or operation of making or becoming liquid; also, the capacity of becoming liquid.
Lysiloma: A small genus of tropical American trees and shrubs with pinnate leaves and flat straight pods.
Laster: A workman whose business it is to shape boots or shoes, or place leather smoothly, on lasts; a tool for stretching leather on a last.
Lugubrious: Mournful; indicating sorrow, often ridiculously or feignedly; doleful; woful; pitiable; as, a whining tone and a lugubrious look.
Love: To have the feeling of love; to be in love.
LISP: a high-level computer programming language in which statements and data are in the form of lists, enclosed in parentheses; -- used especially for rapid development of prototype programs in artificial intelligence applications .
Lepidolite: A species of mica, of a lilac or rose-violet color, containing lithia. It usually occurs in masses consisting of small scales. See Mica.
Ladys hair: A plant of the genus Briza (Briza media); a variety of quaking grass.
Lycophyta: A term used in some classifications for the class Lycopsida: club mosses.
Lawful: Conformable to law; allowed by law; legitimate; competent.
Labyrinthine: Pertaining to, or like, a labyrinth; labyrinthal; labyrinthian.
Litigant: A person engaged in a lawsuit.
Levesel: A leafy shelter; a place covered with foliage.
Litigation: The act or process of litigating; a suit at law; a judicial contest.
lullaby: A song to quiet babes or lull them to sleep; that which quiets.
&Verbar;Lentigo: A freckly eruption on the skin; freckles.
lingcod: The flesh of a lean-fleshed fish  caught off the U.S. Pacific coast.
Lethe: A river of Hades whose waters when drunk caused forgetfulness of the past.
ladder-proof: resistant to runs or (in Britain) ladders; -- of hosiery.
&Verbar;Liedertafel: A popular name for any society or club which meets for the practice of male part songs.
Luteo-: A combining form signifying orange yellow or brownish yellow.
lithographer: One who lithographs; one who practices lithography.
&Verbar;Lamellicornia: A group of lamellicorn, plant-eating beetles; -- called also Lamellicornes.
Leucoplast: One of certain very minute whitish or colorless granules occurring in the protoplasm of plants and supposed to be the nuclei around which starch granules will form.
Lapel: That part of a garment which is turned back; specifically, the lap, or fold, of the front of a coat in continuation of collar.
Larix: The genus of trees comrising the larches.
Lodger: One who, or that which, lodges; one who occupies a hired room in another's house.
Levulin: A substance resembling dextrin, obtained from the bulbs of the dahlia, the artichoke, and other sources, as a colorless, spongy, amorphous material. It is so called because by decomposition it yields levulose.
Legitimate: To make legitimate, lawful, or valid; esp., to put in the position or state of a legitimate person before the law, by legal means; as, to legitimate a bastard child.
Laboredly: In a labored manner; with labor.
Lydian: Of or pertaining to Lydia, a country of Asia Minor, or to its inhabitants; hence, soft; effeminate; -- said especially of one of the ancient Greek modes or keys, the music in which was of a soft, pathetic, or voluptuous character.
Laryngophony: The sound of the voice as heard through a stethoscope when the latter is placed upon the larynx.
Lodged: Lying down; -- used of beasts of the chase, as couchant is of beasts of prey.
Legislature: The body of persons in a state or kingdom invested with power to make and repeal laws; a legislative body.
Lowly: In a low manner; humbly; meekly; modestly.
Luxembourgian: of or pertaining to Luxembourg (definition 2); as, Luxembourgian food.
&Verbar;Lametta: Foil or wire made of gold, silver, or brass.
Lecanoric: Pertaining to, or designating, an organic acid which is obtained from several varieties of lichen (Lecanora, Roccella, etc.), as a white, crystalline substance, and is called also orsellic acid, diorsellinic acid, lecanorin, etc.
Larceny: The unlawful taking and carrying away of things personal with intent to deprive the right owner of the same; theft.  Cf. Embezzlement.
Laager: To form into, or camp in, a laager, or protected camp.
Levelness: The state or quality of being level.
Litigate: To carry on a suit by judicial process.
&Verbar;Limosis: A ravenous appetite caused by disease; excessive and morbid hunger.
Letterpress: Print; letters and words impressed on paper or other material by types; -- often used of the reading matter in distinction from the illustrations.
Lopseed: A perennial herb (Phryma Leptostachya), having slender seedlike fruits.
Lifeblood: The blood necessary to life; vital blood.
Loafer: One who loafs; a lazy lounger.
landlady: A woman having real estate which she leases to a tenant or tenants.
Laterad: Toward the side; away from the mesial plane; -- opposed to mesiad.
Lukewarm: Moderately warm; neither cold nor hot; tepid.
Lateral: Of or pertaining to the sides; as, the lateral walls of a house; the lateral branches of a tree.
Lobbish: Like a lob; consisting of lobs.
Luvaridae: A natural family including the louvars.
lxxx: the Roman numeral representation of eighty; eight times ten; -- a determinate quantifier.
Litchi: The fruit of a tree native to China (Nephelium Litchi). It is nutlike, having a rough but tender shell, containing an aromatic pulp, and a single large seed. In the dried fruit which is exported the pulp somewhat resembles a raisin in color and form.
Logod\u00e6daly: Verbal legerdemain; a playing with words.
Lithophosphoric: Pertaining to lithophosphor; becoming phosphoric by heat.
&Verbar;Lymphadenitis: Inflammation of the lymphatic glands; -- called also lymphitis.
Lisle: A city of France celebrated for certain manufactures.
Leadership: The office, position or function of a leader; as, Gingrich held the House leadership for six years.
Langate: A linen roller used in dressing wounds.
Lacrosse: A game of ball, originating among the North American Indians, now the popular field sport of Canada, and played also in England and the United States.  Each player carries a long-handled racket, called a “crosse”.  The ball is not handled but caught with the crosse and carried on it, or tossed from it, the object being to carry it or throw it through one of the goals placed at opposite ends of the field.
Loculament: The cell of a pericarp in which the seed is lodged.
Liquid air: A transparent limpid liquid, slightly blue in color, consisting of a mixture of liquefied oxygen and nitrogen. It is prepared by subjecting air to great pressure and then cooling it by its own expansion to a temperature below the boiling point of its constituents  (N: -194° C; O: -183° C.).
Lapdog: A small dog which is or can be fondled in the lap.
Large: A musical note, formerly in use, equal to two longs, four breves, or eight semibreves.
Lactimide: A white, crystalline substance obtained as an anhydride of alanine, and regarded as an imido derivative of lactic acid.
Leiopelma: The type and sole genus of the family Leiopelmatidae.
Leptoptilus: A genus of birds including the adjutant bird (Leptoptilus dubius, also called adjutant stork) and marabous.
Libethenite: A mineral of an olive-green color, commonly in orthorhombic crystals. It is a hydrous phosphate of copper.
Leonotis: A small genus of tropical herbs and subshrubs of S Africa.
Lacerable: That can be lacerated or torn.
Leaved: Bearing, or having, a leaf or leaves; having folds; -- used in combination; as, a four-leaved clover; a two-leaved gate; long-leaved.
Lantern: To furnish with a lantern; as, to lantern a lighthouse.
Livering: A kind of pudding or sausage made of liver or pork.
Laird: A lord; a landholder, esp. one who holds land directly of the crown.
Labiodental: Formed or pronounced by the cooperation of the lips and teeth, as f and v.
Lessor: One who leases; the person who lets to farm, or gives a lease.
leather: Of, pertaining to or made of leather; consisting of leather; as, a black leather jacket.
Lock step: A mode of marching by a body of men going one after another as closely as possible, in which the leg of each moves at the same time with the corresponding leg of the person before him.
Lactoscope: An instrument for estimating the amount of cream contained in milk by ascertaining its relative opacity.
looked-for: same as anticipated, 2; as, his looked-for advancement.
Lobster: Any large macrurous crustacean used as food, esp. those of the genus Homarus; as the American lobster (Homarus Americanus), and the European lobster (Homarus vulgaris). The Norwegian lobster (Nephrops Norvegicus) is similar in form.  All these have a pair of large unequal claws.  The spiny lobsters of more southern waters, belonging to Palinurus, Panulirus, and allied genera, have no large claws. The fresh-water crayfishes are sometimes called lobsters.
Loam: To cover, smear, or fill with loam.
&Verbar;Legato: Connected; tied; -- a term used when successive tones are to be produced in a closely connected, smoothly gliding manner. It is often indicated by a tie, thus &unr_;, &unr_;, or &unr_;, &unr_;, written over or under the notes to be so performed; -- opposed to staccato.
liveable: Same as livable; as, liveable conditions.  Opposite of unlivable.
Lanceolate: Rather narrow, tapering to a point at the apex, and sometimes at the base also; as, a lanceolate leaf.
ladder company: Same as hook-and-ladder company, hook-and-ladder truck.
Lichenin: A substance isomeric with starch, extracted from several species of moss and lichen, esp. from Iceland moss.
Lilial: Having a general resemblance to lilies or to liliaceous plants.
left brain: The left cerebral hemisphere of the brain; in humans, it controls motor activity on the right side of the body, and in most people is the primary location for control of language, logic, and mathematical thought.
&Verbar;Lyencephala: A group of Mammalia, including the marsupials and monotremes; -- so called because the corpus callosum is rudimentary.
Lurch: To withdraw to one side, or to a private place; to lurk.
Lavandula: A genus of plants of the mint family including the lavender{1}.
Location: The act or process of locating.
Labyrinthian: Intricately winding; like a labyrinth; perplexed; labyrinthal.
Lords and Ladies: The European wake-robin (Arum maculatum), -- those with purplish spadix the lords, and those with pale spadix the ladies.
left-brained: Exhibiting intellectual or personality characteristics suggesting dominance of linguistic or logical modes of thought, which are usually controlled by the left cerebral hemisphere; as, left-brained pedants unable to appreciate music; also referred to as linear.  See linear{3}.  Contrasted with right-brained.
lexical: Of or pertaining to a lexicon, to lexicography, or words; according or conforming to a lexicon.
Lancastrian: A member (or supporter) of the house of Lancaster.
LDL: Low-density lipoprotein, a lipoprotein that transports cholesterol in the blood; high levels are thought to be associated with increased risk of coronary heart disease and atherosclerosis; sometimes called informally bad cholesterol.
lyricality: the property of being suitable for singing.
loose-fitting: large enough to leave space for movement over the skin; not tight-fitting; -- of clothing.  Opposite of close-fitting, tight, and tight-fitting.
&Verbar;Lactuca: A genus of composite herbs, several of which are cultivated for salad; lettuce.
Leaper: A kind of hooked instrument for untwisting old cordage.
living room: A room in a house used by all or most of the family, where the family entertain guests or relax together for leisure activities.  It usually contains at least one couch, and does not contain a dining table.
longanberry: A tree (Dimocarpus longan) of Southeastern Asia to Australia grown primarily for its sweet translucent-fleshed edible fruit (the longan) resembling litchi nuts; -- it is sometimes placed in genera Euphoria or Nephelium.
Lustihood: State of being lusty; vigor of body.
Litholatry: The worship of a stone or stones.
Landlord: The lord of a manor, or of land; the owner of land or houses which he leases to a tenant or tenants.
Longanimity: Disposition to bear injuries patiently; forbearance; patience.
Laver: The fronds of certain marine algæ used as food, and for making a sauce called laver sauce.  Green laver is the Ulva latissima; purple laver, Porphyra laciniata and Porphyra vulgaris. It is prepared by stewing, either alone or with other vegetables, and with various condiments; -- called also sloke, or sloakan.
Lincoln green: A color of cloth formerly made in Lincoln, England; the cloth itself.
&Verbar;Legator: A testator; one who bequeaths a legacy.
Lexicology: The science of the derivation and signification of words; that branch of learning which treats of the signification and application of words.
L\u00e6tere Sunday: The fourth Sunday of Lent; -- so named from the Latin word Lætare (rejoice), the first word in the antiphone of the introit sung that day in the Roman Catholic service.
Lymphoid: Resembling lymph; also, resembling a lymphatic gland; adenoid; as, lymphoid tissue.
lacrimatory: relating to or inducing tears; -- especially of chemical substances; same as lachrymatory.
Leucous: White; -- applied to albinos, from the whiteness of their skin and hair.
Limenean: Of or pertaining to Lima, or to the inhabitants of Lima, in Peru.
Lordolatry: Worship of, or reverence for, a lord as such.
Lap-jointed: Having a lap joint, or lap joints, as many kinds of woodwork and metal work.
life-sustaining: being the seat or source of life; performing a necessary function in the living body; as, the need for life-sustaining air and water.
Laudanine: A white organic base, resembling morphine, and obtained from certain varieties of opium.
Laboratory: The workroom of a chemist; also, a place devoted to experiments in any branch of natural science; as, a chemical, physical, or biological laboratory. Hence, by extension, a place where something is prepared, or some operation is performed; as, the liver is the laboratory of the bile.
Lucidness: The quality of being lucid; lucidity.
&Verbar;Litotes: A diminution or softening of statement for the sake of avoiding censure or increasing the effect by contrast with the moderation shown in the form of expression; a form of understatement; as, “ a citizen of no mean city,” that is, of an illustrious city; or, “not bad”, meaning “good”.
Lepidomelane: An iron-potash mica, of a raven-black color, usually found in granitic rocks in small six-sided tables, or as an aggregation of minute opaque scales. See Mica.
Leaden: Made of lead; of the nature of lead; as, a leaden ball.
&Verbar;Lev\u00e9e en masse: See Levy in mass, under Levy, n.
Luxembourger: a native or inhabitant of Luxembourg.
Limberness: The quality or state of being limber; flexibleness.
Leaded: Fitted with lead; set in lead; as, leaded windows.
Landholder: A holder, owner, or proprietor of land.
Lariat: To secure with a lariat fastened to a stake, as a horse or mule for grazing; also, to lasso or catch with a lariat.
Lode: A water course or way; a reach of water.
Lethality: The quality of being lethal; mortality.
Lucimeter: an instrument for measuring the intensity of light; a photometer.
Leader: One who, or that which, leads or conducts; a guide; a conductor.
Lamnidae: A natural family of oceanic sharks.
Liliopsida: A class comprising seed plants that produce an embryo with a single cotyledon and parallel-veined leaves.  It includes the grasses; lilies; palms; and orchids.  It is divided into four subclasses or superorders: Alismatidae; Arecidae; Commelinidae; and Liliidae.
Listerism: The systematic use of antiseptics in the performance of operations and the treatment of wounds; -- so called from Joseph Lister, an English surgeon.
low-pitched: low in pitch or frequency; -- used of sounds and voices.  Opposite of high-pitched.
Ladder: A frame usually portable, of wood, metal, or rope, for ascent and descent, consisting of two side pieces to which are fastened cross strips or rounds forming steps.
Lycine: A weak base identical with betaine; -- so called because found in the boxthorn (Lycium barbarum). See Betaine.
Lancepesade: An assistant to a corporal; a private performing the duties of a corporal; -- called also lance corporal.
Lunistice: The farthest point of the moon's northing and southing, in its monthly revolution.
Lenify: To assuage; to soften; to mitigate; to alleviate.
Loreal: Of or pertaining to the lore; -- said of certain feathers of birds, scales of reptiles, etc.
Lawn: A very fine linen (or sometimes cotton) fabric with a rather open texture. Lawn is used for the sleeves of a bishop's official dress in the English Church, and, figuratively, stands for the office itself.
life-giving: Giving life or spirit; having power to give life; inspiriting; invigorating; as, life-giving love and praise.
Loellingite: A tin-white arsenide of iron, isomorphous with arsenopyrite.
Lawe: To cut off the claws and balls of, as of a dog's fore feet.
layperson: someone who is not a clergyman or a professional person; a layman.
Laboring: That labors; performing labor; esp., performing coarse, heavy work, not requiring skill also, set apart for labor; as, laboring days.
Levantine: A native or inhabitant of the Levant.
Learn: To acquire knowledge or skill; to make progress in acquiring knowledge or skill; to receive information or instruction; as, this child learns quickly.
Lanthopine: An alkaloid found in opium in small quantities, and extracted as a white crystalline substance.
Lairdship: The state of being a laird; an estate; landed property.
Lumpenproletariat: the lowest level of the proletariat, comprising unskilled workers, the unemployed, and the dispossessed, alienated from the class with with they would normally identify and having little or no class solidarity; -- an important element in Marxist theory.
Laws: the first five books of the Old Testament, also called The Law and Torah.
&Verbar;Limu: The Hawaiian name for seaweeds. Over sixty kinds are used as food, and have species names, as Limu Lipoa, Limu palawai, etc.
litterbug: a person who litters public places with refuse.
&Verbar;Latirostres: The broad-billed singing birds, such as the swallows, and their allies.
Locellate: Divided into secondary compartments or cells, as where one cavity is separated into several smaller ones.
Loups: The Pawnees, a tribe of North American Indians whose principal totem was the wolf.
Ligroin: A trade name applied somewhat indefinitely to some of the volatile products obtained in refining crude petroleum. It is a complex and variable mixture of several hydrocarbons, generally boils below 170° Fahr., and is more inflammable than safe kerosene. It is used as a solvent, as a carburetant for air gas, and for illumination in special lamps.
Laurel: An evergreen shrub, of the genus Laurus (Laurus nobilis), having aromatic leaves of a lanceolate shape, with clusters of small, yellowish white flowers in their axils; -- called also sweet bay.
Levulinic: Pertaining to, or denoting, an acid (called also acetyl-propionic acid), C5H8O3, obtained by the action of dilute acids on various sugars (as levulose).
Leucoline: A nitrogenous organic base from coal tar, and identical with quinoline. Cf. Quinoline.
Limitary: That which serves to limit; a boundary; border land.
Lighthouse: A tower or other building with a powerful light at top, erected at the entrance of a port, or at some important point on a coast, to serve as a guide to mariners at night; a pharos.
Literation: The act or process of representing by letters.
Leonese: Of or pertaining to Leon, in Spain.
Lactodensimeter: A form of hydrometer, specially graduated, for finding the density of milk, and thus discovering whether it has been mixed with water or some of the cream has been removed.
Lorication: The act of loricating; the protecting substance put on; a covering of scales or plates.
leavened: made light by aerating, as with yeast or baking powder.  Opposite of unleavened.
Looking: The act of one who looks; a glance.
&Verbar;Lecythis: A genus of gigantic trees, chiefly Brazilian, of the order Myrtaceæ, having woody capsules opening by an apical lid. Lecythis Zabucajo yields the delicious sapucaia nuts. Lecythis Ollaria produces the monkey-pots, its capsules. Its bark separates into thin sheets, like paper, used by the natives for cigarette wrappers.
Laniary: Lacerating or tearing; as, the laniary canine teeth.
Linguistic: Of or pertaining to language; relating to linguistics, or to the affinities of languages.
&Verbar;Leipoa: A genus of Australian gallinaceous birds including but a single species (Leipoa ocellata), about the size of a turkey. Its color is variegated, brown, black, white, and gray. Called also native pheasant.
Laterite: An argillaceous sandstone, of a red color, and much seamed; -- found in India.
Labyrinthal: Pertaining to, or resembling, a labyrinth; intricate; labyrinthian.
Littery: Covered or encumbered with litter; consisting of or constituting litter.
Lanky: Somewhat lank; tall, thin, bony and ungraceful.
lodgepole pine: A tall, narrow 2-needled pine (Pinus contorta) of the coastal Northwestern U. S., having a red to yellow-brown bark fissured into small squares and bearing egg-shaped cones.
Lockup: A place where persons under arrest are temporarily locked up; a watchhouse; a jail.
Lifeboat: A strong, buoyant boat especially designed for saving the lives of shipwrecked people.
Limewater: Water impregnated with lime; esp., an artificial solution of lime for medicinal purposes.
-lith: Combining forms fr. Gr. li`qos a stone; -- used chiefly in naming minerals and rocks.
Logrolling: The act or process of rolling logs from the place where they were felled to the stream which floats them to the sawmill or to market. In this labor neighboring camps of loggers combine to assist each other in turn.
Light-handed: Not having a full complement of men; as, a vessel light-handed.
Light-struck: Damaged by accidental exposure to light; light-fogged; -- said of plates or films.
Light-horseman: A soldier who serves in the light horse. See under 5th Light.
Lanuginose: Covered with down, or fine soft hair; downy.
Ligustrin: A bitter principle found in the bark of the privet (Ligustrum vulgare), and extracted as a white crystalline substance with a warm, bitter taste; -- called also ligustron.
Leathern: Made of leather; consisting of leather; as, a leathern purse.
&Verbar;Locum tenens: A substitute or deputy; one filling an office for a time.
Lagenian: Like, or pertaining to, Lagena, a genus of Foraminifera having a straight, chambered shell.
Labradorite: A kind of feldspar commonly showing a beautiful play of colors, and hence much used for ornamental purposes. The finest specimens come from Labrador. See Feldspar.
Lituite: Any species of ammonites of the genus Lituites. They are found in the Cretaceous formation.
Leathery: Resembling leather in appearance or consistency; tough; as, nothing but a leathery steak left to eat.
Laumontite: A mineral, of a white color and vitreous luster. It is a hydrous silicate of alumina and lime. Exposed to the air, it loses water, becomes opaque, and crumbles.
Ligate: To tie with a ligature; to bind around; to bandage.
&Verbar;Lignum-vitae: A tree (Guaiacum officinale) found in the warm latitudes of America, from which the guaiacum of medicine is procured. Its wood is very hard and heavy, and is used for various mechanical purposes, as for the wheels of ships' blocks, cogs, bearings, and the like. See Guaiacum.
Lutrinae: A subdivision of mammals including the otters; it is not used in some classifications.
Logically: In a logical manner; as, to argue logically.
&Verbar;Lokao: A green vegetable dye imported from China.
lemmatize: To convert into a lemma{2}; to normalize the form of (a word) to that form used as the headword in a dictionary, glossary, or index; as, “ride” is the lemmatized form for “riding” and “ridden”.
Lactiferous: Bearing or containing milk or a milky fluid; as, the lactiferous vessels, cells, or tissue of various vascular plants.
Loke: A private path or road; also, the wicket or hatch of a door.
Lubrication: The act of lubricating; the act of making slippery.
Littress: A smooth kind of cartridge paper used for making cards.
Lademan: One who leads a pack horse; a miller's servant.
Liane: A luxuriant woody plant, climbing high trees and having ropelike stems. The grapevine often has the habit of a liane. Lianes are abundant in the forests of the Amazon region.
&Verbar;Lamellibranchia: An earlier name for the class of Mollusca including all those that have bivalve shells, as the clams, oysters, mussels, etc., now called Pelecypoda or Bivalvia.
Lombard: A native or inhabitant of Lombardy.
Legible: Capable of being read or deciphered; distinct to the eye; plain; -- used of writing or printing; as, a fair, legible manuscript.
Lappish: Of or pertaining to the Lapps; Laplandish.
Linear: Of or pertaining to a line; consisting of lines; in a straight direction; lineal.
Liassic: Of the age of the Lias; pertaining to the Lias formation.
Latescent: Slightly withdrawn from view or knowledge; as, a latescent meaning.
Land-poor: Pecuniarily embarrassed through owning much unprofitable land.
Lobeline: A poisonous narcotic alkaloid extracted from the leaves of Indian tobacco (Lobelia inflata) as a yellow oil, having a tobaccolike taste and odor.
Lineal: Descending in a direct line from an ancestor; hereditary; derived from ancestors; -- opposed to collateral; as, a lineal descent or a lineal descendant.
Loblolly: Gruel; porridge; -- so called among seamen.
&Verbar;Lester: A dry sirocco in the Madeira Islands.
&Verbar;Libra: The Balance; the seventh sign in the zodiac, which the sun enters at the autumnal equinox in September, marked thus &libra_; in almanacs, etc.
Leftward: Toward or on the left side.
&Verbar;Loco: A direction in written or printed music to return to the proper pitch after having played an octave higher.
Laconism: A vigorous, brief manner of expression; laconic style.
Latian: Belonging, or relating, to Latium, a country of ancient Italy. See Latin.
&Verbar;Longirostres: A group of birds characterized by having long slender bills, as the sandpipers, curlews, and ibises. It is now regarded as an artificial division.
long-haired: having long hair; as, long-haired hippies.
Lousiness: The state or quality of being lousy.
Liar: A person who knowingly utters falsehood; one who lies.
Localism: The state or quality of being local; affection for a particular place.
Linsang: Any viverrine mammal of the genus Prionodon, inhabiting the East Indies and Southern Asia. The common East Indian linsang (Prionodon gracilis) is white, crossed by broad, black bands. The Guinea linsang (Porana Richardsonii) is brown with black spots.
layby: A paved area beside a main road where cars can stop temporarily.
Lycoperdaceae: A natural family of fungi including the genus Lycoperdon, consisting of puffballs.
Lias: The lowest of the three divisions of the Jurassic period; a name given in England and Europe to a series of marine limestones underlying the Oölite. See the Chart of Geology.
Larchen: Of or pertaining to the larch.
&Verbar;Lithofracteur: An explosive compound of nitroglycerin. See Nitroglycerin.
light-haired: being or having light colored skin and hair; as, a certain light-haired girl.  Contrasted to brunet.
Longevous: Living a long time; of great age.
Love-sick: Languishing with love or amorous desire; as, a love-sick maid.
Loppard: A tree, the top of which has been lopped off.
Leucomaine: An animal base or alkaloid, appearing in the tissue during life; hence, a vital alkaloid, as distinguished from a ptomaine or cadaveric poison.
Lycium: A genus of deciduous and evergreen shrubs often spiny; cosmopolitan in temperate and subtropical regions.
-less: A privative adjective suffix, denoting without, destitute of, not having; as witless, childless, fatherless.
Longitudinal: A railway sleeper lying parallel with the rail.
Lawsonia: An Asiatic and North African shrub (Lawsonia inermis), with smooth oval leaves, and fragrant white flowers. Henna is prepared from the leaves and twigs. In England the shrub is called Egyptian privet, and in the West Indies, Jamaica mignonette.
Libel: To spread defamation, written or printed; -- with against.
Link motion: A valve gear, consisting of two eccentrics with their rods, giving motion to a slide valve by an adjustable connecting bar, called the link, in such a way that the motion of the engine can be reversed, or the cut-off varied, at will; -- used very generally in locomotives and marine engines.
louvered door: A door having louvers in place of a solid panel, in part or all of the surface of the door.
Lumbric: An earthworm, or a worm resembling an earthworm.
Lactoabumin: The albumin present in milk, apparently identical with ordinary serum albumin. It is distinct from the casein of milk.
Liroconite: A hydrated arseniate of copper, occurring in obtuse pyramidal crystals of a sky-blue or verdigris-green color.
Lidless: Having no lid, or not covered with the lids, as the eyes; hence, sleepless; watchful.
love-potion: a fabled drink credited with magical power; it can make the one who takes it love the one who gave it.
Lacerative: Lacerating, or having the power to lacerate; as, lacerative humors.
Loy: A long, narrow spade for stony lands.
Loanmonger: A dealer in, or negotiator of, loans.
Lemuria: A hypothetical land, or continent, supposed by some to have existed formerly in the Indian Ocean, of which Madagascar is a remnant.
&Verbar;Labellum: The lower or apparently anterior petal of an orchidaceous flower, often of a very curious shape.
&Verbar;Leptocardia: The lowest class of Vertebrata, including only the Amphioxus. The heart is represented only by a simple pulsating vessel. The blood is colorless; the brain, renal organs, and limbs are wanting, and the backbone is represented only by a simple, unsegmented notochord. See Amphioxus.
Lonicera: A genus of vines including the woodbine, Lonicera periclymenum.
Lutulence: The state or quality of being lutulent.
Legioned: Formed into a legion or legions; legionary.
Lustiness: State of being lusty; vigor; strength.
Lentiginous: Of or pertaining to lentigo; freckly; scurfy; furfuraceous.
Leavening: The act of making light, or causing to ferment, by means of leaven.
Liechtensteiner: A native or inhabitant of Leichtenstein.
leftover: An unused part or portion; -- used especially of food remaining uneaten from a previous meal; as, to have leftovers for dinner.
Lot: To allot; to sort; to portion.
Lymphography: A description of the lymphatic vessels, their origin and uses.
Laticlave: A broad stripe of purple on the fore part of the tunic, worn by senators in ancient Rome as an emblem of office.
Loanable: Such as can be lent; available for lending; as, loanable funds; -- used mostly in financial business and writings.
Lambskin: The skin of a lamb; especially, a skin dressed with the wool on, and used as a mat. Also used adjectively.
linecut: a print obtained from a line drawing.
Ledgment: A string-course or horizontal suit of moldings, such as the base moldings of a building.
loss leader: an article of merchandise sold at a loss in order to draw customers.
Lophine: A nitrogenous organic base obtained by the oxidation of amarine, and regarded as a derivative of benzoic aldehyde. It is obtained in long white crystalline tufts, -- whence its name.
Lifter: One who, or that which, lifts.
linemen: the football players who line up on the line of scrimmage.
Liturate: Having indistinct spots, paler at their margins.
Levulosan: An unfermentable carbohydrate obtained by gently heating levulose.
Lapling: One who has been fondled to excess; one fond of ease and sensual delights; -- a term of contempt.
Ludwigite: A borate of iron and magnesia, occurring in fibrous masses of a blackish green color.
Logographer: A chronicler; one who writes history in a condensed manner with short simple sentences.
lipfern: any of various terrestrial ferns of the genus Cheilanthes; they are cosmopolitan in arid and semi-arid temperate or tropical regions.
Leash: To tie together, or hold, with a leash.
&Verbar;Leiotrichi: The division of mankind which embraces the smooth-haired races.
Lith: A joint or limb; a division; a member; a part formed by growth, and articulated to, or symmetrical with, other parts.
Labyrinthiform: Having the form of a labyrinth; intricate.
Linoleum: Linseed oil brought to various degrees of hardness by some oxidizing process, as by exposure to heated air, or by treatment with chloride of sulphur. In this condition it is used for many of the purposes to which India rubber has been applied.
Lease: The temporary transfer of a possession to another person in return for a fee or other valuable consideration paid for the transfer;
Liliidae: one of four subclasses or superorders of Monocotyledones; it comprises 17 families including: Liliaceae; Alliaceae; Amaryllidaceae; Iridaceae; Orchidaceae; Trilliaceae.
Lark-colored: Having the sandy brown color of the European larks.
Lilith: a female demon who attacks children.
&Verbar;Limulus: The only existing genus of Merostomata. It includes only a few species from the East Indies, and one (Limulus polyphemus) from the Atlantic coast of North America. Called also Molucca crab, king crab, horseshoe crab, and horsefoot.
Leban: Coagulated sour milk diluted with water; -- a common beverage among the Arabs.  Also, a fermented liquor made of the same.
Land of Steady Habits: Connecticut; -- a nickname alluding to the moral character of its inhabitants, implied by the rigid laws (see Blue laws) of the early period.
Lute: To play on a lute, or as on a lute.
Labiose: Having the appearance of being labiate; -- said of certain polypetalous corollas.
L-P: a long-playing phonograph record; designed to be played at 33.3 rpm.
leatherjack: any of several New World tropical fishes having tiny embedded scales; the leatherjacket{2}.
Luxuriant: Exuberant in growth; rank; excessive; profuse; very abundant; as, a luxuriant growth of grass; luxuriant foliage.
Laryngotomy: The operation of cutting into the larynx, from the outside of the neck, for assisting respiration when obstructed, or for removing foreign bodies.
Llama: A South American ruminant (Auchenia llama), allied to the camels, but much smaller and without a hump. It is supposed to be a domesticated variety of the guanaco. It was formerly much used as a beast of burden in the Andes, and is also kept on some ranches in the United States.
Lobar: Of or pertaining to a lobe; characterized by, or like, a lobe or lobes.
Lombard-house: A bank or a pawnbroker's shop.
Lepidodendrales: An order of fossil arborescent plants arising during the Lower Devonian and conspicuous throughout the Carboniferous.
&Verbar;Leo: The Lion, the fifth sign of the zodiac, marked thus [&leo_;] in almanacs.
Layette: The outfit of clothing, blankets, etc., prepared for a newborn infant, and placed ready for use.
LEM: A lunar excursion module, a spacecraft designed to transport people from a command module in orbit around the moon to the surface of the moon and back again.
Leyte: The name of an island in the Pacific Ocean and of a battle in World War II, at which the American forces experienced the first use of Kamikaze aircraft by the Japanese.  The return of U. S. troops to the Philippines after their expulsion by the Japanese began with landings on Leyte Island in October 1944.
&Verbar;Lex: Law; as, lex talionis, the law of retaliation; lex terræ, the law of the land; lex fori, the law of the forum or court; lex loci, the law of the place; lex mercatoria, the law or custom of merchants.
linelike: resembling a line; long, thin, and narrow.
Lightweight: Light in weight, as a coin; specif., applied to a man or animal who is a lightweight.
Lepidopteral: Of or pertaining to the Lepidoptera.
Lancaster: A city in Northwest England on the river Lune.
Lengthy: Having length; rather long or too long; prolix; not brief; -- said chiefly of discourses, writings, and the like.
Limpness: The quality or state of being limp.
Latent: Not visible or apparent; hidden; concealed; secret; dormant; as, latent springs of action.
Layman: One of the people, in distinction from the clergy; one of the laity; sometimes, a man not belonging to some particular profession, in distinction from those who do.
Laureateship: State, or office, of a laureate.
Latticing: The act or process of making a lattice of, or of fitting a lattice to.
long-playing: playing at a slower speed and for a longer time than earlier records; -- used of phonograph records.
Lifestring: A nerve, or string, that is imagined to be essential to life.
lichee: A Chinese tree (Litchi chinensis) cultivated especially in the Philippines and India for its edible fruit, the litchi nut; sometimes placed in the genus Nephelium.
Lycosa: The type genus of the family Lycosidae.
Lapidescence: The state or quality of being lapidescent.
Lovemonger: One who deals in affairs of love.
Lionize: To treat or regard as a lion or object of great interest.
Lad: A boy; a youth; a stripling.
Liquidate: To determine by agreement or by litigation the precise amount of (indebtedness); or, where there is an indebtedness to more than one person, to determine the precise amount of (each indebtedness); to make the amount of (an indebtedness) clear and certain.
Lightwood: Pine wood abounding in pitch, used for torches in the Southern United States; pine knots, dry sticks, and the like, for kindling a fire quickly or making a blaze.
Lacerate: Rent; torn; mangled; as, a lacerated wound.
left wing: Those trying to reform the established order, particularly in political matters, to enhance the condition of the common people; -- sometimes applied to those advocating overthrow of an existing government by radical means.
Lasthenia: A small genus of herbs of the Pacific coast of North and South America.
Lac: A resinous substance produced mainly on the banyan tree, but to some extent on other trees, by the Laccifer lacca (formerly Coccus lacca), a scale-shaped insect, the female of which fixes herself on the bark, and exudes from the margin of her body this resinous substance.
Lay: That which lies or is laid or is conceived of as having been laid or placed in its position; a row; a stratum; a layer; as, a lay of stone or wood.
Lap: The act of lapping with, or as with, the tongue; as, to take anything into the mouth with a lap.
&Verbar;Lemures: Spirits or ghosts of the departed; specters.
Lar: A species of gibbon (Hylobates lar), found in Burmah. Called also white-handed gibbon.
Lithotypy: The art or process of making a kind of hard, stereotype plate, by pressing into a mold, taken from a page of type or other matter, a composition of gum shellac and sand of a fine quality, together with a little tar and linseed oil, all in a heated state.
Liver: The glossy ibis (Ibis falcinellus); -- said to have given its name to the city of Liverpool.
Lucubrate: To elaborate, perfect, or compose, by night study or by laborious endeavor.
Loneliness: The condition of being lonely; solitude; seclusion.
Lingual: A consonant sound formed by the aid of the tongue; -- a term especially applied to certain articulations (as those of t, d, th, and n) and to the letters denoting them.
Low-pressure: Having, employing, or exerting, a low degree of pressure.
Lithotype: To prepare for printing with plates made by the process of lithotypy. See Lithotypy.
Leitneria: A genus of trees or shrubs coextensive with the family Leitneriaceae, and including the corkwood (Leitneria floridana).
Laurite: A rare sulphide of osmium and ruthenium found with platinum in Borneo and Oregon.
Licensee: The person to whom a license is given.
Licensed: Having a license; permitted or authorized by license; as, a licensed victualer; a licensed traffic.
&Verbar;Lento: Slow; in slow time; slowly; -- rarely written lente.
Lyrid: One of the group of shooting stars which come into the air in certain years on or about the 19th of April; -- so called because the apparent path among the stars if traced backwards crosses the constellation Lyra.
Lyric: A lyric poem; a lyrical composition.
Latimeridae: A natural family of fish extinct except for the coelacanth.
Licenser: One who gives a license; as, a licenser of the press.
Levitate: To make buoyant; to cause to float in the air; as, to levitate a table.
&Verbar;Lern\u00e6a: A Linnæan genus of parasitic Entomostraca, -- the same as the family Lernæidæ.
Lactucin: A white, crystalline substance, having a bitter taste and a neutral reaction, and forming one of the essential ingredients of lactucarium.
limbic system: A group of neural structures in the brain below the cerebral cortex, centered on the hypothalamus and including the hippocampus and amygdala, involved with control of emotion, motivation, memory, and some homeostatic regulatory processes.
Lobster pot: a device used to trap lobsters, consisting of a semi-cylindrical structure made of wooden slats, with openings formed of funnel-shaped nets allowing lobsters to enter, but impeding their exit.  It is also called a lobster trap.
Laminable: Capable of being split into laminæ or thin plates, as mica; capable of being extended under pressure into a thin plate or strip.
Lactucic: Pertaining to, or derived from, the juice of the Lactuca virosa; -- said of certain acids.
Lusitania: An ancient region and Roman province of the Iberian peninsula, corresponding roughly to modern Portugal and parts of Spain.
Lager beer: Originally a German beer, but now also made in immense quantities in the United States; -- so called from its being laid up or stored for some months before use.
long-run: relating to or extending over a relatively long time; as, the long-run significance of the elections.
limelight: That part of the stage upon which the limelight is cast, usually where the most important action is progressing or where the leading player or players are placed and upon which the attention of the spectators is therefore concentrated.
Leptocardian: Of or pertaining to the Leptocardia.
Leiophyllum: A genus having only one species, the sand myrtle.
Lupinin: A glucoside found in the seeds of several species of lupine, and extracted as a yellowish white crystalline substance.
Loriot: The golden oriole of Europe. See Oriole.
Lilywort: Any plant of the Lily family or order.
Lochial: Of or pertaining to the lochia.
Lixiviation: Lixiviating; the process of separating a soluble substance from one that is insoluble, by washing with some solvent, as water; leaching.
Levator: A muscle that serves to raise some part, as the lip or the eyelid.
Liquate: To separate by fusion, as a more fusible from a less fusible material.
Logarithm: One of a class of auxiliary numbers, devised by John Napier, of Merchiston, Scotland (1550-1617), to abridge arithmetical calculations, by the use of addition and subtraction in place of multiplication and division.
Letheonize: To subject to the influence of letheon.
Limenitis: A genus comprising mainly dark northern butterflies with white wing bars.
Litheness: The quality or state of being lithe; flexibility; limberness.
Liman: The deposit of slime at the mouth of a river; slime.
lecherousness: an inclination to excessive indulgence in sexual activity; habitually developing a strong sexual arousal.
Lionism: An attracting of attention, as a lion; also, the treating or regarding as a lion.
lower-middle-class: occupying the lower part of the middle socioeconomic range in a society.
Luxate: To displace, or remove from its proper place, as a joint; to put out of joint; to dislocate.
low-cut: having a neckline low enough to expose part of the breast; -- of a woman's garment; as, a low-cut party dress.
Larviform: Having the form or structure of a larva.
legalisation: the act of legalizing; same as legalization.
Lazyback: A support for the back, attached to the seat of a carriage.
Ligament: Anything that ties or unites one thing or part to another; a bandage; a bond.
Lighterage: The price paid for conveyance of goods on a lighter.
Luscinia: A genus of birds including the nightingale Luscinia megarhyncos.
Limehound: A dog used in hunting the wild boar; a leamer.
&Verbar;Lochia: The discharge from the womb and vagina which follows childbirth.
life-of-man: An unarmed woody rhizomatous perennial plant (Aralia racemosa) distinguished from wild sarsaparilla by more aromatic roots and panicled umbels; it grows from Southeastern North America to Mexico.
liparis: an orchid of the genus Liparis having few leaves and usually fairly small yellow-green or dull purple flowers in terminal racemes.
&Verbar;Lour: An Asiatic sardine (Clupea Neohowii), valued for its oil.
Lithosian: Any one of various species of moths belonging to the family Lithosidæ. Many of them are beautifully colored.
Loosestrife: The name of several species of plants of the genus Lysimachia, having small star-shaped flowers, usually of a yellow color.
Latin: To write or speak in Latin; to turn or render into Latin.
Larcenous: Having the character of larceny; as, a larcenous act; committing larceny.
Leporidae: A natural family of mammals comprising the hares and rabbits.
Lace-bark: A shrub in the West Indies (Lagetta Iintearia); -- so called from the lacelike layers of its inner bark.
Lubricate: To make smooth or slippery; as, mucilaginous and saponaceous remedies lubricate the parts to which they are applied.
lovebird: A small Australian parakeet (Melopsittacus undulatus) usually light green with black and yellow markings in the wild but bred in many colors; also called the budgie.
Linguiform: Having the form of the tongue; tongue-shaped.
Lancelet: A small fishlike animal (Amphioxus lanceolatus), remarkable for the rudimentary condition of its organs. It is the type of the class Leptocardia. See Amphioxus, Leptocardia.
Longing: An eager desire; a craving; a morbid appetite; an earnest wish; an aspiration.
Lemuroid: Like or pertaining to the lemurs or the Lemuroidea.
Lanioid: Of or pertaining to the shrikes (family Laniidæ).
&Verbar;Lituus: A curved staff used by the augurs in quartering the heavens.
Lengthways: In the direction of the length; running or extending in the direction of the length of a thing; in a longitudinal direction.  Contrasted with crosswise.
Lichenous: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, lichens; abounding in lichens; covered with lichens.
lithogenous: Stone-producing; -- said of polyps which form coral.
Lobiped: Having lobate toes, as a coot.
Lepidosiren: An eel-shaped ganoid fish of the order Dipnoi, having both gills and lungs. It inhabits the rivers of South America. The name is also applied to a related African species (Protopterus annectens). The lepidosirens grow to a length of from four to six feet. Called also doko.
Landfall: A sudden transference of property in land by the death of its owner.
losses: something lost, especially money lost at gambling.  Inverse of winnings.
Lapis lazuli: An albuminous mineral of a rich blue color; also called lapis. Same as Lazuli, which see.
lasagna: A baked dish of layers of lasagna{2} pasta with sauce and cheese and meat or vegetables; -- a popular dish of Italian cuisine.
Lancinating: Piercing; seeming to pierce or stab; as, lancinating pains (i.e., severe, darting pains).
Laced: Fastened with a lace or laces; decorated with narrow strips or braid. See Lace, v. t.
Luteocobaltic: Pertaining to, or designating, certain compounds of cobalt having a yellow color.  Cf. Cobaltic.
Ludlow group: A subdivision of the British Upper Silurian lying below the Old Red Sandstone; -- so named from the Ludlow, in Western England. See the Chart of Geology.
Lustrical: Pertaining to, or used for, purification.
Luciferase: an enzyme which catalyzes the oxidation of luciferin, thereby producing bioluminescence.
Lived: Having life; -- used only in composition; as, long-lived; short-lived.
Libation: The act of pouring a liquid or liquor, usually wine, either on the ground or on a victim in sacrifice, in honor of some deity; also, the wine or liquid thus poured out.
&Verbar;Lenticula: A kind of eruption upon the skin; lentigo; freckle.
Labyrinth: An edifice or place full of intricate passageways which render it difficult to find the way from the interior to the entrance; as, the Egyptian and Cretan labyrinths.
-ly: A suffix forming adjectives and adverbs, and denoting likeness or resemblance; as, housewifely duties.
Lollipop: A kind of sugar confection which dissolves easily in the mouth.
Low-churchmanship: The state of being a low-churchman.
Lodgment: The act of lodging, or the state of being lodged.
lady-in-waiting: a lady appointed to attend to a queen or princess.
Legist: One skilled in the laws; a writer on law.
Legitimateness: The state or quality of being legitimate; lawfulness; genuineness.
&Verbar;Literati: Learned or literary men. See Literatus.
Londonism: A characteristic of Londoners; a mode of speaking peculiar to London.
lentissimo: very slow; very slowly; -- of music tempo.
Lorikeet: Any one numerous species of small brush-tongued parrots or lories, found mostly in Australia, New Guinea and the adjacent islands, with some forms in the East Indies. They are arboreal in their habits and feed largely upon the honey of flowers. They belong to Trichoglossus, Loriculus, and several allied genera.
Longshoreman: One of a class of laborers employed about the wharves of a seaport, especially in loading and unloading vessels.
Looplight: A small narrow opening or window in a tower or fortified wall; a loophole.
Leap year: Bissextile; a year containing 366 days; every fourth year which leaps over a day more than a common year, giving to February twenty-nine days. See Bissextile.
Libyan: Of, pertaining to, or characteristic of, the country Libya or its inhabitants.
Laticiferous: Containing the latex; -- applied to the tissue or tubular vessels in which the latex of the plant is found.
liveness: The quality of having animal life as distinguished from plant life.
Low-churchism: The principles of the low-church party.
leafroller: The larva of any tortricid moth which makes a nest by rolling up the leaves of plants and tying the leaves with spun silk; aalso, the moth itself.  See Tortrix.
lefthander: a person who uses the left hand with greater skill than the right; a left-handed{1} person.
Loo: To beat in the game of loo by winning every trick.
Lanate: Wooly; covered with fine long hair, or hairlike filaments.
&Verbar;Lissencephala: A general name for all those placental mammals that have a brain with few or no cerebral convolutions, as Rodentia, Insectivora, etc.
Legion: A body of foot soldiers and cavalry consisting of different numbers at different periods, -- from about four thousand to about six thousand men, -- the cavalry being about one tenth.
Liquefiable: Capable of being changed from a solid to a liquid state.
Low-minded: Inclined in mind to low or unworthy things; showing a base mind.
Lithophagous: Eating or swallowing stones or gravel, as the ostrich.
Lithoid: Like a stone; having a stony structure.
Lentinus: The most important genus of mushrooms in the Far East.
Lettish: Of or pertaining to the Letts.
Lepanto: The name of a battle in which Turkish seapower was destroyed by the Christian League in 1571.
Lamellibranch: One of the Lamellibranchia (also called Pelecypoda). Also used adjectively.
low-rise: Lower than the highest heights; -- used of buildings of one or only a few stories; as, a low-rise apartment building.
Loach: Any one of several small, fresh-water, cyprinoid fishes of the genera Cobitis, Nemachilus, and allied genera, having six or more barbules around the mouth. They are found in Europe and Asia. The common European species (Nemachilus barbatulus) is used as a food fish.
lithographic: Of or pertaining to lithography; made by lithography; as, the lithographic art; a lithographic picture.
Lorica: A cuirass, originally of leather, afterward of plates of metal or horn sewed on linen or the like.
Lustering: The act or process of imparting a luster, as to pottery.
Lucidity: The quality or state of being lucid.
Lather: To beat severely with a thong, strap, or the like; to flog.
leatherfish: any of several brightly colored tropical filefishes.
Loquacity: The habit or practice of talking continually or excessively; inclination to talk too much; talkativeness; garrulity.
Longhand: The written characters used in the common method of writing; -- opposed to shorthand; as, took it down in longhand.
Lisp: The habit or act of lisping. See Lisp, v. i., 1.
lasciviousness: The state or habitual condition of feeling an excessive or morbid sexual desire.
Lemur: One of a family (Lemuridæ) of nocturnal mammals allied to the monkeys, but of small size, and having a sharp and foxlike muzzle, and large eyes. They feed upon birds, insects, and fruit, and are mostly natives of Madagascar and the neighboring islands, one genus (Galago) occurring in Africa.  The slow lemur or kukang of the East Indies is Nycticebus tardigradus. See Galago, Indris, and Colugo.
Liss: To free, as from care or pain; to relieve.
List: To plow and plant with a lister.
Libriform: Having the form of liber, or resembling liber.
Lapsed: Having slipped downward, backward, or away; having lost position, privilege, etc., by neglect; -- restricted to figurative uses.
Larviparous: Depositing living larvæ, instead of eggs; -- said of certain insects.
Liberalistic: Pertaining to, or characterized by, liberalism; as, liberalistic opinions.
lerot: A small rodent (Eliomys nitela) of Europe and Northern Africa, allied to the dormouse.
Lithotomist: One who performs the operation of cutting for stone in the bladder, or one who is skilled in the operation.
Liken: To allege, or think, to be like; to represent as like; to compare; as, to liken life to a pilgrimage.
Lilium: The type genus of the Liliaceae.
&Verbar;Likin: A Chinese provincial tax levied at many inland stations upon imports or articles in transit.
Lithotriptor: An instrument for triturating the stone in the bladder; a lithotrite.
Loment: An elongated pod, consisting, like the legume, of two valves, but divided transversely into small cells, each containing a single seed.
Lego-literary: Pertaining to the literature of law.
Live-forever: A plant (Sedum Telephium) with fleshy leaves, which has extreme powers of resisting drought; garden ox-pine.
Lapidary: Of or pertaining to the art of cutting stones, or engraving on stones, either gems or monuments; as, lapidary ornamentation.
Lakeweed: The water pepper (Polygonum Hydropiper), an aquatic plant of Europe and North America.
Lithophyll: A fossil leaf or impression of a leaf.
&Verbar;Larvalia: An order of Tunicata, including Appendicularia, and allied genera; -- so called because certain larval features are retained by them through life. Called also Copelata. See Appendicularia.
lechatelierite: A naturally occurring colorless glass made of almost pure silica, and found in fulgurites, which are produced by lightning striking sand.
lipophilic: having an affinity for lipids; -- of chemical substances or parts of molecules.  Contrasted to lipophobic or polar.
littler: small or little relative to something else.
Lambis: A genus of scorpion shells of shallow tropical waters of eastern hemisphere.
Labarraques solution: An aqueous solution of sodium hypochlorite, extensively used as a disinfectant.
&Verbar;Lotophagi: A people visited by Ulysses in his wanderings. They subsisted on the lotus. See Lotus (b), and Lotus-eater.
&Verbar;Livraison: A part of a book or literary composition printed and delivered by itself; a number; a part.
lateral: To pass the footbal to a receiver who is behind the passer; to make a lateral pass; as, the ball was lateraled to the fullback, who ran it for a touchdown.
logistician: a person skilled at symbolic logic.
Locutory: A room for conversation; especially, a room in monasteries, where the monks were allowed to converse.
load-bearing: Supporting a load{10} from parts of a structure above; as, a load-bearing wall.
Losing: Causing or likely to cause a loss; as, a losing game or business; a losing strategy.
Loculose: Divided by internal partitions into cells, as the pith of the pokeweed.
light-green: Having a light green color, similar to the color of fresh grass.
Laxness: The state of being lax; laxity.
libido: Sexual desire; the sexual instinct; the sex drive.
L: Having the general shape of the (capital) letter L; as, an L beam, or L-beam.
Lituate: Forked, with the points slightly curved outward.
Loadstone: A piece of magnetite, a magnetic iron ore, possessing polarity like a magnetic needle, having the power to attract as well as to be attracted magnetically. See Magnetite.
low-set: short and thick; especially having short legs and heavy musculature; -- of people.
Lok: The evil deity, the author of all calamities and mischief, answering to the Ahriman of the Persians.
Landslide: The slipping down of a mass of land from a mountain, hill, etc.
Leveler: One who, or that which, levels.
Lantern-jawed: Having lantern jaws or long, thin jaws; as, a lantern-jawed person.
Leucopathy: The state of an albino, or of a white child of black parents.
litter-bearer: one who helps carry a stretcher.
Lace: To be fastened with a lace, or laces; as, these boots lace.
Lochaber ax: A weapon of war, consisting of a pole armed with an axhead at its end, formerly used by the Scotch Highlanders.
Lambdoid: Shaped like the Greek letter lambda (Λ); as, the lambdoid suture between the occipital and parietal bones of the skull.
Locksmith: A person whose occupation is to make, mend, or install locks, or to make keys for locks.
&Verbar;Lakh: Same as Lac, one hundred thousand.
leatherneck: The sordid friar bird of Australia (Tropidorhynchus sordidus).
Landreeve: A subordinate officer on an extensive estate, who acts as an assistant to the steward.
Lucullite: A variety of black limestone, often polished for ornamental purposes.
leaf-hopper: A small leaping insect that sucks the juices of plants.
Legislate: To make or enact a law or laws.
Leporine: Of or pertaining to a hare; like or characteristic of, a hare.
&Verbar;Leptus: The six-legged young, or larva, of certain mites; -- sometimes used as a generic name. See Harvest mite, under Harvest.
Lardy: Containing, or resembling, lard; of the character or consistency of lard.
Lungwort: An herb of the genus Pulmonaria (Pulmonaria officinalis), of Europe; -- so called because the spotted appearance of the leaves resembles that of a diseased lung.
Lamia: A monster capable of assuming a woman's form, who was said to devour human beings or suck their blood; a vampire; a sorceress; a witch.
Loosener: One who, or that which, loosens.
Lowbell: To frighten, as with a lowbell.
Lexicographic: Of or pertaining to, or according to, lexicography.
Lapps: A branch of the Mongolian race, now living in the northern parts of Norway, Sweden, and the adjacent parts of Russia.
Lumbrical: Resembling a worm; as, the lumbrical muscles of the hands of the hands and feet.
Latchkey: A key used to raise, or throw back, the latch of a door, esp. a night latch.
Lorcha: A kind of light vessel used on the coast of China, having the hull built on a European model, and the rigging like that of a Chinese junk.
Lacing: The act of securing, fastening, or tightening, with a lace or laces.
Lacertidae: A natural family of Old World lizards.
Lavatic: Like lava, or composed of lava; lavic.
luminousness: the quality of being luminous; emitting or reflecting light.
Lanthanite: Hydrous carbonate of lanthanum, found in tabular white crystals.
Laker: One that is connected with a lake or lakes, as in habitation, toil, etc.:
lampshell: A mollusklike marine animal with bivalve shell having a pair of arms bearing tentacles for capturing food, found worldwide.
Laparocele: A rupture or hernia in the lumbar regions.
Lurid: Pale yellow; ghastly pale; wan; gloomy; dismal.
Libelous: Containing or involving a libel; defamatory; containing that which exposes some person to public hatred, contempt, or ridicule; as, a libelous pamphlet.
Lovage: An umbelliferous plant (Levisticum officinale), sometimes used in medicine as an aromatic stimulant.
Lobate: Consisting of, or having, lobes; lobed; as, a lobate leaf.
