Ladys mantle: A genus of rosaceous herbs (Alchemilla), esp. the European Alchemilla vulgaris, which has leaves with rounded and finely serrated lobes.
Liniment: A liquid or semiliquid preparation of a consistence thinner than an ointment, applied to the skin by friction, esp. one used as a sedative or a stimulant.
Lycanthrope: A human being fabled to have been changed into a wolf; a werewolf.
Labile: Liable to slip, err, fall, or apostatize.
Longbeak: The American redbellied snipe (Macrorhamphus scolopaceus); -- called also long-billed dowitcher.
Laically: As a layman; after the manner of a layman; as, to treat a matter laically.
Lutheranism: The doctrines taught by Luther or held by the Lutheran Church.
Leverwood: The American hop hornbeam (Ostrya Virginica), a small tree with very tough wood.
Linguist: A master of the use of language; a talker.
loads: A large quantity; a lot; as, loads of fun.
Lagothrix: A mammal genus comprising the woolly monkeys.
Lustral: Of or pertaining to, or used for, purification; as, lustral days; lustral water.
&Verbar;Leptostraca: An order of Crustacea, including Nebalia and allied forms.
Loud-mouthed: Having a loud voice; talking or sounding noisily; noisily impudent or offensive.
liaison: A union, or bond of union; an intimacy; an interrelationship.
&Verbar;Lira: An Italian coin equivalent in value to the French franc.
Leamer: A dog held by a leam.
&Verbar;Lungoor: A long-tailed monkey (Semnopithecus schislaceus), from the mountainous districts of India.
Linener: A dealer in linen; a linen draper.
&Verbar;Labyrinthodonta: An extinct order of Amphibia, including the typical genus Labyrinthodon, and many other allied forms, from the Carboniferous, Permian, and Triassic formations. By recent writers they are divided into two or more orders. See Stegocephala.
Linguistics: The science of languages, or of the origin, signification, and application of words; glossology.
Lyncean: Of or pertaining to the lynx.
Lucule: A spot or fleck on the sun brighter than the surrounding surface.
labourious: characterized by toilsome effort; same as laborious; -- British spelling.
liquefied: converted to a liquid; as, liquified natural gas; liquified coal.
Lithe: To smooth; to soften; to palliate.
Lump: To throw into a mass; to unite in a body or sum without distinction of particulars.
Litho: A combining form from Gr. li`qos, stone.
Leyden jar: A glass jar or bottle used to accumulate electricity.  It is coated with tin foil, within and without, nearly to its top, and is surmounted by a brass knob which communicates with the inner coating, for the purpose of charging it with electricity. It is so named from having been invented in Leyden, Holland.
Lurry: A confused heap; a throng, as of persons; a jumble, as of sounds.
Liturgist: One who favors or adheres strictly to a liturgy.
Locate: To place one's self; to take up one's residence; to settle; as, to locate in Seattle.
landmass: a large continuous extent of land; as, the Eurasian landmass.
Ledum: A genus of evergreen shrubs of the north temperate regions.
Levirate: Of, pertaining to, or in accordance with, a law of the ancient Israelites and other tribes and races, according to which a woman, whose husband died without issue, was married to the husband's brother.
landlubberly: Like a landlubber: inexperienced in seamanshap.
light-sensitive: Affected by light; as, the light-sensitive pigments in the retina.
listed: placed on a list.  Opposite of unlisted.
Lime-twigged: Beset with snares; insnared, as with birdlime.
Language: To communicate by language; to express in language.
limnology: the scientific study of bodies of fresh water for their biological and physical and geological properties.
Locust: Any one of numerous species of long-winged, migratory, orthopterous insects, of the family Acrididæ, allied to the grasshoppers; esp., (Edipoda migratoria, syn. Pachytylus migratoria, and Acridium perigrinum, of Southern Europe, Asia, and Africa. In the United States the related species with similar habits are usually called grasshoppers. See Grasshopper.
Loosen: To become loose; to become less tight, firm, or compact.
Lemming: Any one of several species of small arctic rodents of the genera Myodes and Cuniculus, resembling the meadow mice in form. They are found in both hemispheres.
Lithologist: One who is skilled in lithology.
leaderless: lacking a leader; as, a leaderless mob running riot in the streets.
Llullaillaco: A mountain in Argentina and Chile, 22,057 feet high.
Linaria: A genus of herbs and subshrubs having showy flowers: spurred snapdragon.
Levelism: The disposition or endeavor to level all distinctions of rank in society.
lingenberry: low evergreen shrub (Vaccinium vitis-idaea) of high north temperate regions of Europe and Asia and America bearing red edible berries.
Lance fish: A slender marine fish of the genus Ammodytes, especially Ammodytes tobianus of the English coast; -- called also sand lance.
Long-sightedness: The state or condition of being long-sighted; hence, sagacity; shrewdness.
Lallation: An imperfect enunciation of the letter r, in which it sounds like l.
Limerick: A humorous, often nonsensical, and sometimes risqé poem of five anapestic lines, of which  lines 1, 2, and 5 are of three feet, and rhyme, and lines 3 and 4 are of two feet, and rhyme.
Landlocked: Inclosed, or nearly inclosed, by land; having no border on the sea; as, a landlocked country.
Litmus: A dyestuff extracted from certain lichens (Roccella tinctoria, Lecanora tartarea, etc.), as a blue amorphous mass which consists of a compound of the alkaline carbonates with certain coloring matters related to orcin and orcein.
Luckless: Being without luck; unpropitious; unfortunate; unlucky; meeting with ill success or bad fortune; as, a luckless gamester; a luckless maid.
Lathy: Like a lath; long and slender.
Languor: A state of the body or mind which is caused by exhaustion of strength and characterized by a languid feeling; feebleness; lassitude; laxity.
&Verbar;Linguatulina: An order of wormlike, degraded, parasitic arachnids. They have two pairs of retractile hooks, near the mouth. Called also Pentastomida.
lacrimator: a chemical substance that causes tears to flow; same as lachrymator.
lilting: having a light rhythmical cadence; as, an easy lilting stride; a lilting melody.
Lentil: A leguminous plant of the genus Ervum (Ervum Lens), of small size, common in the fields in Europe. Also, its seed, which is used for food on the continent.
Longboat: Formerly, the largest boat carried by a merchant vessel, corresponding to the launch of a naval vessel.
Late: After the usual or proper time, or the time appointed; after delay; as, he arrived late; -- opposed to early.
Liturgy: An established formula for public worship, or the entire ritual for public worship in a church which uses prescribed forms; a formulary for public prayer or devotion. In the Roman Catholic Church it includes all forms and services in any language, in any part of the world, for the celebration of Mass.
Labialization: The modification of an articulation by contraction of the lip opening.
Lata: A convulsive tic or hysteric neurosis prevalent among Malays, similar to or identical with miryachit and jumping disease, the person affected performing various involuntary actions and making rapid inarticulate ejaculations in imitation of the actions and words of another person.
Losenger: A flatterer; a deceiver; a cozener.
Lions tail: A genus of labiate plants (Leonurus); -- so called from a fancied resemblance of its flower spikes to the tuft of a lion's tail. Leonurus Cardiaca is the common motherwort.
Longmynd rocks: The sparingly fossiliferous conglomerates, grits, schists, and slates of Great Britain, which lie at the base of the Cambrian system; -- so called, because typically developed in the Longmynd Hills, Shropshire.
Lath: To cover or line with laths.
looseleaf paper: Sheets of writing paper having holes at the edge permitting insertion into and removal from a looseleaf binder.
Laputan: Of or pertaining to Laputa, an imaginary flying island described in Gulliver's Travels as the home of chimerical philosophers.
Lygaeidae: A natural family comprising the lygaeid bugs.
Lardacein: A peculiar amyloid substance, colored blue by iodine and sulphuric acid, occurring mainly as an abnormal infiltration into the spleen, liver, etc.
Lithia: The oxide of lithium; a strong alkaline caustic similar to potash and soda, but weaker. See Lithium.
Lucid: Shining; bright; resplendent; as, the lucid orbs of heaven.
Lithic: Pertaining to or denoting lithium or some of its compounds.
Leapfrog: A play among boys, in which one stoops down and another leaps over him by placing his hands on the shoulders of the former.
line-shooter: a very boastful and talkative person.
Long-winded: Long-breathed; hence, tediously long in speaking; consuming much time; as, a long-winded talker.
lachrymator: A chemical substance that causes tears to flow; same as lacrimator.
Linguacious: Given to the use of the tongue; loquacious.
Lorrie: A small cart or wagon moving on rails, as those used on the tramways in mines to carry coal or rubbish; also, a barrow or truck for shifting baggage, as at railway stations.
long-drawn-out: relatively long in duration; as, a long-drawn-out visit from my mother-in-law.
Lyme grass: A coarse perennial grass of several species of Elymus, esp. Elymus Canadensis, and the European Elymus arenarius.
Lifehold: Land held by a life estate.
Latinism: A Latin idiom; a mode of speech peculiar to Latin; also, a mode of speech in another language, as English, formed on a Latin model.
Logography: A method of printing in which whole words or syllables, cast as single types, are used.
leaking: having liquid seeping in or out through openings; leaky.
Loculus: One of the spaces between the septa in the Anthozoa.
Lobotes: The type genus of the Lobotidae.
Larvated: Masked; clothed as with a mask.
Latinist: One skilled in Latin; a Latin scholar.
louche: of questionable taste, decency, or morality; not reputable; as, a louche nightclub; a louche painting.
Liquidity: The state or quality of being liquid.
low-emission: producing little emission of atmospheric pollutants; as, a low-emission vehicle.
Leveret: A hare in the first year of its age.
Levite: One of the tribe or family of Levi; a descendant of Levi; esp., one subordinate to the priests (who were of the same tribe) and employed in various duties connected with the tabernacle first, and afterward the temple, such as the care of the building, bringing of wood and other necessaries for the sacrifices, the music of the services, etc.
Lorimer: A maker of bits, spurs, and metal mounting for bridles and saddles; hence, a saddler.
Lividity: The state or quality of being livid.
Levigation: The act or operation of levigating.
Lacunal: Pertaining to, or having, lacunæ; as, a lacunar circulation.
Laconize: To imitate the manner of the Laconians, especially in brief, pithy speech, or in frugality and austerity.
Lacunar: The ceiling or under surface of any part, especially when it consists of compartments, sunk or hollowed without spaces or bands between the panels.
Lauric acid: a white, crystalline substance, CH3.(CH2)10.COOH, resembling palmitic acid, and obtained from the fruit of the bay tree, and various other vegetable sources. The sodium salt (sodium lauryl sulfate) is used as a detergent.
Levity: The quality of weighing less than something else of equal bulk; relative lightness, especially as shown by rising through, or floating upon, a contiguous substance; buoyancy; -- opposed to gravity.
Laurinol: Ordinary camphor; -- so called in allusion to the family name (Lauraceæ) of the camphor trees. See Camphor.
Laminar: In, or consisting of, thin plates or layers; having the form of a thin plate or lamina.
Loading: The act of putting a load on or into.
Lumachel: A grayish brown limestone, containing fossil shells, which reflect a beautiful play of colors. It is also called fire marble, from its fiery reflections.
Loggerhead: A blockhead; a dunce; a numskull.
Lazarist: One of the Congregation of the Priests of the Mission, a religious institute founded by Vincent de Paul in 1624, and popularly called Lazarists or Lazarites from the College of St. Lazare in Paris, which was occupied by them until 1792.
Ladle: To take up and convey in a ladle; to dip with, or as with, a ladle; as, to ladle out soup; to ladle oatmeal into a kettle.
loudspeaker: A device which converts electrical signals into sounds loud enough to be heard at a distance, usually outdoors; it is used to amplify or transmit over a distance speech from a person, who is typically speaking into a microphone.  Sometimes it is used to play recorded speech or music.
Lithium: A metallic element of the alkaline group, occurring in several minerals, as petalite, spodumene, lepidolite, triphylite, etc., and otherwise widely disseminated, though in small quantities.
Launder: To wash, as clothes; to wash, and to smooth with a flatiron or mangle; to wash and iron; as, to launder shirts.
Lymph: A spring of water; hence, water, or a pure, transparent liquid like water.
Lyonnais: a former province of east central France; now administered by Rhone-Alpes.
Ladyhood: The state or quality of being a lady; the personality of a lady.
loved: p. p. of love, v. t..  Opposite of unloved.
lateen: Of or pertaining to a peculiar rig used in the Mediterranean and adjacent waters, esp. on the northern coast of Africa; pertaining to a lateen sail. See below.
low-toned: relatively low in volume; soft; -- of sound; as, making low-toned noises with their mouths that went as an undercurrent of sound.  Opposite of loud.
Lobelia: A genus of plants, including a great number of species. Lobelia inflata, or Indian tobacco, is an annual plant of North America, whose leaves contain a poisonous white viscid juice, of an acrid taste. It has often been used in medicine as an emetic, expectorant, etc.  Lobelia cardinalis is the cardinal flower, remarkable for the deep and vivid red color of its flowers.
Lordship: The state or condition of being a lord; hence (with his or your), a title applied to a lord (except an archbishop or duke, who is called Grace) or a judge (in Great Britain), etc.
Locomotion: The act of moving from place to place.
Lobelin: A yellowish green resin from Lobelia, used as an emetic and diaphoretic.
Line: To mark with a line or lines; to cover with lines; as, to line a copy book.
Leakage: A leaking; also, the quantity that enters or issues by leaking.
Labor Day: In most of the States and Territories of the United States, a day, usually the first Monday of September, set aside as a legal holiday, in honor of, or in the interest of, workingmen as a class. Also, a similar holiday in Canada, Australia, etc.
left-wing: Of or pertaining to the political left or its ideology.
leppy: A motherless calf in a range herd of cattle.
Loftily: In a lofty manner or position; haughtily.
left-slanting: slanting toward the left; -- of handwriting.
Lechery: Free indulgence of lust; excessive indulgence in sexual relations; -- used mostly of men.
laager: A camp, especially one surrounded by a circular formation of travelers' wagons for temporary defense.
Lumberer: One employed in lumbering, cutting, and getting logs from the forest for lumber; a lumberman.
Lageniform: Shaped like a bottle or flask; flag-shaped.
Letts: An Indo-European people, allied to the Lithuanians and Old Prussians, and inhabiting a part of the Baltic provinces of Russia.
Lothringen: Lorraine, a French region rich in iron-ore deposits.
Lintel: A horizontal member spanning an opening, and carrying the superincumbent weight by means of its strength in resisting crosswise fracture.
Lette: To let; to hinder. See Let, to hinder.
Lithogenesy: The doctrine or science of the origin of the minerals composing the globe.
Loris: Any one of several species of small lemurs of the genus Stenops. They have long, slender limbs and large eyes, and are arboreal in their habits. The slender loris (Stenops gracilis), of Ceylon, in one of the best known species.
Limonite: Hydrous sesquioxide of iron, an important ore of iron, occurring in stalactitic, mammillary, or earthy forms, of a dark brown color, and yellowish brown powder. It includes bog iron. Also called brown hematite.
Lepidote: Having a coat of scurfy scales, as the leaves of the oleaster.
Leitmotif: a guiding theme; in Wagnerian opera, a marked melodic phrase or short musical passage which always accompanies the reappearance of a certain person, situation, abstract idea, or allusion in the course of the play; a sort of musical label.  Also called Leading motive.
Lindera: A genus of aromatic evergreen or deciduous dioecious shrubs or trees of eastern Asia and North America.
&Verbar;Landtag: The diet or legislative body; as, the Landtag of Prussia.  See Legislature, below.
Livistona: A genus of fan palms of Asia and Australia and Malaysia.
Luggage: That which is lugged; anything cumbrous and heavy to be carried; especially, a traveler's trunks, baggage, etc., or their contents.
Lithologically: From a lithological point of view; as, to consider a stratum lithologically.
lancetfish: A large, elongated, scaleless, voracious, deep-sea fish (Alepidosaurus ferox), having long, sharp, lancetlike teeth and a long saillike dorsal fin.
Lemna: A genus of minute acquatic herbs floating on or below the water surface of still water consisting of a leaflike frond or plant body and single root.
Ladykin: A little lady; -- applied by the writers of Queen Elizabeth's time, in the abbreviated form Lakin, to the Virgin Mary.
&Verbar;Leucoryx: A large antelope of North Africa (Oryx leucoryx), allied to the gemsbok.
Lath-shaped: Having a slender elongated form, like a lath; -- said of the feldspar of certain igneous rocks, as diabase, as seen in microscopic sections.
&Verbar;Lemuroidea: A suborder of primates, including the lemurs, the aye-aye, and allied species.
Lawyerlike: Like, or becoming, a lawyer; as, lawyerlike sagacity.
Luddite: One of a number of riotous persons in England, who for six years (1811-17) tried to prevent the use of labor-saving machinery by breaking it, burning factories, etc.; -- so called from Ned Lud, a half-witted man who some years previously had broken stocking frames.
Langarey: One of numerous species of long-winged, shrikelike birds of Australia and the East Indies, of the genus Artamus, and allied genera; called also wood swallow.
Lamplighter: One who, or that which, lights a lamp;
Lithotome: A stone so formed by nature as to appear as if cut by art.
Lithotomy: The operation, art, or practice of cutting for stone in the bladder.
lase: To give off a beam of coherent light; -- of a laser.
Loiter: To be slow in moving; to delay; to linger; to be dilatory; to spend time idly; to saunter; to lag behind.
long-term: same as long-run; as, the long-term consequences.
limeade: A sweetened beverage of lime juice and water.
Lady-killing: The art or practice of captivating the hearts of women.
Lactation: The secretion and yielding of milk by the mammary gland; giving suck.
large-scale: large in area, scope or degree; as, a large-scale attack on AIDS is needed.
leporid: A mammal of the family Leporidae, including the rabbits and hares.
&Verbar;Lamellirostres: A group of birds embracing the Anseres and flamingoes, in which the bill is lamellate.
Leuciscus: A genus of freshwater fishes including the dace (Leuciscus leuciscus).
lowan: The Australian moundbird (Leipoa ocellata); it incubates eggs naturally in sandy mounds.
Lounge: An idle gait or stroll; the state of reclining indolently; a place of lounging.
Lactoprotein: A peculiar albuminous body considered a normal constituent of milk.
Lamina: A thin plate or scale; a layer or coat lying over another; -- said of thin plates or platelike substances, as of bone or minerals.
Lagorchestes: A mammal genus comprising the hare wallabies.
Littleness: The state or quality of being little; as, littleness of size, thought, duration, power, etc.
love-token: something given as a token of love.
Lookout: A careful looking or watching for any object or event.
Lancewood: A tough, elastic wood, often used for the shafts of gigs, archery bows, fishing rods, and the like.  Also, the tree which produces this wood, Duguetia Quitarensis (a native of Guiana and Cuba), and several other trees of the same family (Anonaseæ).
left field: the part of the outfield on the catcher's or batter's left.
Lycopodineae: An alternative designation for the class Lycopsida.
Lumbering: The business of cutting or getting timber or logs from the forest for lumber.
Literalness: The quality or state of being literal; literal import.
Lignite: Mineral coal retaining the texture of the wood from which it was formed, and burning with an empyreumatic odor. It is of more recent origin than the anthracite and bituminous coal of the proper coal series. Called also brown coal, wood coal.
Lubber: A heavy, clumsy, or awkward fellow; a sturdy drone; a clown.
Littoral: Of or pertaining to a shore, as of the sea.
Liquid: A substance whose parts change their relative position on the slightest pressure, and therefore retain no definite form; any substance in the state of liquidity; a fluid that is not gaseous and has a definite volume independent, of the container in which it is held. Liquids have a fixed volume at any given pressure, but their shape is determined by the container in which it is contained.  Liquids, in contrast to gases, cannot expand indefinitely to fill an expanding container, and are only slightly compressible by application of pressure.
liven: to make lively; -- sometimes used with up; as, to liven up the party with some music.
Lapse: To let slip; to permit to devolve on another; to allow to pass.
Larch: A genus of coniferous trees, having deciduous leaves, in fascicles (see Illust. of Fascicle).
Lightsome: Having light; lighted; not dark or gloomy; bright.
left-winger: a person who belongs to the political left.
Letterer: One who makes, inscribes, or engraves, alphabetical letters.
Lowery: Cloudy; gloomy; lowering; as, a lowery sky; lowery weather.
Lunation: The period of a synodic revolution of the moon, or the time from one new moon to the next; varying in length, at different times, from about 291/4 to 295/6 days, the average length being 29 d., 12h., 44m., 2.9s.
landholding: ownership of land; the state or fact of owning land.
Lenticular: Resembling a lentil in size or form; having the form of a double-convex lens.
Lobotidae: A natural family of fishes including the tripletails.
Ladleful: A quantity sufficient to fill a ladle.
lactose intolerance: A physiological condition in which lactose cannot be hydrolyzed in the intestine, leading to uncomfortable gaseousness, cramps, or diarrhea after eating a lactose-containing food such as milk or ice cream.  The symptoms may be prevented by ingesting a preparation of beta-galactosidase before or together with dairy products.
Lenity: The state or quality of being lenient; mildness of temper or disposition; gentleness of treatment; softness; tenderness; clemency; -- opposed to severity and rigor.
Lupulin: A bitter principle extracted from hops.
Logged: Made slow and heavy in movement; water-logged.
Little-ease: An old slang name for the pillory, stocks, etc., of a prison.
Loimic: Of or pertaining to the plague or contagious disorders.
Logger: One engaged in logging. See Log, v. i.
letter bomb: A bomb disguised as a letter and sent through the mail, usually rigged to explode and kill or harm the recipient when opened.
Londoner: A native or inhabitant of London.
Lacturamic: Pertaining to, or designating, an organic amido acid, which is regarded as a derivative of lactic acid and urea.
Luke: Moderately warm; not hot; tepid; lukewarm.
Lengthiness: The state or quality of being lengthy; prolixity.
Life-saving: That saves life, or is suited to save life, esp. from drowning; as, the life-saving service; a life-saving station.
Lyriferous: Having a lyre-shaped shoulder girdle, as certain fishes.
Losingly: In a manner to incur loss.
&Verbar;Lampyris: A genus of coleopterous insects, including the glowworms.
Lampate: A supposed salt of lampic acid.
Loweringly: In a lowering manner; with cloudiness or threatening gloom.
Lean-witted: Having but little sense or shrewdness.
Laminiplantar: Having the tarsus covered behind with a horny sheath continuous on both sides, as in most singing birds, except the larks.
Liner: One who lines, as, a liner of shoes or clothing.
lxx: the Roman numeral representation of seventy; seven times ten; -- a determinate quantifier.
Lionced: Adorned with lions' heads; having arms terminating in lions' heads; -- said of a cross.
Lactyl: An organic residue or radical (CH3.CHOH.CO-) derived from lactic acid.
Lightness: Illumination, or degree of illumination; as, the lightness of a room.
Lilied: Covered with, or having many, lilies.
Linkwork: A fabric consisting of links made of metal or other material fastened together; also, a chain.
Laughter: A movement (usually involuntary) of the muscles of the face, particularly of the lips, with a peculiar expression of the eyes, indicating merriment, satisfaction, or derision, and usually attended by a sonorous and interrupted expulsion of air from the lungs. See Laugh, v. i.
Limited: Confined within limits; narrow; circumscribed; restricted; as, our views of nature are very limited.
Lasher: A piece of rope for binding or making fast one thing to another; -- called also lashing.
Lozenge: A diamond-shaped figure usually with the upper and lower angles slightly acute, borne upon a shield or escutcheon.  Cf. Fusil.
leatherjacket: any of several brightly colored tropical filefishes.
Luxullianite: A kind of granite from Luxullian, Cornwall, characterized by the presence of radiating groups of minute tourmaline crystals.
Let-off: A device for letting off, releasing, or giving forth, as the warp from the cylinder of a loom.
Laciniolate: Consisting of, or abounding in, very minute laciniæ.
Limiter: One who, or that which, limits.
Liberalism: Liberal principles; the principles and methods of the liberals in politics or religion; specifically, the principles of the Liberal party.
Lottery: A scheme for the distribution of prizes by lot or chance; esp., a gaming scheme in which one or more tickets bearing particular numbers draw prizes, and the rest of the tickets are blanks.
&Verbar;Lophosteon: The central keel-bearing part of the sternum in birds.
Lapidification: The act or process of lapidifying; fossilization; petrifaction.
Lampless: Being without a lamp, or without light; hence, being without appreciation; dull.
Llandeilo group: A series of strata in the lower Silurian formations of Great Britain; -- so named from Llandeilo in Southern Wales. See Chart of Geology.
Laryngeal: Of or pertaining to the larynx; adapted to operations on the larynx; as, laryngeal forceps.
Lyre: A stringed instrument of music; a kind of harp much used by the ancients, as an accompaniment to poetry.
Labor: To work at; to work; to till; to cultivate by toil.
Lionship: The state of being a lion.
loaner: someone who lends money or gives credit in business matters.
Limousine: an elongated, luxurious automobile, designed to be driven by a chauffeur and often having a glass partition between the driver's seat and the passengers' compartment behind.
&Verbar;Lupercalia: A feast of the Romans in honor of Lupercus, or Pan.
&Verbar;Liard: A French copper coin of one fourth the value of a sou.
Lictor: An officer who bore an ax and fasces or rods, as ensigns of his office. His duty was to attend the chief magistrates when they appeared in public, to clear the way, and cause due respect to be paid to them, also to apprehend and punish criminals.
Litigious: Inclined to initiate lawsuits; given to the practice of contending in law; fond of litigation.
latinate: derived from or imitative of Latin.
Lofty: Lifted high up; having great height; towering; high.
Lass: A young woman; a girl; a sweetheart.
Last: A load; a heavy burden; hence, a certain weight or measure, generally estimated at 4,000 lbs., but varying for different articles and in different countries. In England, a last of codfish, white herrings, meal, or ashes, is twelve barrels; a last of corn, ten quarters, or eighty bushels, in some parts of England, twenty-one quarters; of gunpowder, twenty-four barrels, each containing 100 lbs; of red herrings, twenty cades, or 20,000; of hides, twelve dozen; of leather, twenty dickers; of pitch and tar, fourteen barrels; of wool, twelve sacks; of flax or feathers, 1,700 lbs.
Leveling: The act or operation of making level.
long-acting: active over a relatively long period of time.
Liverwort: A ranunculaceous plant (Anemone Hepatica) with pretty white or bluish flowers and a three-lobed leaf; -- called also squirrel cups.
Latitudinal: Of or pertaining to latitude; in the direction of latitude.
lavaliere: A neck ornament consisting of a chain and single jewelled pendant, or drop; also, the pendant itself.
Lantanuric: Pertaining to, or designating, a nitrogenous organic acid of the uric acid group, obtained by the decomposition of allantoin, and usually called allanturic acid.
lock-gate: a gate that can be locked.
Lachrymary: Containing, or intended to contain, tears; lachrymal.
Lash: To bind with a rope, cord, thong, or chain, so as to fasten; as, to lash something to a spar; to lash a pack on a horse's back.
L\u00e6vigate: Having a smooth surface, as if polished.
Latin America: That part of the American continents that speak Spanish, Portuguese, or French; the part of the American continents south of the United States.
Lettering: The act or business of making, or marking with, letters, as by cutting or painting.
Lunacy: Insanity or madness; properly, the kind of insanity which is broken by intervals of reason, -- formerly supposed to be influenced by the changes of the moon; any form of unsoundness of mind, except idiocy; mental derangement or alienation.
Lixiviate: To subject to a washing process for the purpose of separating soluble material from that which is insoluble; to leach, as ashes, for the purpose of extracting the alkaline substances.
Links: A tract of ground laid out for the game of golf; a golfing green.
&Verbar;Lordosis: A curvature of the spine forwards, usually in the lumbar region.
lemmatization: The act or process of lemmatizing; conversion into a lemma{2}.
Labidometer: A forceps with a measuring attachment for ascertaining the size of the fetal head.
Learning: The acquisition of knowledge or skill; as, the learning of languages; the learning of telegraphy.
&Verbar;Lyra: A northern constellation, the Harp, containing a white star of the first magnitude, called Alpha Lyræ, or Vega.
Languageless: Lacking or wanting language; speechless; silent.
Laudable: Worthy of being lauded; praiseworthy; commendable; as, laudable motives; laudable actions; laudable ambition.
Legging: a. & vb. n., from Leg, v. t.
Labial: A letter or character representing an articulation or sound formed or uttered chiefly with the lips, as b, p, w.
low-class: Occupying the lowest socioeconomic position in a society.  Contrasted with middle-class and upper-class.
Luganda: the language of the Buganda; spoken in Uganda.
Lobby: To urge the adoption or passage of by soliciting members of a legislative body; as, to lobby a bill; -- also used with the legislators as object; as, to lobby the state legislatuire for protection.
Luminescent: Shining with a light due to any of the various causes which produce luminescence.
Larder: A room or place where meat and other articles of food are kept before they are cooked.
Lampyrine: An insect of the genus Lampyris, or family Lampyridæ. See Lampyris.
Ligation: The act of binding, or the state of being bound.
Lyddite: A high explosive consisting principally of picric acid, used as a shell explosive in the British service; -- so named from the proving grounds at Lydd, England.
Lithagogue: A medicine having, or supposed to have, the power of expelling calculous matter with the urine.
Lollardism: The doctrines or principles of the Lollards.
Lameness: The condition or quality of being lame; as, the lameness of an excuse or an argument.
lemanderin: A fruit tree (Citrus limonia) which is a hybrid between the mandarin orange and the lemon, having a very acid fruit with an orange peel; also, the fruit of this tree, the rangpur.
Lombardic: Of or pertaining to Lombardy of the Lombards.
Long-suffering: disposed to bear inconvenience or injury patiently; long patience of offense; as, a long-suffering and uncomplaining wife.
ladder-backed: Having horizontal stripes on the back, reminiscent of a ladder; -- used of birds; as, a ladder-backed woodpecker.
Lawsuit: An action at law; a suit in equity or admiralty; any legal proceeding before a court for the enforcement of a claim.
Lousewort: Any species of Pedicularis, a genus of perennial herbs. It was said to make sheep that fed on it lousy.
Lool: A vessel used to receive the washings of ores of metals.
Look: The act of looking; a glance; a sight; a view; -- often in certain phrases; as, to have, get, take, throw, or cast, a look.
Lancasterian: Of or pertaining to the monitorial system of instruction followed by Joseph Lancaster, of England, in which advanced pupils in a school teach pupils below them.
Loob: The clay or slimes washed from tin ore in dressing.
Lunette: A fieldwork consisting of two faces, forming a salient angle, and two parallel flanks. See Bastion.
Lock washer: A washer that is not completely smooth or flat, designed to prevent a nut from loosening, placed under the nut on a screw or bolt.
Lenticularly: In the manner of a lens; with a curve.
&Verbar;Lanseh: The small, yellow to whitish brown berrylike fruit of an East Indian tree (Lansium domesticum).  It has a fleshy pulp, with an agreeable tart subacid taste.
Lampas: An inflammation and swelling of the soft parts of the roof of the mouth immediately behind the fore teeth in the horse; -- called also lampers.
Lighterman: A person employed on, or who manages, a lighter.
Loop: To make a loop of or in; to fasten with a loop or loops; -- often with up; as, to loop a string; to loop up a curtain.
&Verbar;Lobosa: An order of Rhizopoda, in which the pseudopodia are thick and irregular in form, as in the Amœba.
Long-stop: One who is set to stop balls which pass the wicket keeper.
Limekiln: A kiln or furnace in which limestone or shells are burned and reduced to lime.
Lychnoscope: Same as Low side window, under Low, a.
Lion: A large carnivorous feline mammal (Panthera leo, formerly Felis leo), found in Southern Asia and in most parts of Africa, distinct varieties occurring in the different countries. The adult male, in most varieties, has a thick mane of long shaggy hair that adds to his apparent size, which is less than that of the largest tigers. The length, however, is sometimes eleven feet to the base of the tail. The color is a tawny yellow or yellowish brown; the mane is darker, and the terminal tuft of the tail is black. In one variety, called the maneless lion, the male has only a slight mane.
Lambert pine: The gigantic sugar pine of California and Oregon (Pinus Lambertiana). It has the leaves in fives, and cones a foot long. The timber is soft, and like that of the white pine of the Eastern States.
Lager wine: Wine which has been kept for some time in the cellar.
Lectern: A choir desk, or reading desk, in some churches, from which the lections, or Scripture lessons, are chanted or read.
low-tech: not involving high technology; using long-established technology.  Opposite of high-tech.
Lobbyist: A member of the lobby; a person who solicits members of a legislature for the purpose of influencing legislation.
Lynx: Any one of several species of feline animals of the genus Felis, and subgenus Lynx. They have a short tail, and usually a pencil of hair on the tip of the ears.
Longimetry: The art or practice of measuring distances or lengths.
&Verbar;Lyopomata: An order of brachiopods, in which the valves of shell are not articulated by a hinge.  It includes the Lingula, Discina, and allied forms.
&Verbar;Landsturm: A general levy in time of war.
Leze majesty: Any crime committed against the sovereign power.
Lugworm: A large marine annelid (Arenicola marina) having a row of tufted gills along each side of the back.  It is found burrowing in sandy beaches, both in America and Europe, and is used for bait by European fishermen.  Called also lobworm, and baitworm.
Loyalty: The state or quality of being loyal; fidelity to a superior, or to duty, love, etc.
&Verbar;Lupus: originally, a cutaneous disease with the appearance of the skin having been gnawed, and occurring under two distinct forms.  Now used as a generic term for over ten distinguishable diseases having visible cutaneous symptoms.
Laced\u00e6monian: Of or pertaining to Lacedæmon or Sparta, the chief city of Laconia in the Peloponnesus.
Lowlily: In a lowly place or manner; humbly.
Literalism: That which accords with the letter; a mode of interpreting literally; adherence to the letter.
Legumin: An albuminous substance resembling casein, found as a characteristic ingredient of the seeds of leguminous and grain-bearing plants.
Lao-tse: A Chinese philosopher who founded Taoism in the 6th-century b.c.
Lubricator: One who, or that which, lubricates.
Lithodomous: Like, or pertaining to, Lithodomus; lithophagous.
Licker: One who, or that which, licks.
Lambrequin: A kind of pendent scarf or covering attached to the helmet, to protect it from wet or heat.
Letterwood: The beautiful and highly elastic wood of a tree of the genus Brosimum (Brosimum Aubletii), found in Guiana; -- so called from black spots in it which bear some resemblance to hieroglyphics; also called snakewood, and leopardwood. It is much used for bows and for walking sticks.
Lappic: Of or pertaining to Lapland, or the Lapps.
law-makers: Those persons who make or amend or repeal laws, collectively.
A term attached to the name of a company that is organized to give its owners limited liability; it corresponds to Inc. in the United States.
Lorate: Having the form of a thong or strap; ligulate.
Lacewing: Any one of several species of neuropterous insects of the genus Chrysopa and allied genera. They have delicate, lacelike wings and brilliant eyes. Their larvæ are useful in destroying aphids. Called also lace-winged fly, and goldeneyed fly.
Lovelock: A long lock of hair hanging prominently by itself; an earlock; -- worn by men of fashion in the reigns of Elizabeth and James I.
Load: To lay a load or burden on or in, as on a horse or in a cart; to charge with a load, as a gun; to furnish with a lading or cargo, as a ship; hence, to add weight to, so as to oppress or embarrass; to heap upon.
Loaf: To spend in idleness; -- with away; as, to loaf time away.
Laramie group: An extensive series of strata, principally developed in the Rocky Mountain region, as in the Laramie Mountains, and formerly supposed to be of the Tertiary age, but now generally regarded as Cretaceous, or of intermediate and transitional character. It contains beds of lignite, often valuable for coal, and is hence also called the lignitic group. See Chart of Geology.
Lilac: A shrub of the genus Syringa. There are six species, natives of Europe and Asia.  Syringa vulgaris, the common lilac, and Syringa Persica, the Persian lilac, are frequently cultivated for the fragrance and beauty of their purplish or white flowers. In the British colonies various other shrubs have this name.
Lithology: The science which treats of rocks, as regards their mineral constitution and classification, and their mode of occurrence in nature.
Luxuriation: The act or process of luxuriating.
Lepus: The type genus of the Leporidae, comprising the hares.
Lynch: To inflict punishment upon, especially death, without the forms of law, as when a mob captures and hangs a suspected person. See Lynch law.
levelheaded: exercising or showing good judgment or common sense; sensible.
Legitimately: In a legitimate manner; lawfully; genuinely.
Livelode: Course of life; means of support; livelihood.
Lane: A passageway between fences or hedges which is not traveled as a highroad; an alley between buildings; a narrow way among trees, rocks, and other natural obstructions; hence, in a general sense, a narrow passageway; as, a lane between lines of men, or through a field of ice.
LTM: long-term memory, the term for the set of neurons and neural processes responsible for the general store of information remembered for more than a day.
Lecture: To deliver a lecture or lectures.
lead to: Same as cause; as, the roaring stock market led to an increase in the purchase of big-ticket items during the 1996 Christmas season.
Laundryman: A man who follows the business of laundering.
Liberality: The quality or state of being liberal; liberal disposition or practice; freedom from narrowness or prejudice; generosity; candor; charity.
lap up: To take up (drink or food) with the tongue; to drink by licking up.
low-polluting: producing little pollution, especially air pollution; as, a low-polluting electric car.
Lipans: A tribe of North American Indians, inhabiting the northern part of Mexico. They belong to the Tinneh stock, and are closely related to the Apaches.
Leiotrichan: Of or pertaining to the Leiotrichi.
linkup: something that serves to join or link.
lockbox: A box of strong and durable construction, fitted with a lock, used for the purpose of protecting valuable items, such as money or jewelry; a strongbox.
Lunged: Having lungs, or breathing organs similar to lungs.
Lames: Small steel plates combined together so as to slide one upon the other and form a piece of armor.
Ling-bird: The European meadow pipit; -- called also titling.
Loadmanage: Pilotage; skill of a pilot or loadsman.
long-lasting: Existing or persisting for a long time; as, a long-lasting friendship.
Latchet: The string that fastens a shoe; a shoestring.
Luxuriancy: The state or quality of being luxuriant; luxuriance.
Latitudinarian: One who is moderate in his notions, or not restrained by precise settled limits in opinion; one who indulges freedom in thinking.
Luciferin: any of several substances found in luminescent organisms (such as the firefly, Photinus pyralis) which, when oxidized, produces an almost heatless light.  It was first isolated from fireflies, and is the source of the firefly luminescence.  See also firefly luciferin
Luxemburger: of or pertaining to Luxemburg; as, Luxemburger streets.
Lutarious: Of, pertaining to, or like, mud; living in mud.
Lineally: In a lineal manner; as, the prince is lineally descended from the Conqueror.
Lackey: To act or serve as lackey; to pay servile attendance.
Limestone: A rock consisting chiefly of calcium carbonate or carbonate of lime. It sometimes contains also magnesium carbonate, and is then called magnesian or dolomitic limestone. Crystalline limestone is called marble.
Liturgics: The science of worship; history, doctrine, and interpretation of liturgies.
levodopa: A substance used as a therapy for Parkinson's Disease; the L form of Dopa; L-dihydroxyphenylalanine; L-hydroxytyrosine (C9H11NO4); also called L-dopa.  In the body it is converted by the enzyme dopa-decarboxylase into dopamine, the form in which it is active in the brain, affecting neural impulse transmission.
look-over: a swift cursory examination or inspection; as, I gave the car a quick look-over.
Lampadrome: A race run by young men with lighted torches in their hands.  He who reached the goal first, with his torch unextinguished, gained the prize.
Liberalization: The act of liberalizing; the act of making less strict.
Lachrymose: Generating or shedding tears; given to shedding tears; suffused with tears; tearful.
&Verbar;Lucernarida: A division of acalephs, including Lucernaria and allied genera; -- called also Calycozoa.
Liver-colored: Having a color like liver; dark reddish brown.
Liquidness: The quality or state of being liquid; liquidity; fluency.
Light-foot: Having a light, springy step; moving lightly and nimbly; nimble in running or dancing; active; as, light-foot Iris.  Opposite of heavy-footed.
Lozenged: Having the form of a lozenge or rhomb.
Lunaria: A small genus of European herbs of the mustard family, including the herb honesty (Lunaria annua), which is also called moonwort and lunary.
Lattice: To make a lattice of; as, to lattice timbers.
Levation: The act of raising; elevation; upward motion, as that produced by the action of a levator muscle.
Lycopodiaceous: Belonging, or relating, to the Lycopodiaceæ, an order of cryptogamous plants (called also club mosses) with branching stems, and small, crowded, one-nerved, and usually pointed leaves.
Lark: To catch larks; as, to go larking.
Lari: A suborder of birds including the gulls; terns; jaegers; and skimmers.
Like-minded: Having a like disposition or purpose; of the same mind.
Lamellicorn: Having antennæ terminating in a group of flat lamellæ; -- said of certain coleopterous insects.
Lofter: An iron club with a sloped face, used in lofting the ball; -- called also lofting iron.
Lettic: Of or pertaining to the Letts; Lettish.
Lucky: Favored by luck; fortunate; meeting with good success or good fortune; -- said of persons; as, a lucky adventurer.
Lift: Act of lifting; also, that which is lifted.
&Verbar;Landwehr: That part of the army, in Germany and Austria, which has completed the usual military service and is exempt from duty in time of peace, except that it is called out occasionally for drill.
Luctation: Effort to overcome in contest; struggle; endeavor.
Lupulinic: Pertaining to, or obtained from, hops; specifically, designating an acid obtained by the decomposition of lupulin.
longbeard: a fat-bellied stoneware drinking jug with a long neck; decorated with a caricature of Cardinal Bellarmine (17th century).
Loevens larva: The peculiar larva of Polygordius. See Polygordius.
Lastreopsis: A genus of tropical terrestrial shield ferns.
Ligator: An instrument for ligating, or for placing and fastening a ligature.
Luxuriance: The state or quality of being luxuriant; rank, vigorous growth; excessive abundance produced by rank growth.
Lamasery: A monastery or convent of lamas, in Tibet, Mongolia, etc.
Laveer: To beat against the wind; to tack.
Loll: To let hang from the mouth, as the tongue.
LAN: A local area network; a network{3} connecting computers and word processors and other electronic office equipment within a small area, to create an inter-office system, typically within one building or one site of a corporation.  Contrasted to WAN, a wide-area network.
Literator: One who teaches the letters or elements of knowledge; a petty schoolmaster.
Lobately: As a lobe; so as to make a lobe; in a lobate manner.
Lambdacism: A fault in speaking or in composition, which consists in too frequent use of the letter l, or in doubling it erroneously.
Luteolin: A yellow dyestuff obtained from the foliage of the dyer's broom (Reseda luteola).
Loveless: Void of love; void of tenderness or kindness.
Lamellose: Composed of, or having, lamellæ; lamelliform.
Lowborn: Born in a low condition or rank; -- opposed to highborn.
Lankiness: The condition or quality or being lanky.
Libertarian: One who holds to the doctrine of free will.
Limicoline: Shore-inhabiting; of or pertaining to the Limicolæ.
Lucchese: A native or inhabitant of Lucca, in Tuscany; in the plural, the people of Lucca.
Larine: Of or pertaining to the Gull family (Laridæ).
Lady: Belonging or becoming to a lady; ladylike.
Lone: Being without a companion; being by one's self; also, sad from lack of companionship; lonely; as, a lone traveler or watcher.
Long: To feel a strong or morbid desire or craving; to wish for something with eagerness; -- followed by an infinitive, or by for or after.
low-resolution: producing images that are not sharply defined; -- of optical instruments or image display devices.  Opposite of high-resolution.
-ling: An adverbial suffix; as, darkling, flatling.
Ladylike: Like a lady in appearance or manners; well-bred.
Lonely: Sequestered from company or neighbors; solitary; retired; as, a lonely situation; a lonely cell.
Latinly: In the manner of the Latin language; in correct Latin.
Laystall: A place where rubbish, dung, etc., are laid or deposited.
-let: A noun suffix having a diminutive force; as in streamlet, wavelet, armlet.
Loculicidal: Dehiscent through the middle of the back of each cell; -- said of capsules.
Legerdemainist: One who practices sleight of hand; a prestidigitator.
Let-up: Abatement; also, cessation; as, it blew a gale for three days without any let-up.
Lenience: The quality or state of being lenient; lenity; clemency.
life-size: Of full size; of the natural size; of the same size as an original; as, a life-size sculpture; a life-size portrait of the general.
Looseness: The state, condition, or quality, of being loose; as, the looseness of a cord; looseness of style; looseness of morals or of principles.
Levulose: A sirupy variety of sugar, rarely obtained crystallized, occurring widely in honey, ripe fruits, etc., and hence called also fruit sugar; also called fructose.  Chemical formula: C6H12O6.  It is called levulose, because it rotates the plane of polarization of light to the left, in contrast to dextrose, the other product of the hydrolysis of sucrose.
Levogyrate: Turning or twisting the plane of polarization of light towards the left, as levulose, levotartaric acid, etc.; levorotatory.
Light: To dismount; to descend, as from a horse or carriage; to alight; -- with from, off, on, upon, at, in.
Lowlander: A native or inhabitant of the Lowlands, especially of the Lowlands of Scotland, as distinguished from Highlander.
Legume: A pod dehiscent into two pieces or valves, and having the seed attached at one suture, as that of the pea.
Locker: One who, or that which, locks.
Laparotomy: A cutting through the walls of the abdomen, as in the Cæsarean section.
Lucubration: The act of lucubrating, or studying by candlelight; nocturnal study; meditation.
Lording: The son of a lord; a person of noble lineage.
Lying: of Lie, to be supported horizontally.
Lumberman: One who is engaged in lumbering as a business or employment.
Long-lived: Having a long life; having constitutional peculiarities which make long life probable; lasting long; as, a long-lived tree; they are a long-lived family; long-lived prejudices.
Likewise: In like manner; also; moreover; too. See Also.
Lamellibranchiate: Having lamellar gills; belonging to the Lamellibranchia (also called Pelecypoda).
Logwood: The heartwood of a tree (Hæmatoxylon Campechianum), a native of South America, It is a red, heavy wood, containing a crystalline substance called hæmatoxylin, and is used largely in dyeing. An extract from this wood is used in medicine as an astringent. Also called Campeachy wood, and bloodwood.
Lovable: Having qualities that excite, or are fitted to excite, love; worthy of love.
Lying-in: The state attending, and consequent to, childbirth; confinement; as, a lying-in hospital.
Limonin: A bitter, white, crystalline substance found in orange and lemon seeds.
Locative: Indicating place, or the place where, or wherein; as, a locative adjective; locative case of a noun.
lilyturf: Asiatic perennial tufted herb (Liriope muscari) with grasslike evergreen foliage and clusters of dark mauve grapelike flowers; grown as ground cover.
looted: wrongfully emptied or stripped of anything of value; as, the robbers left the looted train.
Lilly-pilly: An Australian myrtaceous tree (Eugenia Smithii), having smooth ovate leaves, and panicles of small white flowers. The wood is hard and fine-grained.
Lacert: A muscle of the human body.
Lizards tail: A perennial plant of the genus Saururus (Saururus cernuus), growing in marshes, and having white flowers crowded in a slender terminal spike, somewhat resembling in form a lizard's tail; whence the name.
Lingua Franca: The commercial language of the Levant, -- a mixture of the languages of the people of the region and of foreign traders.
Leading: The act of guiding, directing, governing, or enticing; guidance.
Liliaceous: Of or pertaining to a natural order of which the lily, tulip, and hyacinth are well-known examples.
lime: having a yellowish-green color like that of the lime (the fruit).
Lend: To allow the custody and use of, on condition of the return of the same; to grant the temporary use of; as, to lend a book; -- opposed to borrow.
&Verbar;Liber: The inner bark of plants, lying next to the wood. It usually contains a large proportion of woody, fibrous cells, and is, therefore, the part from which the fiber of the plant is obtained, as that of hemp, etc.
Latterkin: A pointed wooden tool used in glazing leaden lattice.
Leno: A light open cotton fabric used for window curtains.
Lens: A piece of glass, or other transparent substance, ground with two opposite regular surfaces, either both curved, or one curved and the other plane, and commonly used, either singly or combined, in optical instruments, for changing the direction of rays of light, and thus magnifying objects, or otherwise modifying vision. In practice, the curved surfaces are usually spherical, though rarely cylindrical, or of some other figure.
Lackaday: Alack the day; alas; -- an expression of sorrow, regret, dissatisfaction, or surprise.
Laridae: The natural family of birds including the gulls and terns; the gull family.
Lactometer: An instrument for estimating the purity or richness of milk, as a measuring glass, a specific gravity bulb, or other apparatus.
Lent: Slow; mild; gentle; as, lenter heats.
Loftiness: The state or quality of being lofty.
Land: To come to the end of a course; to arrive at a destination, literally or figuratively; as, he landed in trouble; after hithchiking for a week, he landed in Los Angeles.
Lavement: A washing or bathing; also, an enema.
Lithocyst: A sac containing small, calcareous concretions (otoliths). They are found in many Medusæ, and other invertebrates, and are supposed to be auditory organs.
Leachy: Permitting liquids to pass by percolation; not capable of retaining water; porous; pervious; -- said of gravelly or sandy soils, and the like.
Lank: To become lank; to make lank.
Levanter: A strong easterly wind peculiar to the Mediterranean.
lateen sail: A triangular sail, extended by a long yard, which is slung at about one fourth of its length from the lower end, to a low mast, this end being brought down at the tack, while the other end is elevated at an angle or about forty-five degrees; -- used in small boats, feluccas, xebecs, etc., especially in the Mediterranean and adjacent waters. Some lateen sails have also a boom on the lower side.
Lherzolite: An igneous rock consisting largely of chrysolite, with pyroxene and picotite (a variety of spinel containing chromium).
labourer: a laborer; someone who works with their hands.
lachrymatory: Relating to or inducing tears; -- especially of chemical substances.
Leg bridge: A type of bridge for small spans in which  the floor girders are rigidly secured at their extremities to supporting steel legs, driven into the ground as piling, or resting on mudsills.
Laureled: Crowned with laurel, or with a laurel wreath; laureate.
Linoxin: A resinous substance obtained as an oxidation product of linoleic acid.
Liberation: The act of liberating or the state of being liberated.
Lusitanian: Pertaining to Lusitania, the ancient name of the region almost coinciding with Portugal.
Leviable: Fit to be levied; capable of being assessed and collected; as, sums leviable by course of law.
Library: A considerable collection of books kept for use, and not as merchandise; as, a private library; a public library.
Ludlamite: A mineral occurring in small, green, transparent, monoclinic crystals. It is a hydrous phosphate of iron.
Lugger: An Indian falcon (Falco jugger), similar to the European lanner and the American prairie falcon.
Leeboard: A board, or frame of planks, lowered over the side of a vessel to lessen her leeway when closehauled, by giving her greater draught.
Literalization: The act of literalizing; reduction to a literal meaning.
Lipothymous: Pertaining, or given, to swooning; fainting.
lower-class: same as low-class.  Contrasted with middle-class and upper-class.
lacebark: A small tree or shrub (Hoheria populnea) of New Zealand having a profusion of axillary clusters of honey-scented paper-white flowers and whose bark is used for cordage.
Lactim: One of a series of anhydrides resembling the lactams, but of an imido type; as, isatine is a lactim.  Cf. Lactam.
&Verbar;Larghetto: Somewhat slow or slowly, but not so slowly as largo, and rather more so than andante.
Lapidescent: Any substance which has the quality of petrifying other bodies, or of converting or being converted into stone.
Lactic: Of or pertaining to milk; procured from sour milk or whey; as, lactic acid; lactic fermentation, etc.
Lowland: Land which is low with respect to the neighboring country; a low or level country; -- opposed to highland.
loop-line: a railway line that branches from the trunk line and then rejoins it at another point.
Lioncel: A small lion, especially one of several borne in the same coat of arms.
&Verbar;Lim n\u00e6a: A genus of fresh-water air-breathing mollusks, abundant in ponds and streams; -- called also pond snail.
Longevity: Long duration of life; length of life.
Lovely: In a manner to please, or to excite love.
Lithate: A salt of lithic or uric acid; a urate.
Lowing: The calling sound made by cows and other bovine animals.
Lamellary: Of or pertaining to lamella or to lamellæ; lamellar.
lycaenid: any of various butterflies of the family Lycaenidae.
lepton: an elementary particle that participates in weak interactions but does not participate in the strong interaction; it has a baryon number of 0.  Some known leptons are the electron, the negative muon, the tau-minus particle, and the neutrinos associated with each of these particles.
located: situated in a particular spot or position; as, valuable centrally located urban land.
Ludificatory: Making sport; tending to excite derision.
Landamman: A chief magistrate in some of the Swiss cantons.
Lithophosphor: A stone that becomes phosphoric by heat.
luge: a racing sled for one or two people; it is raced down a chute of packed snow or ice, and the occupant(s) lie down on it with feet in the direction of motion.
Lionel: The whelp of a lioness; a young lion.
Lapful: As much as the lap can contain.
lanternfly: any one of several species of large, handsome, brightly marked, tropical hemipterous insects of the genera Laternaria, Fulgora, and allies, of the family Fulgoridæ. The largest species is Laternaria phosphorea of Brazil. The head has a snoutlike process in some species which was formerly thought to emit a phosphorescent light.
Lout: To treat as a lout or fool; to neglect; to disappoint.
ligase: An enzyme which catalyzes creation of a covalent bond between two substrates, resulting in a larger product which is a combination of the two starting materials;  especially, DNA ligase, an enzyme which creates a phosphate bond between 5′ and 3′ ends of a DNA chain, resulting in a longer chain of DNA.  DNA ligase is important in normal biosynthesis of DNA in the replication cycle of cells.
Lessen: To become less; to shrink; to contract; to decrease; to be diminished; as, the apparent magnitude of objects lessens as we recede from them; his care, or his wealth, lessened.
Latakia: A superior quality of Turkish smoking tobacco, so called from the place where produced, the ancient Laodicea.
L\u00e6modipodous: Of or pertaining to the Læmodipoda.
Lesses: The leavings or dung of beasts.
litmus test: A test to determine acidity or alkalinity, using litmus as an inddicator.
Lubricant: That which lubricates; specifically, a substance, as oil, grease, graphite, etc., used for reducing the friction of the working parts of machinery.
lindane: A chemical substance (C6H6Cl6) used as an agricultural insecticide.
Laity: The people, as distinguished from the clergy; the body of the people not in orders.
Ladys bower: A climbing plant with fragrant blossoms (Clematis vitalba).
leadplant: A shrub (Amorpha canescens) of sandy woodlands and streambanks of the Western U. S. having hoary pinnate flowers and dull-colored racemose flowers; it is thought to indicate the presence of lead ore.
live-bearer: Any fish of the family Poeciliiidae, small usually brightly-colored viviparous surface-feeding fishes of fresh or brackish warm waters, often used in mosquito control.
Laugh: An expression of mirth peculiar to the human species; the sound heard in laughing; laughter. See Laugh, v. i.
lined: furnished with items in a line or as if in a line.
Leetman: One subject to the jurisdiction of a court-leet.
&Verbar;Liriodendron: A genus of large and very beautiful trees of North America, having smooth, shining leaves, and handsome, tuliplike flowers; tulip tree; whitewood; -- called also canoewood. Liriodendron tulipifera is the only extant species, but there were several others in the Cretaceous epoch.
Light-heeled: Lively in walking or running; brisk; light-footed.
Liminess: The state or quality of being limy.
lossy compression: The compression of binary data into a form which, when it is re-expanded, has most, but not all, of the original information.  It is used primarily for compression of images and sounds, and is designed to provide a high degree of compression at the cost of a slight loss of data.  It is expemplified by the JPEG compression standard.  Images compressed by a lossy compression algorithm are re-expanded into an image close, but not identical to the original image; the difference between the original and the reconstructed image may be imperceptible to normal viewing by the eye.
Limbed: Having limbs; -- much used in composition; as, large-limbed; short-limbed.
&Verbar;Laxator: That which loosens; -- esp., a muscle which by its contraction loosens some part.
Loot: To plunder; to carry off as plunder or a prize lawfully obtained by war.
Lazaret: A public building, hospital, or pesthouse for the reception of diseased persons, particularly those affected with contagious diseases.
lepidopteran: An insect that in the adult state has four wings more or less covered with tiny scales; a lepidopterous insect.
liebfraumilch: A white Rhenish-type wine produced especially in Hesse in western Germany.
Laburnic: Of, pertaining to, or derived from, the laburnum.
Lattermath: The latter, or second, mowing; the aftermath.
Livid: Black and blue; grayish blue; of a lead color; discolored, as flesh may be from a contusion.
Luvarus: The type genus of the Luvaridae.
Liberian: A native or inhabitant of Liberia.
Lollard: One of a sect of early reformers in Germany.
Lenitude: The quality or habit of being lenient; lenity.
Livonian: A native or an inhabitant of Livonia; the language (allied to the Finnish) of the Livonians.
Linearensate: Having the form of a sword, but very long and narrow.
Laserwort: Any plant of the umbelliferous genus Laserpitium, of several species (as Laserpitium glabrum, and Laserpitium siler), the root of which yields a resinous substance of a bitter taste. The genus is mostly European.
Latter: Later; more recent; coming or happening after something else; -- opposed to former; as, the former and latter rain.
lx: the Roman numeral representation of sixty; six times ten; -- a determinate quantifier.
Lowness: The state or quality of being low.
Lucubratory: Composed by candlelight, or by night; of or pertaining to night studies; laborious or painstaking.
Lions leaf: A South European plant of the genus Leontice (Leontice leontopetalum), the tuberous roots of which contain so much alkali that they are sometimes used as a substitute for soap.
&Verbar;Laryngismus: A spasmodic state of the glottis, giving rise to contraction or closure of the opening.
Lector: A reader of lections; formerly, a person designated to read lessons to the illiterate.
Loser: One who loses; as, the loser pays for a round of beer.
Lamely: In a lame, crippled, disabled, or imperfect manner; as, to walk lamely; a figure lamely drawn.
Leiotrichous: Having smooth, or nearly smooth, hair.
Lava: The melted rock ejected by a volcano from its top or fissured sides. It flows out in streams sometimes miles in length. It also issues from fissures in the earth's surface, and forms beds covering many square miles, as in the Northwestern United States.
Lazuli: A mineral of a fine azure-blue color, usually in small rounded masses. It is essentially a silicate of alumina, lime, and soda, with some sodium sulphide, is often marked by yellow spots or veins of sulphide of iron, and is much valued for ornamental work.  Called also lapis lazuli, and Armenian stone.
lace into: To attack vigorously; -- used of physical or verbal attacks; as, the boss laced into him for coming to the meeting late.
Laughable: Fitted to excite laughter; as, a laughable story; a laughable scene.
Lithontriptic: Having the quality of, or used for, dissolving or destroying stone in the bladder or kidneys; as, lithontriptic forcéps.
Layer: One who, or that which, lays.
Laurentian: Pertaining to, or near, the St. Lawrence River; as, the Laurentian hills.
&Verbar;Lied: A lay; a German song.  It differs from the French chanson, and the Italian canzone, all three being national.
lipophobic: Not soluble in lipids, or in non-polar solvents; -- of chemical substances or parts of molecules; as, the lipophobic end of a detergent is solvated in water.  Contrasted to lipophilic or nonpolar.
Left-handedness: The state or quality of being left-handed; awkwardness.
Leeway: The lateral movement of a ship to the leeward of her course; drift.
Linguistically: In a linguistic manner; from the point of view of a linguist.
lastingness: permanence by virtue of the power to resist stress or force.
Luxury: A free indulgence in costly food, dress, furniture, or anything expensive which gratifies the appetites or tastes.
Libidinous: Having lustful desires; characterized by lewdness; sensual; lascivious.
Laborless: Not involving labor; not laborious; easy.
Liberty: The state of a free person; exemption from subjection to the will of another claiming ownership of the person or services; freedom; -- opposed to slavery, serfdom, bondage, or subjection.
Ladys smock: A plant of the genus Cardamine (Cardamine pratensis); cuckoo flower.
Leucine: a naturally occurring alpha-amino acid ((CH3)2CH.CH2.CH(NH2)-COOH), one of the building units of almost all proteins of living organisms, both animal and vegetable.  It is one of the essential amino acids (not synthesized by the human body, a required component for proper nutrition), and is hydrophobic in character when bound in proteins. In isolated form it is a white, crystalline, zwitterionic substance formed, e. g. by the decomposition of proteins by pancreatic digestion, by the action of boiling dilute mineral acid, or by putrefaction. Chemically it is to be considered as amido-caproic acid.  It occurs as two optical isomers, the L- and D-forms.  The L-form, L-leucine, is the natural form, present in most proteins.
Luller: One who, or that which, lulls.
Long-waisted: Having a long waist; long from the armpits to the bottom of the waist; -- said of persons.
&Verbar;Latus rectum: The line drawn through a focus of a conic section parallel to the directrix and terminated both ways by the curve. It is the parameter of the principal axis. See Focus, and Parameter.
Limitaneous: Of or pertaining to a limit.
Loral: Of or pertaining to the lores.
Loran: A system of electronic navigation in which a vessel or aircraft determines its latitude and longitude by measuring the time differences between low frequency radio transmissions from two stationary transmitters (slaves) and a stationary master transmitter.  Contrary to the name, Loran is a medium range system, usually effective for no more than a few hundred miles from shore.  The first commercial system was called Loran A; the latest (and final) development is Loran C.
Line-up: The members of a team who are scheduled to play a game.
Lunisolar: Resulting from the united action, or pertaining to the mutual relations, of the sun and moon.
Latterly: Lately; of late; recently; at a later, as distinguished from a former, period.
Lagniappe: In Louisiana, a trifling present given to customers by tradesmen; a gratuity.
Levorotation: Rotation in the direction of an outgoing right-handed screw; counter-clockwise rotation; -- applied chiefly to the turning of the plane of polarization of light.
Laudableness: The quality of being laudable; praiseworthiness; commendableness.
Laccic: Pertaining to lac, or produced from it; as, laccic acid.
Lacerta: A genus of lizards. See Lizard.
Legibleness: The state or quality of being legible.
Laudatory: Of or pertaining praise, or to the expression of praise; as, laudatory verses; the laudatory powers of Dryden.
Laccin: A yellow amorphous substance obtained from lac.
Leechcraft: The art of healing; skill of a physician.
Lutidine: Any one of several metameric alkaloids, C5H3N.(CH3)2, of the pyridine series, obtained from bone oil as liquids, and having peculiar pungent odors. These alkaloids are also called respectively dimethyl pyridine, ethyl pyridine, etc.
Lionlike: Like a lion; brave as a lion.
Lepidodendrid: One of an extinct family of trees allied to the modern club mosses, and including Lepidodendron and its allies.
Labourite: a member of the British Labour Party.
Liquidambar: A genus consisting of two species of tall trees having star-shaped leaves, and woody burlike fruit. Liquidambar styraciflua is the North American sweet qum, and Liquidambar Orientalis is found in Asia Minor.
Lurg: A large marine annelid (Nephthys cæca), inhabiting the sandy shores of Europe and America. It is whitish, with a pearly luster, and grows to the length of eight or ten inches.
Lutanist: A person that plays on the lute.
Lambs-quarters: A name given to several common weedy European plants of the Goosefoot family, introduced into N. America, and sometimes used as pot herbs, as Chenopodium album and Atriplex patulsa.
luxuria: self-indulgent sexual desire (personified as one of the deadly sins).
Lobeliaceae: A natural family of plants not recognized in all classification systems; in some classifications lobeliaceous plants are included in family Campanulaceae.
Lanyard: A short piece of rope or line for fastening something in ships; as, the lanyards of the gun ports, of the buoy, and the like; esp., pieces passing through the dead-eyes, and used to extend shrouds, stays, etc.
Lunatic: A person affected by lunacy; an insane person, esp. one who has lucid intervals; a madman; a person of unsound mind.
Lemniscata: A curve in the form of the figure 8, with both parts symmetrical, generated by the point in which a tangent to an equilateral hyperbola meets the perpendicular on it drawn from the center.
Lipochrin: A yellow coloring matter, soluble in ether, contained in the small round fat drops in the retinal epithelium cells. It is best obtained from the eyes of frogs.
London smoke: A neutral tint given to spectacles, shade glasses for optical instruments, etc., which reduces the intensity without materially changing the color of the transmitted light.
Legatine: Of or pertaining to a legate; as, legatine power.
locating: the act of putting something in a certain place or location.
Lamb: To bring forth a lamb or lambs, as sheep.
Lama: In Tibet, Mongolia, etc., a priest or monk of the belief called Lamaism.
Lanier: A thong of leather; a whip lash.
larval: Of or pertaining to a larva.
Lipogrammatic: Omitting a letter; composed of words not having a certain letter or letters; as, lipogrammatic writings.
loose-jowled: having sagging folds of flesh beneath the chin or lower jaw.
Lemma: A preliminary or auxiliary proposition demonstrated or accepted for immediate use in the demonstration of some other proposition, as in mathematics or logic.
Lamp: A light-producing vessel, device, instrument or apparatus;
Lepadidae: A natural family of crustaceans including the goose barnacles.
Latin American: A native or inhabitant of Latin America.
Laryngotracheal: Pertaining to both larynx and trachea; as, the laryngotracheal cartilage in the frog.
Local: A train which receives and deposits passengers or freight along the line of the road; a train for the accommodation of a certain district.
Lacquerer: One who lacquers, especially one who makes a business of lacquering.
layabout: A person who does no work.
louvered window: A window having louvers in place of glass, usually over the entire surface of the window.
Lithoclast: An instrument for crushing stones in the bladder.
Lugsail: A square sail bent upon a yard that hangs obliquely to the mast and is raised or lowered with the sail.
Litharge: Lead monoxide; a yellowish red substance, obtained as an amorphous powder, or crystallized in fine scales, by heating lead moderately in a current of air or by calcining lead nitrate or carbonate. It is used in making flint glass, in glazing earthenware, in making red lead or minium, etc. Called also massicot.
Lactamide: An acid amide derived from lactic acid, and obtained as a white crystalline substance having a neutral reaction. It is metameric with alanine.
Lacwork: Ornamentation by means of lacquer painted or carved, or simply colored, sprinkled with gold or the like; -- said especially of Oriental work of this kind.
Longtail: An animal, particularly a log, having an uncut tail.  Cf. Curtail. Dog.
Leuco-: A combining form signifying white, colorless; specif. (Chem.), denoting an extensive series of colorless organic compounds, obtained by reduction from certain other colored compounds; as, leucaniline, leucaurin, etc.
Leucocyte: A colorless corpuscle, as one of the white blood corpuscles, or those found in lymph, marrow of bone, connective tissue, etc.
Limitation: The act of limiting; the state or condition of being limited; as, the limitation of his authority was approved by the council.
Letter: To impress with letters; to mark with letters or words; as, a book gilt and lettered.
Lithomarge: A clay of a fine smooth texture, and very sectile.
Lasiocampidae: A natural family of moths whose larvae include the tent caterpillars; the eggars; the lappet moths.
&Verbar;Lanugo: The soft woolly hair which covers most parts of the mammal fetus, and in man is shed before or soon after birth.
Lavolt: An old dance, for two persons, being a kind of waltz, in which the woman made a high spring or bound.
Levir: A husband's brother; -- used in reference to levirate marriages.
Leaning: The act, or state, of inclining; inclination; tendency; as, a leaning towards Calvinism.
Lumpectomy: the removal of a cyst or tumor from the breast by surgery.  This is one method of treating breast tumors when in an early stage, and is preferred for cosmetic reasons, when medically feasible, to radical mastectomy, the removal of the entire breast along with nearby muscles.
Lilliputian: Of or pertaining to the imaginary island of Lilliput described by Swift, or to its inhabitants.
lightening: The process of changing to a lighter color.
Limy: Smeared with, or consisting of, lime; viscous.
Llano: An extensive plain with or without vegetation.
Legged: Having (such or so many) legs; -- used in composition; as, a long-legged man; a two-legged animal.
leopards bane: A name of several harmless plants, as Arnica montana (Arnica acaulis syn. Doronicum acaule), Senecio Doronicum, and Paris quadrifolia.
long-range: involving an extended span of time; -- of plans, goals, or predictions; as, long-range goals; a long-range weather forecast.
Limn: To draw or paint; especially, to represent in an artistic way with pencil or brush.
Limb: A border or edge, in certain special uses.
Lastly: In the last place; in conclusion.
Lime: To smear with a viscous substance, as birdlime.
Licitation: The act of offering for sale to the highest bidder.
&Verbar;Leptomeningitis: Inflammation of the pia mater or of the arachnoid membrane.
Lysichiton: A genus of plants including one of the skunk cabbages.
Laconian: Of or pertaining to Laconia, a division of ancient Greece; Spartan.
Ledgy: Abounding in ledges; consisting of a ledge or reef; as, a ledgy island.
Lovelily: In manner to excite love; amiably.
Lochage: An officer who commanded a company; a captain.
Laterally: By the side; sidewise; toward, or from, the side.
Lady Day: The day of the annunciation of the Virgin Mary, March 25. See Annunciation.
Ledge: A shelf on which articles may be laid; also, that which resembles such a shelf in form or use, as a projecting ridge or part, or a molding or edge in joinery.
Loxodromism: The act or process of tracing a loxodromic curve; the act of moving as if in a loxodromic curve.
lunchroom: a dining room (in a school, business, or other non-domestic facility) where lunch can be purchased.
Lance: To pierce with a lance, or with any similar weapon.
Lichwort: An herb, the wall pellitory. See Pellitory.
lipemia: The presence of an abnormally high concentration of lipid in the blood.  Called also hyperlipemia, hyperlipidemia, hyperlipoidemia, lipidemia, lipoidemia.
Lanch: To throw, as a lance; to let fly; to launch.
Lamination: The process of laminating, or the state of being laminated.
Lamellar: Flat and thin; lamelliform; composed of lamellæ.
Likeness: The state or quality of being like; similitude; resemblance; similarity; as, the likeness of the one to the other is remarkable.
limonene: a liquid terpene with a lemon odor; found in lemons and oranges and other essential oils.
Longilateral: Having long sides; especially, having the form of a long parallelogram.
Long-armed: Having long arms; as, the long-armed ape or gibbon.
Ladys cloth: A kind of broadcloth of light weight, used for women's dresses, cloaks, etc.
Lackbrain: One who is deficient in understanding; a witless person.
locknut: a supplementary nut that is screwed down on a primary nut to prevent it from loosening; a check nut.
Lauraceous: Belonging to, or resembling, a natural order (Lauraceæ) of trees and shrubs having aromatic bark and foliage, and including the laurel, sassafras, cinnamon tree, true camphor tree, etc.
Lumpish: Like a lump; inert; gross; heavy; dull; spiritless.
Locomotive: A locomotive engine; a self-propelling wheel carriage, especially one which bears a steam boiler and one or more steam engines which communicate motion to the wheels and thus propel the carriage, -- used to convey goods or passengers, or to draw wagons, railroad cars, etc. See Illustration in Appendix.
Layship: The condition of being a layman.
Labor-saving: Saving labor; adapted to supersede or diminish the labor of men; designed to replace or conserve human and especially manual labor; as, labor-saving machinery;  labor-saving appliances{4}; labor-saving devices like washing machines.
Loch: A kind of medicine to be taken by licking with the tongue; a lambative; a lincture.
Lumbar: Of, pertaining to, or near, the loins; as, the lumbar arteries.
Lutation: The act or method of luting vessels.
libellulid: A dragon fly; -- from Libellula, the name of the typical genus.
Loamy: Consisting of loam; partaking of the nature of loam; resembling loam.
Lineament: One of the outlines, exterior features, or distinctive marks, of a body or figure, particularly of the face; feature; form; mark; -- usually in the plural.
lawbreaker: One who disobeys the law; someone who violates the law; a criminal.
Lamaism: A modified form of Buddhism which prevails in Tibet, Mongolia, and some adjacent parts of Asia; -- so called from the name of its priests. See 2d Lama.
