Lavishness: The quality or state of being lavish.
Litherly: Crafty; cunning; mischievous; wicked; treacherous; lazy.
Lucernal: Of or pertaining to a lamp.
Locustic: Pertaining to, or derived from, the locust; -- formerly used to designate a supposed acid.
Lexiphanicism: The use of pretentious words, language, or style.
lexicalize: To make into a word, coin into a word; as, The concept expressed by German "Gemuetlichkeit" is not lexicalized in English.
Lock-down: A contrivance to fasten logs together in rafting; -- used by lumbermen.
launchpad: a platform from which rockets or space craft are launched.
Lessee: The person to whom a lease is given, or who takes an estate by lease.
Legitimacy: The state, or quality, of being legitimate, or in conformity with law; hence, the condition of having been lawfully begotten, or born in wedlock.
Light-headed: Disordered in the head; dizzy; feeling faint; delirious.
Lightly: With little weight; with little force; as, to tread lightly; to press lightly.
Limpkin: Either one of two species of wading birds of the genus Aramus, intermediate between the cranes and rails. The limpkins are remarkable for the great length of the toes. One species (Aramus giganteus) inhabits Florida and the West Indies; the other (Aramus scolopaceus) is found in South America. Called also courlan, and crying bird.
Lactide: A white, crystalline substance, obtained from lactic acid by distillation, and regarded as an anhydride; also, by extension, any similar substance.
Linn\u00e6ite: A mineral of pale steel-gray color and metallic luster, occurring in isometric crystals, and also massive. It is a sulphide of cobalt containing some nickel or copper.
Legend: To tell or narrate, as a legend.
&Verbar;Lacuna: A small opening; a small pit or depression; a small blank space; a gap or vacancy; a hiatus.
Lutetium: A metallic element separated from ytterbium in 1907, by Urbain in Paris and by von Welsbach in Vienna.  It is a member of the Lanthanide rare earth group. Symbol, Lu; atomic number 71; atomic weight 174.967 [C=12.011].  Previously spelled Lutecium.
Leucosoid: Like or pertaining to the Leucosoidea, a tribe of marine crabs including the box crab or Calappa.
&Verbar;Legatura: A tie or brace; a syncopation.
Leave-taking: Taking of leave; the act of departing politely; the giving of parting compliments.
Limbat: A cooling periodical wind in the Isle of Cyprus, blowing from the northwest from eight o'clock, A. M., to the middle of the day or later.
Lifeless: Destitute of life, or deprived of life; not containing, or inhabited by, living beings or vegetation; dead, or apparently dead; spiritless; powerless; dull; as, a lifeless carcass; lifeless matter; a lifeless desert; a lifeless wine; a lifeless story.
Landsman: One who lives on the land; -- opposed to seaman.
Looped: Bent, folded, or tied, so as to make a loop; as, a looped wire or string.
Liberate: To release from restraint or bondage; to set at liberty; to free; to manumit; to disengage; as, to liberate a slave or prisoner; to liberate the mind from prejudice; to liberate gases.
littlest: having or being distinguished by diminutive size.
loanblend: a word that is composed of parts from different languages; e.g. monolingual has a Greek prefix and a Latin root.
Laughingstock: An object of ridicule; a butt of sport.
Laniariform: Shaped like a laniary, or canine, tooth.
Laterality: The state or condition of being lateral.
Langdak: A wolf (Canis pallipes), found in India, allied to the jackal.
Leguminous: Pertaining to pulse; consisting of pulse.
Lapper: One who takes up food or liquid with his tongue.
Lappet: To decorate with, or as with, a lappet.
Leptopteris: A genus including some ferns sometimes placed in genus Todea.
Legislator: A lawgiver; one who makes laws for a state or community; a member of a legislative body.
Latitancy: Act or state of lying hid, or lurking.
Lustration: The act of lustrating or purifying.
lanternfish: A small fish having rows of luminous organs along each side; some surface at night.
ladys-eardrop: An erect or climbing shrub (Fuchsia coccinea) of Brazil with deep pink to red flowers.
Longirostral: Having a long bill; of or pertaining to the Longirostres.
Labyrinthodont: Of or pertaining to the Labyrinthodonta.
Larkspur: A genus of ranunculaceous plants (Delphinium), having showy flowers, and a spurred calyx.  They are natives of the North Temperate zone.  The commonest larkspur of the gardens is Delphinium Consolida.  The flower of the bee larkspur (Delphinium elatum) has two petals bearded with yellow hairs, and looks not unlike a bee.
Loricate: An animal covered with bony scales, as crocodiles among reptiles, and the pangolins among mammals.
Lungworm: Any one of several species of parasitic nematoid worms which infest the lungs and air passages of cattle, sheep, and other animals, often proving fatal.  The lungworm of cattle (Strongylus micrurus) and that of sheep (Strongylus filaria) are the best known.
Laurestine: The Viburnum Tinus, an evergreen shrub or tree of the south of Europe, which flowers during the winter months.
Linden: A handsome tree (Tilia Europæa), having cymes of light yellow flowers, and large cordate leaves. The tree is common in Europe.
Ligneous: Made of wood; consisting of wood; of the nature of, or resembling, wood; woody.
Lignoceric: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid of the formic acid series, found in the tar, wax, or paraffine obtained by distilling certain kinds of wood, as the beech.
Lawless: Contrary to, or unauthorized by, law; illegal; as, a lawless claim.
Latinity: The Latin tongue, style, or idiom, or the use thereof; specifically, purity of Latin style or idiom.
Librarian: One who has the care or charge of a library.
Legation: The sending forth or commissioning one person to act for another.
Lententide: The season of Lenten or Lent.
Lapwing: A small European bird of the Plover family (Vanellus cristatus, or Vanellus vanellus). It has long and broad wings, and is noted for its rapid, irregular fight, upwards, downwards, and in circles.  Its back is coppery or greenish bronze. Its eggs are the “plover's eggs” of the London market, esteemed a delicacy.  It is called also peewit, dastard plover, and wype.  The gray lapwing is the Squatarola cinerea.
Legitimism: The principles or plans of legitimists.
Limburg cheese: A soft cheese made in the Belgian province of Limburg (Limbourg), and usually not eaten until the curing has developed a peculiar and, to most people, unpleasant odor.
Lunate: Crescent-shaped; resembling the crescent moon; as, a lunate leaf; a lunate beak; a lunated cross.
Lithotrity: The operation of breaking a stone in the bladder or urethrea into small pieces capable of being voided; lithotripsy.
Loathsome: Fitted to cause loathing; exciting disgust; disgusting; as, a loathsome disease.
&Verbar;Laminitis: Inflammation of the laminæ or fleshy plates along the coffin bone of a horse; founder.
Logometric: Serving to measure or ascertain chemical equivalents; stoichiometric.
Legislatorial: Of or pertaining to a legislator or legislature.
Legitimist: One who supports legitimate authority; esp., one who believes in hereditary monarchy, as a divine right.
Lymphangial: Of or pertaining to the lymphatics, or lymphoid tissue; lymphatic.
&Verbar;Lachrym\u00e6 Christi: A rich, sweet, red Neapolitan wine.
Labyrinthibranch: Of or pertaining to the Labyrinthici.
Latreutical: Acting as a hired servant; serving; ministering; assisting.
Law-abiding: Abiding the law; waiting for the operation of law for the enforcement of rights; also, abiding by the law; obedient to the law; as, law-abiding people.
Locator: One who locates, or is entitled to locate, land or a mining claim.
Low-lived: Characteristic of, or like, one bred in a low and vulgar condition of life; mean; dishonorable; contemptible; as, low-lived dishonesty.
Lammas: The first day of August; -- called also Lammas day, and Lammastide.
Lawyer: One versed in the laws, or a practitioner of law; one whose profession is to conduct lawsuits for clients, or to advise as to prosecution or defence of lawsuits, or as to legal rights and obligations in other matters. It is a general term, comprehending attorneys, counselors, solicitors, barristers, sergeants, and advocates.
Lifelike: Like a living being; resembling life; giving an accurate representation; as, a lifelike portrait.
lobster-backed: Of or pertaining to British soldiers during the Revolutionary War in America; -- so called because of their red coats.
Lyrate: Lyre-shaped, or spatulate and oblong, with small lobes toward the base; as, a lyrate leaf.
&Verbar;Lern\u00e6acea: A suborder of copepod Crustacea, including a large number of remarkable forms, mostly parasitic on fishes. The young, however, are active and swim freely. See Illustration in Appendix.
Log: To engage in the business of cutting or transporting logs for timber; to get out logs.
Laryngoscopy: The art of using the laryngoscope; investigations made with the laryngoscope.
Leeward: Pertaining to, or in the direction of, the part or side toward which the wind blows; -- opposed to windward; as, a leeward berth; a leeward ship.
Ledger: A book in which a summary of accounts is laid up or preserved; the final book of record in business transactions, in which all debits and credits from the journal, etc., are placed under appropriate heads.
Lilt: Animated, brisk motion; spirited rhythm; sprightliness.
Lop: Hanging down; as, lop ears; -- used also in compound adjectives; as, lopeared; lopsided.
Laryngoscope: An instrument, consisting of an arrangement of two mirrors, for reflecting light upon the larynx, and for examining its image.
Locomotor: Of or pertaining to movement or locomotion.
Leaky: Permitting water or other fluid to leak in or out; as, a leaky roof or cask; a leaky faucet.
Lily: A plant and flower of the genus Lilium, endogenous bulbous plants, having a regular perianth of six colored pieces, six stamens, and a superior three-celled ovary.
Leonurus: A genus of stout Old World herbs having cut-lobed leaves and flowers in whorls.
lavalava: A printed cloth garment resembling a skirt or kilt, worn as the principle garment by both men and women in Polynesia, especialy in  Samoa; called also pareu.
Ladify: To make a lady of; to make ladylike.
Lithuanian: A native, or one of the people, of Lithuania; also, the language of the Lithuanian people.
Lyceum: A place of exercise with covered walks, in the suburbs of Athens, where Aristotle taught philosophy.
Ladys bedstraw: The common bedstraw (Galium verum); also, a slender-leaved East Indian shrub (Pharnaceum Mollugo), with white flowers in umbels.
Legatee: One to whom a legacy is bequeathed.
Lugmark: A mark cut into the ear of an animal to identify it; an earmark.
Lienteric: Of or pertaining to, or of the nature of, a lientery.
Laburnine: A poisonous alkaloid found in the unripe seeds of the laburnum.
lobectomy: surgical removal of a lobe from any organ of the body (such as the lung or brain).
Lamp-post: A post (generally a pillar of iron) supporting a lamp or lantern for lighting a street, park, etc.
&Verbar;Loligo: A genus of cephalopods, including numerous species of squids, common on the coasts of America and Europe. They are much used for fish bait.
Looking-glass: A mirror made of glass on which has been placed a backing of some reflecting substance, as quicksilver.
locomote: To change location; move, travel, or proceed.
laminated: Consisting of, or covered with, laminae, or thin plates, sheets, scales, or layers, one over another; laminate.
&Verbar;Lautverschiebung: The regular changes which the primitive Indo-European stops, or mute consonants, underwent in the Teutonic languages, probably as early as the 3d century b. c. , often called the first Lautverschiebung, sound shifting, or consonant shifting.
Lollop: To move heavily; to lounge or idle; to loll.
Logistics: That branch of the military art which embraces the details of moving and supplying armies. The meaning of the word is by some writers extended to include strategy.
Lemnaceae: A natural family of small free-floating thalloid plants.
laser: A device which produces an intense, usually narrow, monochromatic beam of coherent light; called also optical maser.  It has various forms, and is used in various applications in science and technology.  The beam is produced by boosting the majority of the electrons in specific radiation-absorbing atoms in a medium into a higher energy level, from which they are stimulated by their own emitted radiation to drop back synchronously to their lower energy level, and emit light which is in phase (coherent).
Lickpenny: A devourer or absorber of money.
Libelant: One who libels; one who institutes a suit in an ecclesiastical or admiralty court.
Lavish: To expend or bestow with profusion; to use with prodigality; to squander; as, to lavish money or praise.
&Verbar;Lucernaria: A genus of acalephs, having a bell-shaped body with eight groups of short tentacles around the margin.  It attaches itself by a sucker at the base of the pedicel.
Lumpfish: A large, thick, clumsy, marine fish (Cyclopterus lumpus) of Europe and America. The color is usually translucent sea green, sometimes purplish. It has a dorsal row of spiny tubercles, and three rows on each side, but has no scales. The ventral fins unite and form a ventral sucker for adhesion to stones and seaweeds. Called also lumpsucker, cock-paddle, sea owl.
Latency: The state or quality of being latent.
Laodicean: Of or pertaining to Laodicea, a city in Phrygia Major; like the Christians of Laodicea; lukewarm in religion.
Lupuline: An alkaloid extracted from hops as a colorless volatile liquid.
law-breaking: an act punishable by law; usually considered an evil act.
Lethean: Of or pertaining to Lethe; resembling in effect the water of Lethe.
Latibulize: To retire into a den, or hole, and lie dormant in winter; to retreat and lie hid.
Lipic: Pertaining to, or derived from, fat. The word was formerly used specifically to designate a supposed acid obtained by the oxidation of oleic acid, tallow, wax, etc.
Leafcup: A coarse American composite weed (Polymnia Uvedalia).
Laundering: The act, or occupation, of one who launders; washing and ironing.
Lampblack: The fine impalpable soot obtained from the smoke of carbonaceous substances which have been only partly burnt, as in the flame of a smoking lamp. It consists of finely divided carbon, with sometimes a very small proportion of various impurities. It is used as an ingredient of printers' ink, and various black pigments and cements.
Lithesome: Pliant; limber; flexible; supple; nimble; lissom.
Lobe: Any projection or division, especially one of a somewhat rounded form
left-brain: Of or pertaining to the left cerebral hemisphere of the brain.
Lichen: One of a class of cellular, flowerless plants, (technically called Lichenes), having no distinction of leaf and stem, usually of scaly, expanded, frond-like forms, but sometimes erect or pendulous and variously branched. They derive their nourishment from the air, and generate by means of spores. The species are very widely distributed, and form irregular spots or patches, usually of a greenish or yellowish color, upon rocks, trees, and various bodies, to which they adhere with great tenacity. They are often improperly called rock moss or tree moss.
Latinitaster: One who has but a smattering of Latin.
largest: greatest in size of those under consideration.
Lions ear: A name given in Western South America to certain plants with shaggy tomentose leaves, as species of Culcitium, and Espeletia.
Lalo: The powdered leaves of the baobab tree, used by the Africans to mix in their soup, as the southern negroes use powdered sassafras.  Cf. Couscous.
lipidosis: A disorder of lipid metabolism, whether congenital or acquired.
Lactescence: The state or quality of producing milk, or milklike juice; resemblance to milk; a milky color.
&Verbar;Liederkranz: Lit., wreath of songs; -- used as the title of a group of songs, and esp. as the common name for German vocal clubs of men.
Legerdemain: Sleight of hand; a trick of sleight of hand; hence, any artful deception or trick.
&Verbar;Lindia: A peculiar genus of rotifers, remarkable for the absence of ciliated disks. By some zoölogists it is thought to be like the ancestral form of the Arthropoda.
Lacteal: One of the lymphatic vessels which convey chyle from the small intestine through the mesenteric glands to the thoracic duct; a chyliferous vessel.
Lactean: Milky; consisting of, or resembling, milk.
Lysimachia: a cosmopolitan genus of plants, including some of the loosestrifes, found in damp or swampy terrain having usually yellow flowers; they are inclined to be invasive.
Lichenographist: One who describes lichens; one versed in lichenography.
low-voltage: subjected to or capable of operating under relative low voltage, usually considered as no greater than 250 volts.  Contrasted with high-voltage.
Labret: A piece of wood, shell, stone, or other substance, worn in a perforation of the lip or cheek by many savages.
&Verbar;Latigo: A strap for tightening a saddle girth.
lizardfish: Any of several mostly tropical marine scopeloid fish of the family Synodontidae having large mouths in lizardlike heads, especially the inshore lizardfish (Synodus foetens syn. Synodus poeyi) of Mideastern and Southern United States and West Indies; -- sometimes called sand pike.
Loveliness: The state or quality of being lovely.
Light-winged: Having light and active wings; volatile; fleeting.
Lumbricoid: Like an earthworm; belonging to the genus Lumbricus, or family Lumbricidæ.
Lucre: Gain in money or goods; profit; riches; -- often in an ill sense.
Lampyridae: A natural family of insects comprising the fireflies.
Lingulate: Shaped like the tongue or a strap; ligulate.
Lexigraphy: The art or practice of defining words; definition of words.
lightbulb: A glass bulb with metallic contacts on the outside connected to a wire filament (usually tungsten) inside that emits light when heated by passage of electricity through the filament; -- used as the replaceable light-emitting component of an electric lamp, flashlight, lighting fixture, etc.
Leptorhine: Having the nose narrow; -- said especially of the skull.  Opposed to platyrhine.
Lectual: Confining to the bed; as, a lectual disease.
Lamellate: Composed of, or furnished with, thin plates or scales. See Illust. of Antennæ.
Larixinic: Of, or derived from, the larch (Larix); as, larixinic acid.
Leptodactyl: A bird or other animal having slender toes.
Lonesome: Secluded from society; not frequented by human beings; solitary.
Lab: To prate; to gossip; to babble; to blab.
Larvacea: A class sometimes classified as an order.
Lancegay: A kind of spear anciently used. Its use was prohibited by a statute of Richard II.
low-level: weak; not intense; as, low-level radiation.
Lutheran: One who accepts or adheres to the doctrines of Luther or the Lutheran Church.
Lientery: A diarrhea, in which the food is discharged imperfectly digested, or with but little change.
Labioplasty: A plastic operation for making a new lip, or for replacing a lost tissue of a lip.
lion-hunter: someone who tries to attract social lions as guests.
Lustrum: A lustration or purification, especially the purification of the whole Roman people, which was made by the censors once in five years.
leg-pull: An attempt to make somebody believe something that is not true, done as a joke.
letter-perfect: correct to the last detail; especially being in or following the exact words; as, a letter-perfect rendition of the soliloquy.
Lutein: A substance of a strongly marked yellow color, extracted from the yolk of eggs, and from the tissue of the corpus luteum.
Landlubber: One who passes his life on land; -- so called among seamen in contempt or ridicule.
Lazar: A person infected with a filthy or pestilential disease; a leper.
Luteic: Pertaining to, or derived from, weld (Reseda luteola).
Loquat: The fruit of the Japanese medlar (Photinia Japonica). It is as large as a small plum, but grows in clusters, and contains four or five large seeds. Also, the tree itself.
Lickerish: Eager; craving; urged by desire; eager to taste or enjoy; greedy.
&Verbar;Lipoma: A tumor consisting of fat or adipose tissue.
Lacunose: Furrowed or pitted; having shallow cavities or lacunæ; as, a lacunose leaf.
Lustring: A kind of glossy silk fabric. See Lutestring.
Launderer: One who follows the business of laundering.
Leucophane: A mineral of a greenish yellow color; it is a silicate of glucina, lime, and soda with fluorine. Called also leucophanite.
Lutist: One who plays on a lute.
&Verbar;Lacertus: A bundle or fascicle of muscular fibers.
Lanciform: Having the form of a lance.
Laziness: The state or quality of being lazy.
Lycaena: The type genus of the Lycaenidae; small slender butterflies with upper surface of wings usually metallic blue or green or copper.
Llyr: the sea personified, father of Manawydan; corresponds to the Irish Ler.
Leucoturic: Pertaining to, or designating, a nitrogenous organic substance of the uric acid group, called leucoturic acid or oxalantin. See Oxalantin.
Lowliness: The state or quality of being lowly; humility; humbleness of mind.
Lindheimera: A genus having only one species, the Texas star.
Laminating: Forming, or separating into, scales or thin layers.
Licheniform: Having the form of a lichen.
Localize: To make local; to fix in, or assign to, a definite place.
libidinal: Of or pertaining to the libido; caused by libido; as, libidinal gratification; libidinal impulses.
Lunulet: A small spot, shaped like a half-moon or crescent; as, the lunulet on the wings of many insects.
Lieberk\u00fchns glands: The simple tubular glands of the small intestines; -- called also crypts of Lieberkühn.
Loggat: A small log or piece of wood.
Lining: The act of one who lines; the act or process of making lines, or of inserting a lining.
Litany: A solemn form of supplication in the public worship of various churches, in which the clergy and congregation join, the former leading and the latter responding in alternate sentences. It is usually of a penitential character.
Labialism: The quality of being labial; as, the labialism of an articulation; conversion into a labial, as of a sound which is different in another language.
Lenticel: One of the small, oval, rounded spots upon the stem or branch of a plant, from which the underlying tissues may protrude or roots may issue, either in the air, or more commonly when the stem or branch is covered with water or earth.
Lichanura: A genus of boas of western North America.
&Verbar;Lates: A genus of large percoid fishes, of which one species (Lates Niloticus) inhabits the Nile, and another (Lates calcarifer) is found in the Ganges and other Indian rivers. They are valued as food fishes.
Loader: One who, or that which, loads; a mechanical contrivance for loading, as a gun.
&Verbar;Latex: A milky or colored juice in certain plants in cavities (called latex cells or latex tubes). It contains the peculiar principles of the plants, whether aromatic, bitter, or acid, and in many instances yields caoutchouc upon coagulation.  The lattex of the India rubber plant produces the rubber of commerce on coagulation.
lepiota: any fungus of the genus Lepiota.
latched: secured by means of a latch against opening.
laryngotracheotomy: The operation of cutting into the larynx and the upper part of the trachea, -- a frequent operation for obstruction to breathing.
Lapping: A kind of machine blanket or wrapping material used by calico printers.
lithoglypher: One who curs or engraves precious stones.
Luminosity: The quality or state of being luminous; luminousness.
&Verbar;Lith\u00e6mia: A condition in which uric (lithic) acid is present in the blood.
Louping: An enzoötic, often fatal, disease of sheep and other domestic animals, of unknown cause. It is characterized by muscular tremors and spasms, followed by more or less complete paralysis. The principal lesion is an inflammation of the membranes covering the brain and spinal cord.
Lutestring: A plain, stout, lustrous silk, used for ladies' dresses and for ribbon.
lumberjack: a person who works at lumbering; a lumberman.
Left-hand: Situated on the left; nearer the left hand than the right; as, the left-hand side; the left-hand road.
lipid: Any of a variety of oily or greasy organic compounds found as major structural components of living cells; they are insoluble in water but soluble in organic solvents such as alcohol and ether, and include the common fats, cholesterol and other steroids, phospholipids, sphingolipids, waxes, and fatty acids; some of the lipids, together with proteins and carbohydrates, form an essential structural component of living cells, as in the cell walls and membranes.  The term lipid refers to its solubility in nonpolar solvents, and has no significance with regard to chemical structure.
Lament: Grief or sorrow expressed in complaints or cries; lamentation; a wailing; a moaning; a weeping.
Lankness: The state or quality of being lank.
&Verbar;L\u00e6modipoda: A division of amphipod Crustacea, in which the abdomen is small or rudimentary and the legs are often reduced to five pairs. The whale louse, or Cyamus, and Caprella are examples.
lawyerbush: A stout-stemmed trailing shrub (Rubus cissoides) of New Zealand that scrambles over other growth.
Literature: Learning; acquaintance with letters or books.
Laplander: A native or inhabitant of Lapland; -- called also Lapp.
Loyalist: A person who adheres to his sovereign or to the lawful authority; especially, one who maintains his allegiance to his prince or government, and defends his cause in times of revolt or revolution.
Lyrie: A European fish (Peristethus cataphractum), having the body covered with bony plates, and having three spines projecting in front of the nose; -- called also noble, pluck, pogge, sea poacher, and armed bullhead.
&Verbar;Largo: Slow or slowly; -- more so than adagio; next in slowness to grave, which is also weighty and solemn.
Labored: Bearing marks of labor and effort; elaborately wrought; not easy or natural; as, labored poetry; a labored style.
Logical: Of or pertaining to logic; used in logic; as, logical subtilties.
Lascivious: Wanton; lewd; lustful; as, lascivious men; lascivious desires.
Lagging: The clothing (esp., an outer, wooden covering), as of a steam cylinder, applied to prevent the radiation of heat; a covering of lags; -- called also deading and cleading.
Leafstalk: The stalk or petiole which supports a leaf.
Ladyship: The rank or position of a lady; -- given as a title (preceded by her or your).
Lichenography: A description of lichens; the science which illustrates the natural history of lichens.
Lablab: an East Indian name for several twining leguminous plants related to the bean, but commonly applied to the hyacinth bean (Dolichos Lablab).
Lammergeir: A very large vulture (Gypaëtus barbatus), which inhabits the mountains of Southern Europe, Asia, and Northern Africa.  When full-grown it is nine or ten feet in extent of wings.  It is brownish black above, with the under parts and neck rusty yellow; the forehead and crown white; the sides of the head and beard black.  It feeds partly on carrion and partly on small animals, which it kills.  It has the habit of carrying tortoises and marrow bones to a great height, and dropping them on stones to obtain the contents, and is therefore called bonebreaker and ossifrage.  It is supposed to be the ossifrage of the Bible. Called also bearded vulture and bearded eagle.
Lateritious: Like bricks; of the color of red bricks.
louvered: supplied with louvers for ventilation; as, a louvered door.
Liguliflorous: Bearing only ligulate flowers; -- said of a large suborder of composite plants, such as the dandelion, lettuce, hawkweed, etc.
&Verbar;Lagophthalmia: A morbid condition in which the eye stands wide open, giving a peculiar staring appearance.
Lutzen: A battle in the Thirty Years' War (1632) at which the Swedes under King Gustavus Adolphus defeated the Imperialists under Wallenstein, and in which Adolphus was killed.
Leninism: a form of communism based on the writings of Marx and Lenin; called also Marxism-Leninism.
Long-breathed: Having the power of retaining the breath for a long time; long-winded.
Low-thoughted: Having one's thoughts directed toward mean or insignificant subjects.
Lightroom: A small room from which the magazine of a naval vessel is lighted, being separated from the magazine by heavy glass windows.
Lincture: Medicine taken by licking with the tongue.
Limitive: Involving a limit; as, a limitive law, one designed to limit existing powers.
Lithiophilite: A phosphate of manganese and lithium; a variety of triphylite.
lyreflower: A garden plant (Dicentra spectabilis) having deep-pink drooping heart-shaped flowers.
Low-church: Not placing a high estimate on ecclesiastical organizations or forms; -- applied especially to Episcopalians, and opposed to high-church. See High Church, under High.
Loxodromic: Pertaining to sailing on rhumb lines; as, loxodromic tables.
Lomentaceous: Of the nature of a loment; having fruits like loments.
Licentious: Characterized by license; passing due bounds; excessive; abusive of freedom; wantonly offensive; as, a licentious press.
Lustful: Full of lust; excited by lust.
Loon: Any one of several aquatic, wed-footed, northern birds of the genus Urinator (formerly Colymbus), noted for their expertness in diving and swimming under water. The common loon, or great northern diver (Urinator imber, or Colymbus torquatus), and the red-throated loon or diver (Urinator septentrionalis), are the best known species. See Diver.
Lithochromics: The art of printing colored pictures on canvas from oil paintings on stone.
Lancashire boiler: A steam boiler having two flues which contain the furnaces and extend through the boiler from end to end.
Laudanum: Tincture of opium, used for various medical purposes.
Lecherous: Like a lecher; addicted to lewdness; excessively lustful; -- used mostly of men;
Ladylikeness: The quality or state of being ladylike.
Lutecium: same as Lutetium; -- an older spelling.
Loess: A quaternary deposit, usually consisting of a fine yellowish earth, on the banks of the Rhine and other large rivers.
Lycopsida: The class including club mosses and related forms: includes Lycopodiales; Isoetales; Selaginellales; and extinct Lepidodendrales; sometimes considered a subdivision of Tracheophyta.
lowered: pointed downward; as, with lowered eyes.  Opposite of raised.
Livingness: The state or quality of being alive; possession of energy or vigor; animation; quickening.
Longan: A pulpy fruit related to the litchi, and produced by an evergreen East Indian longanberry (Nephelium Longan).
Lobefoot: A bird having lobate toes; esp., a phalarope.
Leading edge: the front edge of an airfoil; same as Advancing edge, above.
Laureation: The act of crowning with laurel; the act of conferring an academic degree, or honorary title.
Leasing: The act of lying; falsehood; a lie or lies.
Lr: The chemical symbol for lawrencium, a transuranic element of atomic number 103.
Labyrinthodon: A genus of very large fossil amphibians, of the Triassic period, having bony plates on the under side of the body. It is the type of the order Labyrinthodonta. Called also Mastodonsaurus.
Lamarckism: The theory that structural variations, characteristic of species and genera, are produced in animals and plants by the direct influence of physical environments, and esp., in the case of animals, by effort, or by use or disuse of certain organs.  It is a discredited theory, not believed by modern biologists.
Linsey-woolsey: Made of linen and wool; hence, of different and unsuitable parts; mean.
Looper: An instrument, as a bodkin, for forming a loop in yarn, a cord, etc.
Leaf-nosed: Having a leaflike membrane on the nose; -- said of certain bats, esp. of the genera Phyllostoma and Rhinonycteris. See Vampire.
&Verbar;Llanero: One of the inhabitants of the llanos of South America.
Latchstring: A string for raising the latch of a door by a person outside. It is fastened to the latch and passed through a hole above it in the door.
lubricated: smeared with oil or grease to reduce friction.
Lampern: The river lamprey (Ammocœtes  fluviatilis syn. Lampetra fluviatilis).
Larderer: One in charge of the larder.
Linament: Lint; esp., lint made into a tent for insertion into wounds or ulcers.
Libertinism: The state of a libertine or freedman.
Laden: Loaded; freighted; burdened; as, a laden vessel; a laden heart.
&Verbar;Lithodomus: A genus of elongated bivalve shells, allied to the mussels, and remarkable for their ability to bore holes for shelter, in solid limestone, shells, etc. Called also Lithophagus.
Lessener: One who, or that which, lessens.
Lake: A large body of water contained in a depression of the earth's surface, and supplied from the drainage of a more or less extended area.
Laky: Transparent; -- said of blood rendered transparent by the action of some solvent agent on the red blood corpuscles.
Loom: The state of looming; esp., an unnatural and indistinct appearance of elevation or enlargement of anything, as of land or of a ship, seen by one at sea.
lived-in: having residents; as, a house with a lived-in look.
Lactone: One of a series of organic compounds, being cyclic esters which may be regarded as anhydrides of certain hydroxy acids.  In general, they are colorless liquids, having a weak aromatic odor. They are so called because the typical lactone is derived from lactic acid.
lobotomy: The surgical interruption of nerve tracts to and from the frontal lobe of the brain, by cutting into the brain.
Lowering: Dark and threatening; gloomy; sullen; as, lowering clouds or sky.
Lander: One who lands, or makes a landing.
Lumbago: A rheumatic pain in the loins and the small of the back.
Lastage: A duty exacted, in some fairs or markets, for the right to carry things where one will.
Luxurious: Of or pertaining to luxury; ministering to luxury; supplied with the conditions of luxury; as, a luxurious life; a luxurious table; luxurious ease.
lookup: an operation that determines whether one or more of a set of items has a specified property; as, they wrote a program to do a table lookup.
Lyre bird: Any one of two or three species of Australian birds of the genus Menura. The male is remarkable for having the sixteen tail feathers very long and, when spread, arranged in the form of a lyre. The common lyre bird (Menura superba), inhabiting New South Wales, is about the size of a grouse. Its general color is brown, with rufous color on the throat, wings, tail coverts and tail. Called also lyre pheasant and lyre-tail.
Labyrinthic: Like or pertaining to a labyrinth.
Ladanum: A gum resin gathered from certain Oriental species of Cistus. It has a pungent odor and is chiefly used in making plasters, and for fumigation.
Loss: The act of losing; failure; destruction; privation; as, the loss of property; loss of money by gaming; loss of health or reputation.
&Verbar;Loricata: A suborder of edentates, covered with bony plates, including the armadillos.
Laborer: One who labors in a toilsome occupation; a person who does work that requires strength rather than skill, as distinguished from that of an artisan.
&Verbar;Langue doc: The dialect, closely akin to French, formerly spoken south of the Loire (in which the word for “yes” was oc); Provençal.
Lost: Parted with unwillingly or unintentionally; not to be found; missing; as, a lost book or sheep.
Limit: To beg, or to exercise functions, within a certain limited region; as, a limiting friar.
lateen-rig: the rig on a sailing vessel with a lateen sail.
Lose: To suffer loss, disadvantage, or defeat; to be worse off, esp. as the result of any kind of contest.
&Verbar;Lophiomys: A very singular rodent (Lophiomys Imhausi) of Northeastern Africa. It is the only known representative of a special family (Lophiomyidæ), remarkable for the structure of the skull. It has handlike feet, and the hair is peculiar in structure and arrangement.
Limoniad: A nymph of the meadows; -- called also Limniad.
Largition: The bestowment of a largess or gift.
Lorettine: One of an order of nuns founded in 1812 at Loretto, in Kentucky. The members of the order (called also Sisters of Loretto, or Friends of Mary at the Foot of the Cross) devote themselves to the cause of education and the care of destitute orphans, their labors being chiefly confined to the western United States.
&Verbar;Labrus: A genus of marine fishes, including the wrasses of Europe. See Wrasse.
&Verbar;Longicornia: A division of beetles, including a large number of species, in which the antennæ are very long.  Most of them, while in the larval state, bore into the wood or beneath the bark of trees, and some species are very destructive to fruit and shade trees. See Apple borer, under Apple, and Locust beetle, under Locust.
Lambale: A feast at the time of shearing lambs.
Laccolite: A mass of igneous rock intruded between sedimentary beds and resulting in a mammiform bulging of the overlying strata.
lactose: The main sugar present in milk, called also sugar of milk or milk sugar.  When isolated pure it is obtained crystalline; it is separable from the whey by evaporation and crystallization.  It is a disaccharide with the formula C12H22O11, being chemically 4-(β-D-galactosido)-D-glucose. It has a slightly sweet taste, is dextrorotary, and is much less soluble in water than either cane sugar or glucose. Formerly called lactin.  When hydrolyzed it yields glucose and galactose.  In cells it may be hydrolyzed by the enzyme β-galactosidase.
Lithophyte: A hard, or stony, plantlike organism, as the gorgonians, corals, and corallines, esp. those gorgonians having a calcareous axis. All the lithophytes except the corallines are animals.
Livery: To clothe in, or as in, livery.
Ladys traces: A name given to several species of the orchidaceous genus Spiranthes, in which the white flowers are set in spirals about a slender axis and remotely resemble braided hair.
&Verbar;Labrum: A lip or edge, as of a basin.
